text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The Jacksonville Jaguars have one victory, the lowest-ranked offense and one of the worst run defenses after the first month of the N.F.L. season.

headline: Iran Denies Plan to End Nuclear Standoff
text: TEHRAN — Iranian officials on Saturday dismissed a New York Times report saying Iran had offered a “nine-step plan” for resolving a standoff with the United States and its allies over its disputed nuclear program, calling the report “baseless.”

headline: Americans Join Pakistan Convoy to Protest Drone Strikes
text: CHASHMA, Pakistan — Hundreds of political activists, led by the opposition politician Imran Khan and accompanied by 32 American peace activists, departed Pakistan’s capital on Saturday in a convoy headed toward the country’s tribal regions to protest American drone strikes.

headline: They Work Long Hours, but What About Results?
text: IT’S 5 p.m. at the office. Working fast, you’ve finished your tasks for the day and want to go home. But none of your colleagues have left yet, so you stay another hour or two, surfing the Web and reading your e-mails again, so you don’t come off as a slacker.

headline: Sports Replay, Oct. 6
text: A look at the day in sports worldwide, from motorcycle racing in Egypt to cricket in Sri Lanka.

headline: Beyond Our ‘True Calling’
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Seeds That Federal Money Can Plant
text: LUIS VON AHN, a computer scientist at Carnegie Mellon University, sold one Internet start-up to Google in 2009, and is now on to another. With the new company, Duolingo, he hopes to tap the millions of people learning languages online to create a crowdsourced engine of translation. “We want to translate the whole Web into every major language,” Mr. von Ahn says.

headline: How the G.O.P. Became the Anti-Urban Party
text: A LEADING Republican columnist, trying to re-stoke her candidate’s faltering campaign before the first presidential debate, felt so desperate that she advised him to turn to cities.

headline: The Case for Calm Over Rising Health Costs
text: IN 1946, a British newspaper shocked its readers by running an article with this ominous-sounding headline: “Nearly Half of U.K. Student Grades Are Below Average.” Read that back to yourself slowly, and you’ll realize, of course, that the law of averages would have it no other way. But man, does it sound bad.

headline: Housing Fever Can Work Both Ways
text: THE boom and bust in the housing market was a dual social epidemic. First, there was an epidemic of positive thinking that led to high expectations for long-term home price appreciation — and for the economy, too. Then, after 2005, an epidemic of negative thinking discouraged many people from buying a house or from spending in general, and kept many employers from hiring.

headline: In Ryder Cup, Yay, Team!
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Information About Cancer? Suppress It!
text: My Sunday column looks at what I call “the cancer lobby” — a term that will have said lobby writing in indignation about now. But I’m pretty indignant, too.

headline: Rutgers Shuts Down Connecticut
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Rutgers’s top-ranked rushing defense continued its dominant season, holding Connecticut to 53 yards on the ground in a 19-3 victory Saturday.

headline: Democrats Bet on Shift in Hispanic Numbers to Win Arizona Race
text: TUCSON — The man who could be the first Latino to represent Arizona in the Senate, Richard H. Carmona, says he is not fooling himself. “I want to be realistic on the expectations,” he said last week at his office.

headline: Market Clarity When Campaign Feathers Fly
text: “IN the short run, the market is a voting machine, but in the long run it is a weighing machine,” Benjamin Graham, the guru of value investing, once wrote about the stock market.

headline: Good, by Design
text: Innovative change makers are trying to create a beautiful, just world.

headline: Dignifying Design
text: IN 2006 a 26-year-old architecture student, Michael Murphy, approached the global health pioneer Paul Farmer after a lecture at Harvard. Mr. Murphy asked which architects Dr. Farmer had worked with to build the clinics, housing, schools and even the roads he had described in his talk. An aspiring social entrepreneur, Mr. Murphy was hoping to put his design degree to use by apprenticing with the humanitarian architects aiding Dr. Farmer’s work. But it turns out, those architects didn’t exist.

headline: Assistants, Yes, but They Can Do It All
text: THEIR titles vary: executive assistant, administrative assistant, the syllable-clipped “admin,” the classic secretary. Whatever you call them, these professionals continue to keep offices running as technology and budget cuts reshape their roles.

headline: Writing With Miles Davis
text: If Miles Davis’s midcentury trumpet solos can be described by a single phrase, it might be “doing more with less.” Despite his renown, Davis wasn’t a flashy or highly technical player during the late 1950s and early ’60s. He was melodic and economical, and his approach can teach prose writers a lot about the power of concision, suggestion and space.

headline: A Career’s Building Blocks
text: I LIVE on ancestral land that my family has owned in Alabama for almost 200 years. My wife and I have created a green space on part of it for school groups, church groups and organizations like the Boy Scouts to enjoy. Our family chapel is there, too.

headline: With Baltimore, Buck Showalter Faces Past in Present
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Baltimore Orioles were wildly drenching themselves in celebration Friday, but Manager Buck Showalter was still dry. Suddenly, Jim Thome emerged, wrapped tightly in postseason plastic, and began to uncork a bottle of Champagne.

headline: Knicks Battle Injuries Early
text: The Knicks, a team with several older veterans, announced their first significant injury of training camp Saturday. Marcus Camby, a 38-year-old power forward, will likely miss the first two preseason games with a strained left calf.

headline: Mutual Fund Investors, Flying Again but Feeling Dizzy
text: THE ups and downs that have unnerved investors for at least two years produced another course correction for the stock market in the third quarter. A spring decline gave way to a summer rally that took popular indexes to their highest levels in at least five years.

headline: Ways to Play a Recovery in Housing
text: WALL STREET prides itself on seeing things before they are broadly apparent. But, sometimes, even the shrewdest investors get ahead of themselves. The stock market, the old joke goes, has predicted nine of the last five recessions.

headline: Nowadays, I Can’t Even Invest in My Words
text: IT’S not an easy time to be an investor — especially an inept investor. My buy-and-hold strategy feels like trying to tread water while holding a sack of hammers.

headline: A.L.D.S. Preview: Drought Over, Orioles Face a Seasoned Foe
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Baltimore Orioles did not stage a wild celebration upon securing a spot in the postseason because they clinched a berth while traveling last Sunday night. But the bubbly flowed in the clubhouse here late Friday, and Adam Jones, the center fielder and team leader, surveyed the scene.

headline: Emerging Markets Are More Than Just the BRICs
text: THE BRIC backlash has begun.

headline: Fund Investors Are Nearing the Edge, Too
text: TAX increases and federal spending cuts scheduled for the end of 2012 could lop off nearly four percentage points of annual economic growth, according to government and private estimates. In an economy expanding at less than a 2 percent annual rate, this fiscal cliff, as the potential decline is called, is a concern on Wall Street, in Washington and beyond.

headline: For Uncertain Times, Some Back-to-Basics Advice
text: AFTER a loss in which his Green Bay Packers played horrifically, Coach Vince Lombardi, according to legend, announced to the team that it would be returning to fundamentals.

headline: N.L.D.S. Preview: A Fractured Timeline From Senators to Expos to Nationals
text: On Oct. 7, 1933, at Griffith Stadium, Dolf Luque of the New York Giants struck out Joe Kuhel of the Washington Senators for the final out of the World Series. This was the last postseason game in Washington.

headline: Avoiding Yardsticks, Bond Funds Excel
text: BOND funds are on track for their best year since 2009, and the secret to many managers’ recent success has been simple: just don’t mimic the indexes.

headline: In Search of Funds That Don’t Rock the Boat
text: IN the canon of investing commandments, risk and return are inextricably linked. We’ve had it pounded into our heads that having a shot at higher returns requires accepting a more volatile portfolio. And any suggestion that it’s possible to ratchet down volatility without sacrificing performance would be an act of modern portfolio blasphemy, or a specious marketing ploy. Right?

headline: What a Difference a Percentage Point Can Make
text: INVESTORS can’t count on very much these days. The economy remains troubled, the stock market is volatile and the bond market seems fraught with risk.

headline: Q & A
text: Neighbor’s Dog Barks for Hours

headline: For Three Top Funds, the Paths to Success Don’t Cross
text: OIL refineries, all-terrain vehicles and European banks would seem to share little, but they helped to provide good returns to managers of three of the better-performing mutual funds of the third quarter.

headline: Space Invasion
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — A HIGH FIVE to Zoe Wheeler for being the first to have HIGH FIVE in a New York Times crossword puzzle. Considering how long we’ve all been slapping each other silly up high, wouldn’t you think the phrase would have made it into a puzzle by now?

headline: A Child’s Remains Are Found in a Backyard on Long Island
text: A routine visit by child welfare authorities on Long Island led to a multicounty search for a boy who was mysteriously absent, an Amber Alert for one of the boy’s half-brothers and the discovery of a small body in a shallow grave in the backyard of the family’s home, the police said Saturday.

headline: Citing U.S. Fears, Arab Allies Limit Syrian Rebel Aid
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — For months, Saudi Arabia and Qatar have been funneling money and small arms to Syria’s rebels but have refused to provide heavier weapons, like shoulder-fired missiles, that could allow opposition fighters to bring down government aircraft, take out armored vehicles and turn the war’s tide.

headline: Scant Oversight of Drug Maker in Fatal Meningitis Outbreak
text: Eddie C. Lovelace, a Kentucky judge still on the bench into his late 70s, had a penchant for reciting Shakespeare from memory and telling funny stories in his big, booming voice. But a car accident last spring left him with severe neck pain, and in July and August he sought spinal injections with a steroid medicine for relief.

headline: Cardinals, With Edge in Experience, Consider Themselves Underdogs
text: ST. LOUIS — Experience was the key word here Saturday, popping up in all contexts and conversations as the St. Louis Cardinals and Washington Nationals prepared for the start of their National League Division Series on Sunday afternoon.

headline: British Soil Is Battlefield Over Peat, for Bogs’ Sake
text: DICKLEBURGH, England — For Britain’s legion of gardeners, peat has long been as essential to gardening as beer is to the corner pub. So trowels flew after the British government — heeding environmental concerns — announced plans to gradually eliminate peat from all gardening products, setting off an intense battle over how to prioritize two of this country’s defining passions: indulging the yard and protecting the planet.

headline: Greens Versus the Green Thumb
text: The Times’s Elisabeth Rosenthal documents the heated British debate between gardeners and environmentalists over the use of peat.

headline: Oct. 6: Romney Maintains Poll Momentum
text: Mitt Romney continues to show improved numbers in polls published since the presidential debate in Denver on Wednesday and has now made clear gains in the FiveThirtyEight forecast. The forecast gives him roughly a 20 percent chance of winning the Electoral College, up from about 15 percent before the debate. Mr. Romney’s gains in the polls have been sharp enough that he should continue to advance in the FiveThirtyEight forecast if he can maintain his numbers over the next couple of days.

headline: A 2012 Scorecard
text: The regular season, 2,430 games in all, produced memorable moments — from a rare triple crown to an unprecedented three perfect games.

headline: New Somalian President Picks a Businessman, a Political Newcomer, as Prime Minister
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The new Somalian president, Hassan Sheik Mohamud, on Saturday evening named as prime minister a political novice who is expected to lead the council of ministers for the next four years, officials said.

headline: Good Start for a Promoter Who Is New to the Game
text: There were four winners in the inaugural tournament of the 2012-13 Men’s Grand Prix, including the series organizer.

headline: Bloomberg Pushes a Plan to Let Midtown Soar
text: London, Tokyo and other metropolises have created central business districts with forests of skyscrapers in recent years, seeking to meet the needs of globe-trotting corporate tenants.

headline: The Kimbell Art Museum Casts Major Shadow
text: Eric M. Lee, the director of Fort Worth’s Kimbell Art Museum — regarded by some as the country’s finest small museum — had his first day on the job three and a half years ago, but his admiration of the museum dates back to 1987, when he was an art history major at Yale.

headline: In Rematch, Memories of a Stolen Moment
text: When the Yankees face the Baltimore Orioles on Sunday, inevitably the conversation in living rooms across the country will turn to the last time these teams met in the playoffs, in 1996, when 12-year-old Jeffrey Maier’s reach over the right-field wall in Yankee Stadium helped turn the American League Championship Series.

headline: Close 2-Team Marathon Now Turns Into a Sprint
text: BALTIMORE — The Yankees and the Orioles played each other six times in September and split those games. For the rest of the month, they played other teams in a playoff race by proxy, but the results were just as close.

headline: Romney, Buoyed by Debate, Shows Off His Softer Side
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Mitt Romney walked off the debate stage on Wednesday night to find that his staff had already lined the hall backstage, greeting him with applause.

headline: Carroll F. Johnson, Schools Integrator, Dies at 99
text: Carroll F. Johnson, a Southern-born educator who was one of the first superintendents to voluntarily use busing to integrate an urban school district, doing so in White Plains in the 1960s, died on Monday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 99.

headline: Florida Validates Standing in the SEC, Toppling L.S.U.
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — After incremental steps at improvement against lesser opponents, the Florida Gators took a leap forward Saturday, beating Louisiana State, 14-6, and perhaps signaling a shift of power in the Southeastern Conference.

headline: Howard H. Scott, a Developer of the LP, Dies at 92
text: Howard H. Scott, who was part of the team at Columbia Records that introduced the long-playing vinyl record in 1948 before going on to produce albums with the New York Philharmonic, Glenn Gould, Isaac Stern and many other giants of classical music, died on Sept. 22 in Reading, Pa. He was 92.

headline: Shlomo Venezia Dies at 88; Wrote of Auschwitz Horror
text: Shlomo Venezia was one of the first Jews to climb out of the freight car when it came to the end of the line at the Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp in Poland on April 11, 1944, his mother crammed behind him. Two blows from a German guard’s baton struck him in the back of the neck.

headline: Changing Her Mind, a Queens Woman Decides to Remain on Life Support
text: A terminally ill Queens woman who won a court battle against her parents to allow a hospital to disconnect a breathing tube has decided that she wants to live out the rest of her life, the woman’s lawyer said Saturday.

headline: Browns at Giants: Matchup to Watch
text: Browns (0-4) at Giants (2-2), 1 p.m. Eastern Sunday, CBS

headline: Sven Hassel, Novelist Who Depicted Nazi Soldiers’ Lives, Dies at 95
text: Sven Hassel, a Danish-born writer whose pulp novels depicting grunt life in the Wehrmacht during World War II — drawn, he said, from his own combat experiences — sold millions of copies worldwide died on Sept. 21 in Barcelona, Spain. He was 95.

headline: Even After Rains, Facing Long-Term Water Needs
text: SAN ANGELO — With its pretty rivers and lakes, this city of 95,000 people is sometimes called the oasis of West Texas. But San Angelo recently came within a year of running out of water, as it faced a severe drought that produced brown lawns, dying bushes and fear.

headline: A’s Swing and Miss, Again and Again
text: DETROIT — Justin Verlander is the most durable and dominant starter in baseball, a three-time leader in strikeouts and innings who faced more batters this season than any other pitcher in the majors. His opponent on Saturday, the Oakland Athletics, seemed set up to fail against him in Game 1 of this American League division series.

headline: Student IDs That Track the Students
text: SAN ANTONIO —  For Tira Starr, an eighth grader at Anson Jones Middle School, the plastic nametag hanging around her neck that she has decorated with a smiley face and a purple bat sticker offers a way to reflect her personal flair. For administrators, it is something else entirely: a device that lets them use radio frequency technology —  with scanners tucked behind walls and ceilings —  to track her whereabouts.

headline: No Child Left Behind. Just a Demographic.

headline: In Florida, a Look at the Challenges of Mailed Ballots
text: Votes cast by mail are less likely to be counted, more likely to be compromised and more likely to be contested than those cast in a voting booth, statistics show.

headline: Error and Fraud at Issue as Absentee Voting Rises
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — On the morning of the primary here in August, the local elections board met to decide which absentee ballots to count. It was not an easy job.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Spurrier’s Team Delivers a Pummeling and a Party
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Never had the fans here partied quite like this. Marcus Lattimore bobbed and weaved. Connor Shaw pulled and fired. The stadium physically rocked. Never had more people come to watch a South Carolina football game, and all 85,199 of them would leave — once the sixth-ranked Gamecocks beat No. 5 Georgia, 35-7 — knowing the Head Ball Coach could still have fun.

headline: After Son’s Death, A’s Reliever Finds Sense of Normalcy on Mound
text: DETROIT — On the most emotional night that Oakland Athletics reliever Pat Neshek has spent in the majors, when almost every question about the loss of his infant son left him on the verge of tears, one practical matter made him laugh.

headline: Stewart and O’Reilly Share Stage in Political Joust
text: It was a battle for hearts and minds, a chance to appeal to those who see the world differently and try to move those realities just a little closer together.

headline: Reds Lose Starter but Win Opener Against Giants
text: SAN FRANCISCO — What was expected to be an extended pitching duel between two Cy Young Award candidates at a pitching-friendly ballpark was unpredictably unraveled by an eight-pitch performance on one side and an unusually rocky one on the other.

headline: Sept. 30-Oct. 6: The Week of the First Debate
text: The Mitt Romney on display this week was looser and more relaxed. President Obama followed a passive debate performance with a more aggressive stance.

headline: U.S. Agrees to Let South Korea Extend Range of Ballistic Missiles
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea has reached an agreement with the United States that lets it more than double the range of its ballistic missiles to counter what it considers to be a growing threat from North Korea.

headline: Stephanopoulizing
text: My head talks on This Week this morning. Yes, I’m jet-lagged out of my mind.

headline: Philippine Rebel Group Agrees to Peace Accord to End Violence in South
text: MANILA — President Benigno S. Aquino III announced Sunday that the Philippine government had reached a deal with a major rebel group that officials hope will reduce the persistent violence in the southern part of the country.

headline: ‘Sleepovers’ With My 9-Year-Old Daughter
text: When I was in high school in the late ’80s, I took a job baby-sitting for a single mother with a 9-year-old boy. I didn’t know the family well. The father was absent from the situation, and the mother appeared overwhelmed. The kid ran the show, and he got what he wanted by throwing fits, stomping his feet and pouting. The mother doted on her son, and spoke to him in a syrupy baby talk that made my skin crawl.

headline: Romney Ad Says Obama Distorts Tax Cut Plan
text: In a television ad released Sunday, the Romney campaign returned to one of the most contentious issues of the presidential debate, accusing President Obama of falsely claiming that Mitt Romney would cut $5 trillion in taxes.

headline: Disruptions: With a 3-D Printer, Building a Gun With the Push of a Button
text: It has long been possible to make a gun at home. But what happens when it no longer takes knowledge and skill to build one?

headline: The Payroll Data
text: Another quick note, this time on what the payroll data say. Again, you want to focus on somewhat longer-term trends, not monthly numbers. Over the past year the employer survey says that we’ve added 1.8 million jobs, or 150,000 a month:

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: A lengthy article in The New Yorker takes a close look at India’s newspaper industry, which, unlike the newspaper industry in the United States – which has lost 50 percent of its advertising revenue in the past five years – is thriving. There are an estimated 80,000 newspapers in India, the article finds, 85 percent of which are printed in one of India’s 22 official regional languages, and the circulation of English-language newspapers is growing 1.5 percent each year.

headline: Ethiopians Sweep Chicago Marathon
text: CHICAGO — Tsegaye Kebede crossed the finish line at Grant Park on Sunday with his country on his mind. He raised his arms, gave thumbs-up to the crowd and took in the applause as he became the first Ethiopian man to win the Chicago Marathon, setting a course record in the process.

headline: The Rumble That Wasn’t Entirely Live Online
text: 6:46 p.m. | Updated

headline: Group Sends First Rocket Under Deal With NASA
text: The first commercial cargo flight to the International Space Station lifted off on Sunday evening, inaugurating a new era for NASA in which private companies will take over the transportation of people and supplies to low-Earth orbit.

headline: Liam Neeson Leads Box Office With ‘Taken 2’
text: Liam Neeson’s already hot box-office streak got hotter over the weekend, while Tim Burton’s already cold one became, well, colder. “Taken 2” (20th Century Fox), starring Mr. Neeson as a retired C.I.A. operative, was No. 1 at North American theaters, taking in about $50 million, about twice the amount of its 2009 franchise predecessor. Mr. Neeson, 60, has recently become one of Hollywood’s most bankable stars, turning small action films like “Unknown” and “The Grey” into hits. For the weekend, “Hotel Transylvania” (Sony) was second, taking in about $26.3 million, for a two-week total of $76 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.

headline: Axelrod Says Obama Will Review Tape of Debate
text: As senior adviser for the Obama campaign, David Axelrod knows that his public criticisms of the boss should be exceedingly rare, and oh-so-gently worded when they do come. But he made it clear on Sunday, however indirectly, that President Obama was less than thrilled by his debate performance on Wednesday and that he would be making some changes.

headline: As Military Suicides Rise, Focus Is on Private Weapons
text: With nearly half of all suicides in the military having been committed with privately owned firearms, the Pentagon and Congress are moving to establish policies intended to separate at-risk service members from their personal weapons.

headline: Friedel’s Streak of Starts Is Over
text: There was an American in Tottenham Hotspur’s starting 11 against visiting Aston Villa on Sunday in north London.

headline: For Software, Cracks in the Patent System
text: When the nation’s patent system was born, many inventions were mechanical. Some say the patent system is ill suited for today’s digital world, where innovations like software are often based on abstract concepts.

headline: Chávez Wins New Term in Venezuela, Holding Off Surge by Opposition
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez, long a fiery foe of Washington, won re-election on Sunday, facing down cancer and the strongest electoral challenge of his nearly 14 years in office and gaining a new mandate to deepen his socialist revolution.

headline: To Regulate Rapid Traders, S.E.C. Turns to One of Them
text: RED BANK, N.J. — As billions of shares course through the stock market each day, investors rely on the government to keep up with Wall Street’s rapid-fire traders.

headline: Europe Still at Odds Over the Workings of Its Bailout Fund
text: BRUSSELS — It has been referred to as “the bazooka” — the 500 billion euro European bailout fund that after much dispute will have its first board meeting on Monday.

headline: Romney and G.O.P. Make Inroads in Silicon Valley
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When President Obama makes his latest foray into Silicon Valley on Monday, he will face a technology industry more engaged than ever in the wheeling and dealing of Washington, and much more forthcoming with its political contributions — including, generously, to his rival, Mitt Romney.

headline: Highlights and Analysis From Game 1 of Orioles-Yankees
text: The Orioles and Yankees have been as close as two teams can be down the stretch since early September, when Baltimore pulled even for the American League East lead after trailing by 10 games. The two teams got a little closer Sunday when they opened their A.L. Division Series, which stayed tied for most of the game until the Yankees broke it up with a ninth-inning rally.

headline: Week in Pictures for Oct. 5
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the opening event at the Barclays Center, police layoffs in Camden, New Jersey, and a shooting involving the police in Queens.

headline: Desperately Chasing Jobs in a Polarized Wisconsin Town
text: In 2008, Brad Lichtenstein began filming a modest documentary about the effects of the recession, specifically the closing of a General Motors plant, on Janesville, Wis., a small Midwestern city. That’s how he found himself, a few years later, with an up-close view of one of the meanest and most dramatic chapters in recent American politics: the battle over collective-bargaining rights for Wisconsin state employees and the subsequent effort to recall the Republican governor, Scott Walker, from office.

headline: Keeping Up the Spirit of Bach and Carrying On
text: It was a happy reunion of survivors last week as Bach at One, the young and sturdy oak of Trinity Wall Street’s music program, opened its season at St. Paul’s Chapel on Monday, and Pipes at One, an offshoot, took root on Wednesday. First among the survivors was the building itself, “The Little Chapel That Stood,” as A. B. Curtiss titled her children’s book about it.

headline: A Writer With Wit and Bite Proves He’s Not Dead Yet
text: CAMBRIDGE, England — A few months ago the writer and broadcaster Clive James read with some alarm that he was about to die.

headline: The Joys of Letting Life Glide Along
text: There are long moments in Rob List’s “Play by Ear” where you could imagine an alternate title for this 70-minute work, maybe something along the lines of “Still Life: Man With Radiators.”

headline: A Feisty Debate Between Candidates in Connecticut Senate Race
text: Facing off in a feisty and highly personal debate on Sunday, the candidates in Connecticut’s closely contested race for United States Senate seemed determined to prove that they had gleaned a lesson from President Obama’s lethargic performance from last week: attack early and often.

headline: Bach Is Still Revving Up Engine of Musical Innovation
text: Paul Elie begins his intriguingly titled “Reinventing Bach” with a charming anecdote that seems, at first, a neat frame for his argument. He recalls visiting a museum of historic musical instruments in Berlin, where he was very moved to see the harpsichord that belonged to Bach.

headline: Myriad Ways for the Facets in the Crown of Ballet to Sparkle and Shine
text: With so many great ballets in its repertory, New York City Ballet constantly faces the challenge of how to group and arrange its jewels. The choices aren’t always coherent. At the David H. Koch Theater on Thursday, however, the programming was illuminating. Each dance brought out colors in the rest.

headline: Two Paths Through Dartmouth Meet in a U.S. Senate Race
text: Perhaps no school in the Ivy League resisted coeducation as fiercely as Dartmouth College.

headline: Little Lives Caught in a Troubled No Man’s Land
text: As rough and tumble as the lives it documents, “In My Mother’s Arms” profiles a stopgap orphanage in one of Baghdad’s toughest neighborhoods. Headed by Husham Al Thabe, a pensive young father whose emotions run silent and deep, this two-bedroom shelter serves 32 boys in various stages of loss and displacement.

headline: A Star and a Utility Man Bring Tigers Within Win of Advancing
text: DETROIT — The postgame celebration featured Don Kelly lifting Prince Fielder off the ground. Think about that for a moment. Kelly had just driven in the winning run in the bottom of the ninth for the Detroit Tigers, so clearly, the wrong person was doing the lifting. And the stocky Fielder is not exactly an easy hoist.

headline: Rebels Clash With Syrian Security Forces Near Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rebel fighters and security forces in Syria clashed near the border with Lebanon and fought over a military barracks in Aleppo on Sunday, while Turkish artillery fired into Syria for a fifth consecutive day in retaliation for cross-border shelling.

headline: ‘What Now?’ Following ‘What Ifs?’
text: “You would be married to some feed salesman,” Megan’s opinionated lesbian roommate suggests.

headline: A Sluggish Start, but a Rousing Response
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On the N.F.L. player’s degree of desirability scale, a Sunday 1 p.m. home game against a seemingly inferior opponent ought to be something close to the pinnacle. An early breakfast, brisk warm-up and breezy victory ideally leaves plenty of time to celebrate and make it to the couch well before the prime-time game kicks off.

headline: Reasons Matter (When Intuitions Don’t Object)
text: This post by the psychologist Jonathan Haidt is a response to two previous articles in The Stone — one by Gary Gutting, the other by Michael P. Lynch — which argued against certain views on reason found in Haidt’s recent book, “The Righteous Mind.”

headline: A Choreographer Emerges, Assisted by the Chinese Zodiac
text: When someone in a corps de ballet gets a shot in the spotlight and shines, it can be the stuff of legend: a star is born. That’s unusual enough, but what happened at the David H. Koch Theater on Friday night is even less common. The someone who emerged from the corps of New York City Ballet was a choreographer, the rare real thing. And he didn’t leave his fellow corps members behind in his glory. He shared it with them.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Era Women: Their Tale
text: Though you couldn’t tell it from the delighted expressions of the women they’re dancing with, the men at the Christmas office party are real stiffs. Sure, they’re tall, dark and kind of handsome, if your tastes run to buttoned-down, Scotch-scented swagger.

headline: Asia Pacific Bridge Federation Championships
text: The seventh Asia Pacific Bridge Federation championships took place in Fukuoka, Japan, from Aug. 25 to Sept. 2.

headline: Wives Take the Campaign to Newsstands
text: As the candidates for president debate in the press over weighty topics like taxes and health care, their wives are waging their own campaigns in women’s and celebrity magazines to show voters their spouses’ softer sides.

headline: Footnote
text: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt announced on Sunday that it had acquired the United States rights to publish a previously unknown work by J. R. R. Tolkien, “The Fall of Arthur.” The book, set for publication in May, chronicles the last days of King Arthur and will be edited by Tolkien’s son Christopher, who will also provide commentary and notes. Tolkien, the author of “The Lord of the Rings,” died in 1973. This is the first new work by him to be unearthed since “The Legend of Sigurd and Gudrun” was released in 2009.

headline: Restoring Film Gems, Pre-Code or Political
text: As the New York Film Festival slides into its final weekend on Friday, the fall’s other major cinematic event opens on Thursday, just a few blocks away. Celebrating its 10th anniversary, “To Save and Project,” the Museum of Modern Art’s international celebration of film preservation, offers a dense and varied collection of films that feels like a festival in itself — one that, unlike most, isn’t subject to the tyranny of the present.

headline: Libya’s Prime Minister Is Dismissed
text: CAIRO — The Libyan Parliament voted on Sunday to dismiss the prime minister it chose less than four weeks ago, deepening a leadership crisis at a moment when the country’s transitional authorities are under intense pressure to catch the killers of the American ambassador, J. Christopher Stevens, and to stop the prevailing lawlessness that led to his death.

headline: Duo + One
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Dave Sarpola made his New York Times debut earlier this year, and today he offers us a rather strange puzzle: it’s infested with FLIES. They’re all over the grid.

headline: Giving New Life, Even to the Hoary
text: Throughout his long career the conductor Riccardo Muti has proved himself expert at revealing subtleties in pieces that on the surface may seem musically obvious. He did this thrillingly on Wednesday night, when the Chicago Symphony Orchestra opened the Carnegie Hall season with a stunning performance of Orff’s “Carmina Burana.” Mr. Muti treated that pummeling, elemental score with respect and brought out great tenderness in the music that most accounts miss.

headline: Lured In by a Family Just Being Itself on TV
text: WEST MONROE, La. — The moments before a religious service begins are generally ones of quiet reflection for the congregants, but on a recent Sunday at White’s Ferry Road Church of Christ here something incongruous was going on two-thirds of the way back in the spacious hall.

headline: Report to Reveal Evidence in Armstrong Drug Case
text: The United States Anti-Doping Agency is preparing to unveil some details of its doping case against Lance Armstrong this week, a move bound to send more shocks through the bruised sport of cycling.

headline: Lowe, With Impressive Final Stretch, Earns Spot on Postseason Roster
text: BALTIMORE — As recently as two weeks ago Derek Lowe was certain he would not be on the Yankees roster for the American League division series. Acquired as a free agent on Aug. 13, Lowe had only been used sparingly, and when he expressed his pessimism about making the roster in the middle of September, he may have been right.

headline: The Presidential Campaign on Social Media
text: It’s not enough for the presidential candidates Barack Obama and Mitt Romney to kiss babies, shake hands and lunch at small-town diners to win over voters. In 2012, they also need to cozy up to citizens online.

headline: Campaigns Use Social Media to Lure Younger Voters
text: In 2012, it is not enough for candidates to shake some hands, kiss a baby or two and run some TV ads. They also need to be posting funny little animations on the blogging site Tumblr.

headline: Pith Follows British Leader on Twitter
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron must have felt kind of cool, if a little late, when he joined Twitter on Saturday. “I promise there won’t be ‘too many tweets ...’ ” he wrote in his first message, as if quoting someone.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: In observance of Columbus Day, bond markets will be closed on Monday. Stock markets will be open for trading. The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

text: HERE is a look at some highlights, lowlights and sidelights of Advertising Week 2012, which took place from Monday through Friday in New York.

text: ST. LOUIS — Somehow, even as Gio Gonzalez spiraled uncharacteristically out of control, his team never followed suit.

text: The series is featuring occasional works of fiction. This is one.

headline: Canada Puts Spotlight on War of 1812, With U.S. as Villain
text: DUNVEGAN, Ontario — Although it produced “The Star-Spangled Banner,” the War of 1812 does not get much attention in the United States. In Canada, however, the federal government is devoting surprising attention to the bicentennial of the conflict, which it describes bluntly in a new television commercial as an act of American aggression against Canada.

headline: Giants Replay: Week 5
text: All the action in the Giants’ 41-27 victory over the Browns, including a big day from running back Ahmad Bradshaw and three touchdown passes by Eli Manning.

headline: In Pakistan, Drone Protest Takes Detour for Safety
text: TANK, Pakistan — Imran Khan, a cricket star turned opposition politician, abandoned plans to hold a much-heralded rally against American drone strikes at a village deep inside Pakistan’s tribal belt on Sunday after the Pakistani military warned him of “imminent danger” if he went ahead with the event.

headline: Oct. 7: National Polls Show Signs of Settling
text: Mitt Romney remains in a considerably stronger polling position than he was before last Wednesday’s debate in Denver. But the polls released on Sunday did not tell quite as optimistic a story for him as those in the debate’s immediate aftermath.

headline: Venezuelans Line Up Before Dawn to Vote in Midtown
text: Alejandro Fandiño awoke at 3 a.m. on Sunday and drove from his home in Dover, N.J., to the Venezuelan Consulate in New York, hoping to be first in line to vote in Venezuela’s presidential election.

headline: Romney’s Missing Foreign Policy
text: IF it hadn’t been for the deadly Sept. 11 attack on the United States Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, Mitt Romney probably wouldn’t be giving a speech on foreign policy in the waning weeks of this election season. But Mr. Romney sensed an opening in President Obama’s missteps in Libya, and on Monday he plans to lay out his case that he will be a better steward of America’s national security.

headline: No Strangers to Yankees, Orioles Face New Pressure
text: BALTIMORE — Orioles Manager Buck Showalter said before Sunday’s game that the biggest challenge he faced would be keeping the emotions of his players in check, this being Baltimore’s first playoff game since Oct. 15, 1997.

headline: Lebanon Says Israeli Planes Circled Its Airspace for an Hour
text: JERUSALEM — The morning after the Israeli Air Force shot down an unidentified drone in the Negev Desert, the Lebanese government said that four Israeli warplanes spent an hour on Sunday illegally circling in its airspace.

headline: For Judge in Firefighter Discrimination Case, an Evolving Opinion
text: One after another, nearly 150 white firefighters approached a lectern facing a federal judge and, voices sometimes trembling with anger, decried what they called a perversion of justice. Years of hard work to make it into the ranks of the department were being tossed aside to make way for unqualified minority candidates, they said, all in a questionable effort to end discrimination.

headline: October Fortunes Seem Beyond Oakland’s Reach
text: DETROIT — There were two outs and two on and the triple crown winner at the plate in the seventh inning Sunday for the Detroit Tigers. Out in faraway center field, under the Chevrolet Fountain, Coco Crisp played deep. He would not let a ball sail over his head, and he would race in for anything shallow.

headline: Happy Birthday, Mr. President: Putin Turns 60, and Russians Pay Notice
text: MOSCOW — So what does President Vladimir V. Putin think about inevitably becoming a retiree?

headline: Inquiry Finds That Four ‘Rebecca’ Investors Did Not Exist
text: The lawyer for the lead producer of the Broadway musical “Rebecca,” which collapsed after the reported death from malaria of a mysterious investor, said on Sunday that he had confirmed that the investor and three others brought in by a middleman with a history of civil fraud complaints never existed.

headline: Vettel Wins Second Straight, and Kobayashi Shines at Home
text: SUZUKA, Japan — The 2012 Formula One championship just keeps on renewing itself, freshening itself up and creating unpredictable, entertaining stories.

headline: Stop and Frisk, Part 3
text: The New York City Police Department has come under criticism in recent years for arresting people for trespassing in public housing, often for little or no reason. The trespassing arrests are a variation on the city’s broader, and highly controversial, stop-and-frisk program. On Thursday, Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court in Manhattan added her voice to the chorus, ruling that a lawsuit challenging police arrests for trespassing in public housing could move closer to trial. The city had tried to have most of the plaintiffs’ claims dismissed.

headline: Randle’s Study Session Pays Off
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Giants quarterback Eli Manning texted Rueben Randle on Thursday and asked him to join him in watching film of the Cleveland Browns’ defense, Randle, a rookie wide receiver, eagerly grasped that helping hand.

headline: Safer Streets for New York
text: The streets of New York City have become a lot more dangerous in the last year. Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s latest management report that tracks city data shows that traffic fatalities, including those caused in car crashes, were up to 291 between July 2011 and June 2012, compared with 236 deaths in the previous 12-month period. New York does better at protecting its population from traffic deaths than some cities, including Los Angeles. But the death rate is still unacceptably high compared with places that police traffic better, like Paris and Tokyo.

headline: Ye Olde Partisanship Is Nothing New
text: WASHINGTON — An American political system marked by partisanship and polarization engenders despair from both Republicans and Democrats.

headline: California Moves to Reduce Gas Prices
text: LOS ANGELES — With gasoline prices reaching record highs across California over the last week, Gov. Jerry Brown moved on Sunday to alleviate some of the pain at the pump.

headline: A Gloomy Season for Dairy Farmers
text: Last week began without a farm bill, a legislative lapse of shameful proportions. Since 1949, the bill has always been renewed, but not this year. Even so, most of the 2012 crop is still covered by loans, insurance programs and commodity supports until the end of the year — with one important exception.

headline: Still a Conservative Provocateur, Carlson Angles for Clicks, Not Fights
text: A week ago, Tucker Carlson cued up a video of President Obama that had been sent to him by a source. The video, recorded in 2007 when Mr. Obama was a presidential candidate, showed him speaking to a black audience about “quiet riots” in the black community and the differences in the federal government’s responses to the Sept. 11 attacks and Hurricane Katrina.

headline: For Pastor Trying to Keep Daughter Alive, Party Is Grim
text: It was the pastor’s birthday at Antioch Missionary Church in Flushing, Queens, and members of the church, mostly Korean, were preparing a special Sunday lunch for him.

headline: A Paris Review Mobile App
text: Literary magazines have taken their time emerging from a solely paper-and-ink world, but now it is routine for them to supplement their printed material with Web sites, blogs and Twitter feeds. On Monday, the Paris Review, the venerable journal founded in 1953 by Harold L. Humes, Peter Matthiessen and George Plimpton, will go a step further, introducing an app for the iPad and iPhone that is almost a year in the making.

headline: Truth About Jobs
text: If anyone had doubts about the madness that has spread through a large part of the American political spectrum, the reaction to Friday’s better-than expected report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics should have settled the issue. For the immediate response of many on the right — and we’re not just talking fringe figures — was to cry conspiracy.

headline: MetroCards Go on Sale With Ads on Both Sides
text: It sputtered out of the subway vending machine, an oddity that deserved careful examination. Some riders asked a station agent how to swipe it. One woman was confused about whether it was even a MetroCard at all.

text: Baltimore

text: Salmon? Pink?

headline: With Affirmative Action, India’s Rich Gain School Slots Meant for Poor
text: CHENNAI, India — The two women both claim that affirmative action cost them coveted spots at elite public universities. Both cases have now reached the Supreme Court.

headline: For Both Campaigns, Time to Fine-Tune Their Messages
text: Presidential candidates win when they adapt. And that is exactly whatMitt Romney andPresident Obama are each trying to do.

headline: The Cacophony of Money
text: Two-thirds of the $50 million spent on Mitt Romney’s behalf in Ohio has come from outside “super PACs” and other so-called independent groups, and yet Mr. Romney has lagged behind in all of the major Ohio polls. Hundreds of millions in third-party spending from unlimited checks, much of it from undisclosed donors, has also failed to give Mr. Romney a clear lead in any of the other swing states.

headline: How to Die
text: ONE morning last month, Anthony Gilbey awakened from anesthesia in a hospital in the east of England. At his bedside were his daughter and an attending physician.

headline: With Biden Up Next to Debate, Obama’s Aides Plot Comeback
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s campaign is working feverishly to restore its momentum after a lackluster debate performance last week, an effort that began with a conference call 10 minutes before the debate even ended and led to new advertisements, a rewritten stump speech, a carefully timed leak and a reversal of months-old strategy.

headline: Patriots Play Keep-Away for Victory Over Manning
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — In the dozen times they had met before, Peyton Manning and Tom Brady had forged an epic rivalry, the greatest quarterbacks of their generation creating monuments to electric passing and scintillating competition.

headline: N.H.L. Replacement Players Would Be Illegal in Two Provinces

headline: The Patent, Used as a Sword
text: When Apple announced last year that all iPhones would come with a voice-activated assistant named Siri, capable of answering spoken questions, Michael Phillips’s heart sank.

headline: Spinning Gaffes Into Gags: Live From New York, It’s Debate Night
text: All last week, Lorne Michaels, the creator and longtime executive producer of “Saturday Night Live” was working the phone trying to nail down a visit to the show from either of this year’s presidential candidates. By late Friday, it looked like it wouldn’t happen, at least for this last week.

headline: As SEC Sees Power Shift, Spurrier Has to Smile
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — It was a slight jab, delivered as always with a wry smile, as if South Carolina Coach Steve Spurrier could not help himself. His Gamecocks had beaten Georgia so thoroughly Saturday that Bulldogs fans had left the stadium, hailed taxis and gone to sulk before the first quarter was over. This had not been an innocent misstep by Georgia but an honest declaration by South Carolina that it was the better team.

headline: At First Practice, Nets Praise Intimate Feel of Arena
text: Jay-Z had departed, taking his verses, his stage and his Brooklyn slide show with him. The Harlem Globetrotters had not yet arrived. For two hours, at least, Barclays Center belonged to its primary tenant — along with a few dozen workers wielding power tools.

headline: A Charitable Wash
text: In Phoenix, carwashes allow groups, whether cheerleaders or church congregants, to raise money for their causes.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Dexter’ in Uncharted Waters
text: This season, the critics Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger are checking out favorite shows and seeing how they hold up. Previous entries in this series include posts on “New Girl,” “NCIS,” “Scandal,” “The Good Wife” and “30 Rock.”

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Fighting for a Cause With Soap and Suds
text: PHOENIX — There are about 600 cars for every 1,000 residents here, federal officials estimate, and roughly 300 carwashing businesses listed in the Yellow Pages. But there are also benefit carwashes just about every weekend for all sorts of purposes and needs.

headline: Slain Man’s Video a Factor in Convention Arrest Suits
text: The video shows lines of police officers herding protesters, a commander suggesting a way to disperse and a milling crowd, including a marching band with an impromptu parade behind it, with curious onlookers watching from sidewalks on East 16th Street.

headline: Lincecum Will Not Start Game 3; He Will Probably Work Out of Bullpen
text: SAN FRANCISCO — No debate has taken up more oxygen in the Bay Area the past week than the one over Tim Lincecum and his role for the Giants this postseason.

headline: Amid Successes, W.N.B.A. Is Still Facing Challenges
text: With all the good news that it has to shout about, the W.N.B.A. may be the quietest professional sports league in the United States.

headline: Relatives Rally at Protest of Fatal Police Shooting
text: When Hawa Bah decided to call 911 two weeks ago, she hoped an ambulance would arrive first, not the police.

headline: Nguyen Chi Thien, Whose Poems Spoke Truth to Power, From a Cell, Dies at 73
text: It was not the isolation that was hardest to endure, though it lasted nearly three decades. Nor was it the cold of his cell, where he was often chained naked, nor summer’s blistering heat, nor the rusty shackles that infected his legs, nor the relentless hunger.

headline: Swedish Club Looks to Sign Lundqvist
text: The big obstacle for a European club looking to sign a locked-out N.H.L. star is the cost of insuring that player against injury. The Swedish Elitserien club Frolunda Gothenburg seems to have overcome that barrier in its attempt to sign Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist, the city’s hometown hero, for the duration of the lockout.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Marijuana Only for the Sick? A Farce, Some Angelenos Say
text: LOS ANGELES — One year after federal law enforcement officials began cracking down on California’s medical marijuana industry with a series of high-profile arrests around the state, they finally moved into Los Angeles last month, giving 71 dispensaries until Tuesday to shut down. At the same time, because of a well-organized push by a new coalition of medical marijuana supporters, the City Council last week repealed a ban on the dispensaries that it had passed only a couple of months earlier.

headline: 2004 R.N.C. Protest Video
text: Video excerpts from Bradley Will’s 2004 video of Republican National Convention protesters in New York City.

headline: It’s Big. It’s Confusing. And It’s Anybody’s Race.
text: WOODINVILLE, Wash. — The big news is what did not happen here. In the politics of redrawing the map of Congressional districts after the 2010 census, boring and predictable lost the battle and fled the field. The result, politicians and academics say, is one of the most unusual corners in the nation heading toward Election Day.

headline: Strategy in Draft May Leave Jets Short of Depth
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Behind the desk in Mike Tannenbaum’s office, a three-sided whiteboard hangs on the wall. It is loaded with magnets, one for each player on the Jets’ roster — a visual representation of the underperforming and the overachieving, the injured and the fit, and everybody in between.

headline: Vonn Seeks Chance to Race Against Men
text: Having won all of the top crowns in women’s downhill ski racing, Lindsey Vonn has set her sights on a new goal: competing against the best male ski racers in the world.

headline: Romney Works to Build Momentum in Florida, a State Critical to Victory
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Seeking to capitalize on his commanding debate performance last week, Mitt Romney tried to turn the enthusiasm of large crowds during a three-day visit to Florida into momentum to carry a state that, by all accounts, is crucial to his path to the White House.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Columbus Day and Shemini Atzeret, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: On Fund-Raising Tour, Obama Admits Poor Debate Showing
text: LOS ANGELES – President Obama joined the chorus of critics who have been slamming his debate performance, acknowledging on Sunday night before a star-studded fund-raiser that he may have flubbed the face-to-face standoff with Mitt Romney last week.

headline: N.F.L. Replay: Week 5
text: A view from around the National Football League, including quarterback duels and a one-handed catch.

headline: YouTube to Serve Niche Tastes by Adding Channels
text: A visit to YouTube these days shows so many professionally produced channels that it could be confused with a TV guide. There are channels for ABC News, Taylor Swift, Nike Football, America’s Test Kitchen and the Obama for America campaign.

headline: After Scare, Baker Looks Between the Milestones
text: SAN FRANCISCO — To everyone else, the image of a 3-year-old son of the San Francisco Giants’ manager being rescued from a near collision at home plate is a lasting World Series memory.

text: Friday found President Obama starting his day at the White House, then making campaign stops in Virginia and Ohio, both battleground states.

headline: Corruption Is Seen as a Drain on Italy’s South
text: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy — Italy’s A3 highway, begun in the 1960s and still not finished, starts outside Naples in the ancient hill town of Salerno and ends, rather unceremoniously, 300 miles farther south as a local street in downtown Reggio Calabria.

headline: Toe to Toe

headline: Study Finds Broad Wariness Over Online Tracking
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — As marketers, browser makers and government regulators spar over efforts to let consumers limit custom advertising online, a new study suggests that Americans are largely unaware of what that means and have a strong aversion to being tracked online.

headline: Julian Assange Has Book Deal
text: The publisher OR Books announced on Sunday that it had acquired “Cypherpunks,” a new book about freedom and the Internet by  Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks. Mr. Assange, who was granted asylum at the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in August, wrote the book with three other authors:  Jacob Appelbaum, Jérémie Zimmermann and  Andy Müller-Maguhn. The book will go on sale Nov. 26 in paperback and as an e-book. Mr. Assange said in a statement that he wrote the book in response to his longstanding worries about government control of the Internet and surveillance. “In March 2012 I gathered together three of today’s leading cypherpunks to discuss the resistance,” he said. “Two of them, besides myself, have been targeted by law enforcement agencies as a result of their work to safeguard privacy and to keep government accountable. Their words, and their stories, need to be heard.”

headline: Study Shows Children With Autism Tend to Stray
text: When Patrick Murphy was 6, he became obsessed with vacuum cleaners. The boy, who has autism, used to slip out of his house near Buffalo without telling his parents, running to a nearby appliance store or into strangers’ homes to marvel at vacuum cleaners.

headline: Romney Strives to Stand Apart in Global Policy
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney intensified his efforts Monday to draw a sharp contrast with President Obama on national security in the presidential campaign’s closing stages, portraying Mr. Obama as having mishandled the tumult in the Arab world and having left the nation exposed to a terrorist attack in Libya.

headline: Russell Martin Stars on Defense, Too
text: BALTIMORE — Yankees catcher Russell Martin spent much of Sunday flinging himself to the ground to block pitches around home plate. He slid to the dirt in the same area as part of a desperate attempt to try to score a run — even if he was tagged out. And in the grass in front of home plate, he flopped face-first as he threw the ball to get what proved to be a crucial out.

headline: A New Term for Chávez
text: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela won re-election on Sunday, facing down the strongest electoral challenge of his nearly 14 years in office.

headline: Martin and Yanks Are Better Late
text: BALTIMORE — The Yankees were the last team to enter the postseason fray, waiting four days after the end of the regular season to play their first playoff game. And then they had to wait about two and a half hours more for rain to subside before finally opening their 2012 postseason campaign.

headline: Arroyo Shuts Down Giants as Reds Take 2-0 Series Lead
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Cincinnati’s Bronson Arroyo, a 35-year-old with a flap of blond hair dropping out the back of his cap, has built a reputation over 13 seasons as a control pitcher who devours innings rather than overwhelming hitters.

headline: Korean-American Star Confesses in Skating Scandal
text: HONG KONG — Simon Cho, a Korean-American speedskater who won a bronze medal at the 2010 Olympics, originally came to the United States in 1996 under cover of darkness, smuggled across the border from Canada, holding his mother’s hand. He was an illegal immigrant, and he was 4 years old.

headline: Textbook Victory: Throw, Run and Catch
text: After the Giants fell behind, 14-0, on Sunday, Eli Manning, Ahmad Bradshaw and Victor Cruz led them to a victory against the winless Cleveland Browns.

headline: A Conversation With:  P. Chidambaram
text: Palaniappan Chidambaram, the powerful minister of finance and senior leader in the Indian National Congress, has been a central figure in the recent flurry of economic measures pushed through by the government. His return to the Finance Ministry on the last day of July – he had previously served as finance minister from 2004 to 2008 – coincided with a new, more assertive attitude by a government that had been criticized for drift and ineffectiveness.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Monday, Oct. 8
text: NEWS As euro zone finance ministers gather Monday for their monthly meeting in Luxembourg, there is still considerable disagreement over how the €500 billion European bailout fund will work — it’s known officially as the European Stability Mechanism but referred to as “the bazooka” — and whether it can help countries like Spain that are already in crisis. James Kanter reports from Brussels.

headline: Families of South Korean Sailors Held by Pirates Ask Seoul for Help
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The families of four South Korean sailors held hostage by Somali pirates for more than 17 months appealed to the government on Monday to intervene for their release.

headline: Philippines and U.S. Start Joint Exercises
text: SUBIC BAY, the Philippines — Marines from the Philippines and the United States began 10 days of joint exercises focused on disaster relief, humanitarian assistance and maritime security.

headline: Asian Universities Play Catch-up in Global Rankings
text: The California Institute of Technology is still the No. 1 university in the world, according to the Times Higher Education rankings, compiled in London and published last week, and American institutions still dominate the top 10. But in the middle of the pack, Asian universities were the biggest gainers, D.D. Guttenplan writes.

headline: Poorer but Wiser After a Year of Unemployment
text: There is a great spiraling downward going on in this country, and it has meant that people like Cindy Roberts of Tulsa, Okla., Bob Hockman of Superior, Wis., and Michael Rose of New Hyde Park on Long Island have had to fight with all their strength or be pulled under.

headline: The Madam and the Imam
text: KARACHI — Last month, the police in Peshawar, the capital of Pakistan’s northwestern Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province, arrested four women and one man for engaging in prostitution, a crime punishable by up to 25 years in prison. The High Court in Peshawar released them after acknowledging that a lack of employment opportunities often forces women into selling sex. But it also ordered Neelam, who was charged with running a brothel, to attend an hour-long class with a cleric at a local mosque every day for a month. After that the police will assess her moral progress and report back to the court.

headline: Weighed Down by History, a Town Slides in Mexico
text: The thrust of civilization is commonly imagined as an arc curving ever upward. From the Industrial Revolution on, innovation, comfort, health and wealth have seemed to expand and improve limitlessly for much of the world. But take a long look at the remote, sinking town of Santiago Mitlatongo, in Mexico, and that arc appears to slump — and not just graphically. The geologic term is “slumping”; its foundation diminished by erosion, Santiago Mitlatongo is sliding down its mountain at a rate of about a meter per day.

headline: Bhutan’s Middle Path
text: Aaron Putnam, a postdoctoral research scientist at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, is leading a field expedition to the mountain kingdom of Bhutan to examine links among past climate, glaciers and water resources in the Himalaya.

headline: Big Spaces for Big Art at the Edges of Paris
text: PARIS — On the Île Seguin, construction of the 30,000-square-meter R4 arts complex designed by Jean Nouvel has yet to begin — but the space is already up and running.

headline: Israel Launches Airstrikes After Attacks From Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — Gaza militants fired a barrage of rockets and mortar shells into Israeli territory on Monday, causing no casualties but some property damage, after an Israeli airstrike in southern Gaza on Sunday killed one Palestinian and wounded at least nine others.

headline: The Competing Views on Competition
text: JUST before bedtime on a recent night, two toddlers marched reluctantly to the bathroom to brush their teeth. And on the way, my four-year-old son told his little sister: “I’m going to win. I’m going to win!”

headline: Test Drive: Zappos Introduces PinPointing, a Pinterest Shopping Companion Tool
text: Ask any dedicated online shopper about the tools in his or her digital arsenal and you’ll hear about Pinterest. You may also hear complaints about how difficult it is to shop from. Unless an image has been pinned directly from the retailer’s site, useful hyperlinks and information, such as product name, in the description are rare. Instead, you’re likely to find a description supplied by the pinner along the lines of “colorful ballet slippers” or “Flares. flares. #fall.” Telepathy or Nancy Drew-level skills are required to find pinned items. (Let’s not even get into whether the product will even be in stock by the time you track down the retailer.)

headline: In Phoenix, the Search for a Successor to Nash
text: Spirit, engine, face of the franchise – in his nine seasons with the Phoenix Suns, Steve Nash was all of these things and more. So when word came on July 11 that the two-time most valuable player and perennial All-Star had been traded to the Los Angeles Lakers for little more than a bounty of future draft picks, the writing on the wall in Phoenix was: rebuild.

headline: Will Britain’s Rivalries Harm Governance?

headline: Debating the Death Sentence for ‘Honor’ Killings

headline: A Regulatory Odd Couple
text: The Odd Couple: The S.E.C. and High-Frequency Traders  |  Regulators are getting help policing the rapid-fire markets from an unlikely source — the rapid-fire traders. Tradeworx, 45-person high-speed trading firm based in New Jersey, has designed a program that will allow the Securities and Exchange Commission to see every bid and offer on each of the nation’s 13 public stock exchanges. “The system, akin to an X-ray machine for the stock market, could enable regulators to detect whether trading firms are overwhelming the market’s plumbing when they rapidly submit and cancel orders,” Nathaniel Popper and Ben Protess write in The New York Times. While critics contend the program is akin to “the fox guarding the hen house,” the trading firm defends its partnership with regulators. “Where else are they going to be able to get these capabilities?” said Manoj Narang, the chief executive of Tradeworx.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Susan Dominus on What We Know About Ina Drew
text: Susan Dominus, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about Ina Drew, who was one of the most powerful women on Wall Street before resigning from JPMorgan Chase in May. In recent years, Dominus has written for the magazine on such subjects as a mysterious illness in Le Roy, N.Y., conjoined twins, the actress Kristen Wiig and “The Hunger Games” author Suzanne Collins. Her most recent article was about Jenny Craig in France.

headline: And Now for Something Completely Literate: A Memoir From John Cleese
text: Speaking of authors who are not dead yet: whenever that Great Critic in the sky delivers His final assessment of John Cleese, the 72-year-old Monty Python co-founder should earn a place in comedy paradise just on the basis of his performance in the “Ministry of Silly Walks” skit. (To say nothing of the “Dead Parrot” and “Cheese Shop” bits.) Until then, Mr. Cleese may sometimes perambulate strangely but he still types perfectly fine, and he has agreed to write a book about his life that the Crown Archetype imprint of Random House said on Monday it had acquired.

headline: Daily Report: When Patents Become Weapons
text: Last year, for the first time, spending by Apple and Google on patent lawsuits and unusually big-dollar patent purchases exceeded spending on research and development of new products, according to public filings. Many technology executives, economists and policy makers say the use of software patents as destructive weapons has corrupted the marketplace for new ideas, Charles Duhigg and Steve Lohr report in the latest installment in The New York Times’s “iEconomy” series.

headline: Monday Reading: Strategies for Saving on Holiday Airfares
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Hark, the Danger! Or Not
text: Did you hear how sympathizers of a notorious terrorism suspect tried to storm the federal courthouse off Foley Square over the weekend? No? Surely, then, you heard about the armed camp that Lower Manhattan became, with a ring of blue uniforms so thick that you couldn’t walk south of Canal Street without being stopped by a police officer.

headline: The Get | Latest Revival’s Vintage Lanvin Necklace
text: The newest member of the niche e-commerce clique is Latest Revival, an online boutique that went live last month and specializes in estate gems, vintage bijoux and fine jewelry, old and new. Founded by Dalia Oberlander the site stocks an eclectic mix of pieces, many of them one-of-a-kind and curated from resources around the world. Today, a capsule collection of Lanvin costume jewelry from the 1970s goes on sale. Handpicked from the House of Lavande archives, the eight Deco-modern pieces start at $498 for a pair of red and gold zigzag button earrings and go up to about $2,500 for a more sculptural large-scale pendant necklace. T’s favorite is this hexagonal charm necklace with a diamond center and striking black frame. “It’s an exceptional example of Lanvin’s statements from the ’70s,”  Oberlander says. “I’d wear it with current Lanvin or Céline.”

text: Culture: Since you’ve already got those new autumn novels by Zadie Smith, Michael Chabon and Junot Diaz piled up next to the bed, why not place a wheel of Parmigiano-Reggiano on top of the heap, too? There’s a lot of stuff to read on the rind, and here’s some guidance on how to decipher it all. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Cloning and Stem Cell Work Earns Nobel
text: Two scientists who were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine on Monday helped lay the foundation for regenerative medicine, the hotly pursued though still distant idea of rebuilding the body with tissues generated from its own cells. They are John B. Gurdon of the University of Cambridge in England and Shinya Yamanaka of Kyoto University in Japan.

headline: On Our Radar: California’s Runaway Gasoline Prices
text: As gasoline prices head toward $5 a gallon in California, Gov. Jerry Brown tells state regulators to relax smog controls so oil refineries can increase supplies of cheaper fuel. Meanwhile, police officers are contending with scattered cases of fuel theft from filling stations. [Bloomberg News, The Los Angeles Times]

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Debate Prep on ‘S.N.L.’ and The F.T.’s True Colors
text: What’s so funny about marginal tax rates? That was the question facing the writers and performers of “Saturday Night Live” who had to turn last week’s presidential debate into comedy in just five days. The usually secretive Lorne Michaels let Bill Carter watch the whole process.

headline: Violence and Pepper Spray During Nasheed’s Arrest in Maldives, Party Claims
text: The former president of the Maldives, Mohamed Nasheed, was detained on Monday for failing to turn up for a court hearing in a case involving the unlawful arrest of a High Court judge when Mr. Nasheed was president.

headline: CNN Creates Documentary Unit
text: LOS ANGELES — CNN, laboring to make itself more relevant, has decided that part of the answer involves movies — at least the nonfiction kind — and on Monday plans to announce the creation of CNN Films.

headline: Missing List of Names Widens Greek Political Fissure
text: ATHENS — Can a memory stick bring down a political order? That is the question in Greece, where a tragicomic debate over what became of a list of nearly 2,000 Greeks with Swiss bank accounts is rapidly turning into a full-blown political crisis that is imperiling Greece’s fragile coalition government at a crucial time.

headline: BP to Sell Texas City Refinery to Marathon Petroleum
text: BP said on Monday that it would sell its refinery in Texas City, Tex., and other assets to Marathon Petroleum for as much as $2.5 billion, as BP neared the completion of an aggressive plan to pare back assets.

headline: Lena Dunham Signs Book Deal for More Than $3.5 Million
text: Random House has acquired a book by Lena Dunham, the 26-year-old writer, actor and filmmaker, in one of the most heated auctions of the year.

headline: Eddie Huang Gets His Own Show
text: Eddie Huang came screeching onto the New York food scene in late 2009, when he opened the first Baohaus, a storefront serving bao — stuffed steamed buns, Taiwanese style — on the Lower East Side. It was the combination of his bao and blog posts that endowed him with instant fame.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Matt Kenseth Avoids the Big One at Talladega
text: Talladega Superspeedway, with its trioval design, four lanes of traffic and a backstretch measuring nearly 4,000 feet, encourages some of the highest speeds and most tightly packed competition on the Nascar Sprint Cup circuit. The race on Sunday illustrated how those factors can contribute to a chain reaction crash known in stock-car racing simply as the big one.

headline: Barbra Streisand Finally Comes Home
text: Barbra Streisand is set to give her first concert ever in her hometown of Brooklyn. A 1981 documentary about her upbringing in Flatbush has a new moment of relevance.

headline: Jay-Z Releasing Barclays Concert Album
text: Jay-Z is releasing an eight-song, extended-play record of songs recorded during his recent string of live concerts at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn. The rapper, whose real name is Shawn Carter, announced the new EP, “Live in Brooklyn,” on Twitter. The message directed fans to iTunes, where the record can be ordered in advance. No track list has been released by iTunes yet, but it appears the $9.99 download of the album will include eight videos as well.

headline: E-Health Opportunities for Seniors
text: Are you among the 47 percent of older Americans who have not yet entered the digital age? If so, you’re likely to be missing out on a lot of e-health opportunities available to help you live well despite chronic ailments and encroaching physical limitations.

headline: Baseball’s Twists Match Football’s Turns
text: With the start of the baseball playoffs on hyperdrive and the N.F.L. season in full attention-hogging mode, Sunday felt like a day spent in a sports fun house. It was sensory overload, full of twists and hairpin turns, and a lot of what you saw seemed just a bit off from what you’re used to.

headline: When the Tax Tail Wags Your Investment Dog
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: Aid Groups Push for Clean Energy
text: BARCELONA—When Samantha Smith started working for the World Wildlife Fund more than a decade ago, she was stationed in the Arctic, where her work focused on the species she was trying to protect in that habitat.

headline: U.S. Panel Cites Risks in Chinese Equipment
text: WASHINGTON — In the latest development to highlight the sensitive terrain that the United States and China are navigating on economic issues, a House committee issued a blistering bipartisan report on Monday that accused two of China’s largest telecommunications companies of being arms of the government that had stolen intellectual property from American companies and could potentially spy on Americans.

headline: High Lead Found in City-Sourced Eggs
text: TO the long list of food conundrums, add this: research has found elevated levels of lead in eggs from chickens in New York City public neighborhood gardens.

headline: Rothko Vandalized at Tate Modern
text: A Rothko mural at the Tate Modern in London was vandalized on Sunday afternoon when a visitor applied what museum officials described as “a small area of black paint with a brush to the painting.’’ A photograph posted by a visitor, Tim Wright, on Twitter also shows the name Vladimir scrawled on the painting along with the phrase “a potential piece of yellowism.’’

headline: How Pennies Add Up in a Securities Fraud Case
text: We are used to hearing big numbers thrown around in securities fraud cases, like the purported $64 billion in losses from the Ponzi scheme perpetrated by Bernard L. Madoff or $7 billion by R. Allen Stanford. What sometimes gets overlooked is how conduct involving relatively small amounts can add up to millions of dollars if allowed to go on long enough.

headline: Discontent Over Renaming of Kabul College Turns Into Violence
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The student, a social sciences major named Abdul Basir, was in the middle of giving an interview on Monday about why he did not want his university renamed.

headline: The Non-Euclidean Geometry of Whales
text: This week we explore non-Euclidean geometry with an excerpt from Dr. Mackenzie’s “The Universe in Zero Words: The Story of Mathematics as Told through Equations.”

headline: Remembering a Film About Brooklynites Who Were All About Streisand
text: “Come back to Brooklyn and give us a concert.”

headline: Snake Charmer
text: After 31 years of wrapping precious stones in gold, the jeweler veteran Paul Morelli has added handbags to his range. And it turns out that leather goods were always on his mind: “It’s not like I was going to start making candelabras,” he explains. But he wasn’t going to do just any old tote, either. “I wanted to steer away from what everyone else was doing — the minimal bag, if you will.” The 40-piece collection centers on an array of skins — fur, alligator, python, you name it — made (in Philadelphia) into hobo bags, satchels and minaudières. Every piece comes embellished with Morelli’s signature gold meditation bells, an exotic counterpoint to the line’s classic shapes (as in the $2,895 leather envelope clutch seen here) and a way of creating what the designer calls “a casual evening vibe.” Go to paulmorelli.com.

headline: Don’t Apologize, Don’t Explain (but You Can Confess Here)
text: I recently confessed one of my darkest kitchen secrets — that if I mess up a dish, I’ll often just change the name and serve it anyway. It’s a strategy I’ve been using for years, ever since, taking a cue from bitter melons, I changed the name of my baba ghanouj to “bitter eggplant salad.” As in, that thread of bitterness running through the dish was supposed to be there. (Not.)

headline: Strict New Procedures for Iran Currency Trading After Protest
text: TEHRAN — Iranian police officers moved to arrest unlicensed currency dealers and increase patrols in the center of the capital on Monday to prevent unofficial trading from disrupting new government-imposed rates of exchange for the national currency, the rial.

headline: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
text: This week’s birthdays include one of my favorite writers, Elmore Leonard, hardly a boomer, but an author whose books of snappy dialogue, black humor and characters of questionable character influenced this generation of writers and are pure joy to read. There may not be anyone who can set a plot in motion with fewer words than Mr. Leonard. Take a look at this interview with him where he describes how he writes. Like a lot of gifted people, he makes what he does sound very simple.

headline: What They Wore When the Impressionists Painted
text: PARIS—”The Belle Époque has never seemed such an orgy of gorgeousness as it does in ‘Impressionisme et la Mode’ at the Musée d’Orsay,” Suzy Menkes writes in her review of the exhibition.

headline: My 6 Biggest Complaints About Business Travel
text: Although TerraCycle still has less than $20 million a year in annual revenue, it operates in 21 countries now. That means that my intense domestic travel — Minneapolis to Racine, Wisconsin, to Chicago — has morphed into intense global travel — Newark to Bogotá, Colombia, to Tel Aviv.
