The question is a perfect strike for an existentialist like the San Francisco Giants’ Brian Wilson, who is on the disabled list after having reconstructive surgery on his right elbow, his season shut down after two appearances in April.

headline: Q & A About Wittenberg and the Marathon
text: In less than three weeks, nearly 50,000 runners will participate in the New York City Marathon, the marquee event of New York Road Runners. Under the leadership of Mary Wittenberg, the marathon and the Road Runners organization more broadly have experienced soaring growth by almost every measure. The club has an increasingly global presence, and Wittenberg is one of the most influential women in sports.

headline: Austerity Protests Are Rude Awakening in Portugal
text: LISBON — Portugal has long been regarded a role model in the grinding euro zone crisis. In return for an international bailout, its government cut services and raised taxes while its citizens patiently endured with little of the popular outcry seen elsewhere in southern Europe.

headline: China in Hollywood, Hailed and Investigated

He will be honored at the third annual U.S.-China Film Summit, sponsored by the Asia Society of Southern California.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Without Jeter, Yanks Look to Nix and Nunez

headline: A Risky Lifeline for the Elderly Is Costing Some Their Homes
text: The very loans that are supposed to help seniors stay in their homes are in many cases pushing them out.

headline: Two Sides Trade Criticism in Rancor Over Libya Attack
text: WASHINGTON — Caught in the uneasy nexus between politics and foreign policy, the debate over the violence in Benghazi, Libya, that claimed four American lives turned angry on Sunday as Republicans said it reflected a dangerous failure by the Obama administration to protect Americans across the region. Democrats, meanwhile, accused the Republican presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, of “cravenly” trying to exploit the episode in a political “witch hunt.”

headline: Architects of Sound, Creating Structures From the Ground Up
text: One of the real challenges for a composer today is finding a way to structure a piece so that it comes across with a compelling dramatic arc. Things were a little easier back in the days when sonata form, rondo and other such genres were common, though in reality those classical forms provided little more than general layouts.

headline: Flavors of Algeria and China, and Emily Dickinson
text: In 1908 and 1909, after one of the most difficult periods of his life, Gustav Mahler wrote a dark, challenging masterpiece, “Das Lied von der Erde” (“The Song of the Earth”). It is a song cycle for two voices, but given its scoring for full orchestra and its length of more than an hour, on the title page Mahler called it a symphony.

headline: Celebrating a Southern California Light Before Its Sunset
text: A wistful fairy tale without a happy ending: that is the story of the Los Angeles singer-songwriters clustered in Laurel Canyon in the late 1960s and early ’70s, as sung and told by Lauren Fox in her enthralling new show, “Canyon Folkies,” on Friday at the Metropolitan Room. The program is a companion piece to “Love, Lust, Fear & Freedom: The Songs of Joni Mitchell and Leonard Cohen,” her brilliant exploration of the music and the personal relationship of two songwriting legends, which I saw at the same club in February.

headline: Tension Is Uncorked Before a Parting
text: We audience members are always getting attached to companies and individual performers — it’s one of the deeply human pleasures (and pains: life spans in dance can be so brief) to be gotten from following a live art form.

headline: A Reverse Mortgage Solicitation
text: Regulators worry that some of the same high-pressure tactics deployed during the subprime lending crisis are showing up again in reverse mortgage solicitations.

headline: Reconsidering Obama the Pragmatist
text: The December 29, 2008, issue of The Nation magazine proclaimed in all caps on the cover:  “Barack Obama, Pragmatist.” Inside, the story, written by Christopher Hayes, considered the idea that Obama was more interested in “what works” than in either conservative or liberal ideology. Others have continued to reflect on that idea: Fareed Zakaria, Glenn Greenwald, Peter Berkowitz and Andrew Sullivan have all done so of late, as have the academic philosophers who contributed to a recent symposium on Obama and pragmatism.

headline: ‘Girls’ Who Broke the Laugh Ceiling
text: The oral history is a dicey format, especially when it comes to comedy. Performers famed for their hilarious writing or delivery may not sound the least bit funny when talking about the creation myths behind their own careers.

headline: Jets Regain Footing, Trampling the Colts
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In a departure from the norm, the Jets’ special-teams unit — not their offense, not their defense — was announced before Sunday’s game against Indianapolis. Punter Robert Malone sprinted out of the tunnel. The long snapper Tanner Purdum welcomed the fans’ cheers. Fire spewed as Nick Folk, the kicker, slapped hands with his teammates.

headline: Cavendish Invitational Tournament in Monaco
text: The Cavendish Invitational tournament, which begins in Monaco on Monday, features two competitions. There is a two-day team tournament on Monday and Tuesday, followed by the main event, the three-day pairs.

headline: Christian Group Finds Gay Agenda in an Anti-Bullying Day
text: On Mix It Up at Lunch Day, schoolchildren around the country are encouraged to hang out with someone they normally might not speak to.

headline: Glories of Capitalism, With Gas at $40 a Gallon
text: If you have never read Ayn Rand’s legendary 1957 novel, “Atlas Shrugged,” (guilty!) or seen the 2011 dystopian fantasy “Atlas Shrugged: Part I” (not guilty, alas), you may have trouble parsing who’s doing what and why in that movie’s narratively addled sequel. “Atlas Shrugged: Part II,” which opened on Friday and was not shown in advance to critics for The New York Times, takes off where “Part I” left off. Like the first, it opens in 2016 with the world gripped in an economic crisis (and rife with amusingly torpid Occupy-style protests) that has led to an astonishing development that sounds like an environmentalist’s dream: because gas costs more than $40 a gallon, Americans now rely on railroads as their major means of transportation.

headline: On Stage, a Comic’s Still at Home
text: At the Beacon Theater almost two weeks ago Jerry Seinfeld didn’t walk to the microphone. He ran. After his meticulously paced trot, he froze in an action pose, then riffed on the challenge of simply going out to do something.

headline: Eerie Harmonics and Timbres Evoking a Swarm of Bees
text: Witold Lutoslawski, the avant-garde Polish composer, told a member of the LaSalle Quartet, which gave the premiere of his String Quartet in 1965, that “each particular player is supposed not to know what the others are doing, or at least to perform his part as if he were to hear nothing except that which he is playing himself.” In other words, the performers should ignore the chamber music mantra of closely listening to and collaborating with colleagues and instead think as a soloist.

headline: Jazz Guitarist Assumes Many Guises
text: Near the end of Pat Metheny’s capacious performance with his new quartet and his old machines on Friday night at Town Hall, he played his new song “Breakdealer,” and the best music of the night happened. It’s a medium-fast song with a hard rhythm and heavy accents; it’s a little dire, messaging right away that something’s going to go down, and it did.

headline: TV Debates That Sell More Than Just Drama
text: In 1960, John F. Kennedy was trailing Richard Nixon as they stepped into the crucible of the first nationally televised debate. While Kennedy soared, Nixon stumbled and never recovered.

headline: Worshiper in a Temple
text: “There is something about a Martini,A tingle remarkably pleasant;A yellow, a mellow Martini;I wish I had one at present.There is something about a Martini,Ere the dining and dancing begin,And to tell you the truth,It is not the vermouth–I think that perhaps it’s the gin.” — “A Drink With Something in It,” OGDEN Nash

headline: Driven by Desire Back to Meat
text: Sherie Rene Scott, a star of the 2010 Broadway production of “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown” but probably best known for the autobiographical “Everyday Rapture,” is opening a one-woman show on Tuesday night at 54 Below. Called “Piece of Meat” and developed in collaboration with Todd Almond as musical director, it’s a mash-up of (mostly) contemporary pop songs by Joni Mitchell, Talking Heads and Paul McCartney, among others, along with tightly woven monologues inspired, partly, by Ms. Scott’s recent conversion to omnivore, after spending her entire adult life as a vegetarian. She says, quite simply, that the show — which runs through Oct. 27 — is about “desire.”

Joe DiPietro, who wrote the book and co-wrote the lyrics with David Bryan, will write the screenplay for that tale of two star-crossed lovers living in segregated Memphis in the 1950s.

headline: Want to Ruin Teaching? Give Ratings

headline: Unique Morning Show on NPR Thrives as Others Slip

headline: A Seat for the Taking, but First Seeking Traction

text: Mayor Holly Brinda, a fourth-generation Elyrian, wants to restore the glory and the economy, and reviving the downtown would be a big step toward a revival.

headline: Drive Seeks to Curb Revelry on Lower East Side by Limiting Liquor Licenses
text: The crowds arrived on the Lower East Side on Friday night by car service, subway and taxi. Some people came bundled against the autumn chill. Others shivered, in thin dresses or T-shirts, prepared for the heat inside packed nightclubs with names like Viktor and Spoils, Hotel Chantelle and Libation.

headline: North Koreans See Few Gains Below Top Tier
text: DANDONG, China — On her weekly shopping trips to downtown Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea, a 52-year-old pig farmer who gave her name as Mrs. Kim tries to ignore the dusting of prosperity that has begun to transform the city in recent years: the newly built apartment blocks, the increasing number of Mercedes-Benzes that zip along once-empty boulevards, the smartly dressed young women who conspicuously gab on their newly acquired cellphones. She has never been to the Rungna People’s Pleasure Ground, a new amusement park where children of the elite howled with delight this summer as they shot down a waterslide.

headline: Mining Contract Details Disclosed in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Enmeshed in a bruising political battle over new mining rules seen as vital to Afghanistan’s economic future, the country’s mining minister on Sunday disclosed about 200 previous mining contracts for the first time, portraying the move as an attempt to bring transparency to a process vulnerable to corruption.

headline: Tebow Plays His Part on Fake Punt
New Mayor, Big To-Do List
text: ELYRIA, OHIO — Near the cherished gazebo of Ely Square Park, just outside Donna’s Diner, the mayor of Elyria waits with patient grace to perform a wedding already running late. She wears a blue blazer, white pants, a red-white-and-blue scarf and an American flag lapel pin that dazzles when caught by the midday June sun. It is Flag Day.

headline: High-Speed Trading No Longer Hurtling Forward
text: The hottest new thing on Wall Street is cooling down.

headline: Yanks’ Offense, Still Asleep, Fails to Support Kuroda
text: The Yankees lost the first two games at home, barely scoring four runs in 21 innings, their captain and hits leader, Derek Jeter, is moving on crutches, and they next face Justin Verlander, perhaps the best pitcher in baseball, in a critical Game 3 in Detroit.

headline: Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodian Leader Through Shifting Allegiances, Dies at 89
text: Norodom Sihanouk, the charismatic Cambodian leader whose remarkable skills of political adaptation personified for the world the tiny, troubled kingdom where he was a towering figure through six decades, died early Monday in Beijing. He was 89.

headline: Eagles’ Loss Adds to Run of Struggles and Doubts
text: PHILADELPHIA — Not much has come easily for the Philadelphia Eagles this season. Not holding on to the ball, not scoring points and certainly not winning.

headline: A Prisoner’s Incompetence, a Judge’s Discretion
text: At the Supreme Court last week, the  justices considered the rights of an Ohio death row inmate, Sean Carter, who challenged his conviction in federal court, but who is mentally incompetent and cannot assist in his own legal defense. Mr. Carter had pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity to rape and murder, but was found competent to stand trial. He sought to overturn the conviction, alleging ineffective assistance of counsel.

headline: Sick Leave in New York
text: The arrival of flu season is a reminder that New York City has no law requiring employers to provide paid sick leave and that the City Council should pass one. Connecticut requires paid sick leave from most companies with more than 50 employees. Seattle, San Francisco and Washington all require employers to provide sick leave, and workers in New York deserve the same benefit.

headline: The Speculators Win a Round
text: The foes of Dodd-Frank financial reform scored a victory recently when a federal court overturned a new rule to limit speculative trading in derivatives.

headline: Death by Ideology

text: America has Jerry Sandusky. Britain has Jimmy Savile.

headline: As Tension Escalates, Turkey Issues a Ban on All Syrian Aircraft
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s foreign minister announced on Sunday a ban on all Syrian aircraft entering his country’s airspace, days after the authorities discovered what they said were Russian military munitions on board a passenger plane bound for Damascus.

But Republican lawmakers leading the charge on Capitol Hill seem more interested in attacking President Obama than in formulating an effective response.

headline: Even Making Amends Comes With Drawbacks
text: A judge facing a potential death sentence — imposed by illness, as opposed to the legal system — is arraigned before the court of his progeny in “Don’t Go Gentle,” a tidy drama by Stephen Belber that opened on Sunday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater in an MCC Theater production. In the central role of a retired conservative judge in Buffalo, the veteran actor Michael Cristofer gives the play an absorbing center, delivering a prickly, moving performance as a man whose attempt to make amends for a lifetime of spiritual flaws only draws him deeper into conflict with his troubled children.

headline: What If Candidates Ran Without the Horse Race?
text: What would a presidential election be like if the media neither commissioned nor reported on any polls.

headline: Obama’s Prep Session Goal: Don’t Repeat Mistakes of Last Debate

headline: Gray Pinstripes: With Jeter Out, Time’s Toll Rises
text: It is the one foe every athlete faces, but no athlete can beat. Each knows that the end will come, that age is undefeated in the annals of sports. The trick is to make summer last as long as possible, to put off reality for another day.

headline: Getting It Right on the Field and in the Booth Isn’t Always the Same
text: You could sense George Steinbrenner smiling from Yankee heaven when the team’s radio voice, John Sterling, invoked the late owner Saturday night, as in, “If George Steinbrenner were alive, those tapes would be in the commissioner’s office tomorrow.”

headline: Cano Sets Record for Futility in Playoffs
text: Robinson Cano, the Yankees’ star second baseman, maintained Sunday night that he still felt good at the plate. The team’s hitting coach, Kevin Long, maintained that Cano still looked good at the plate. But for another night, the evidence, both visual and numerical, suggested otherwise.

headline: Knicks’ Copeland Stands Out After Entrance Is Put Off
text: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson kept rotating players in and out during the first half of Saturday’s preseason game against the Boston Celtics — everyone except for Chris Copeland. While Woodson used 11 players in the first half, Copeland watched from the bench, eager to get his chance.

text: No Yankee plays to the crowd more than Nick Swisher. But if Swisher, who is facing free agency, has played his final home game as a Yankee, he went out bitterly.

headline: A Shift to the Left in Lithuania Jeopardizes the Ruling Party
text: MOSCOW — Preliminary returns from parliamentary elections in Lithuania on Sunday showed voters on track to oust the conservative government of Prime Minister Andrius Kubilius — an apparent reflection of public anger over tax increases and other austerity measures imposed in response to the European financial crisis.

headline: Woman Must Relinquish Kafka Papers, Judge Says
text: JERUSALEM — An Israeli judge has ruled that a huge trove of documents written by Franz Kafka and his friend Max Brod that have been hidden from view for decades must be turned over to Israel’s national library, which plans to publish them online.

The new campus of the Cornell University graduate school for technology is expected to transform Roosevelt Island from a sleepy bedroom community into a high-technology hothouse, and indeed, the plans to be formally unveiled for the campus on Monday bear little resemblance to anything that is there now.

text: Stroke is the fourth leading cause of death among Americans, and a much larger contributor to chronic disability and health care costs than this ranking suggests. There’s no question that preventing strokes is important. But a big question is how best to do so and in whom.

headline: George Whitmore Jr., Who Falsely Confessed to 3 Murders in 1964, Dies at 68

He was 68.

headline: The Breakup Bed
text: I stopped seeing someone recently and decided, as one does in these situations, that it was time to change my life, or at least my bed. This bed and the set it is a part of have been an embarrassment to me ever since I told my mother I would take them. Big and overwrought, they are the sort of thing that might work in the European mountain house of a histrionic soprano, but in a New York City apartment they are too much. I was pretty certain that if a guy got a look at my bedroom he would reassess my character and be gone, although a good male friend, with whom I discuss this, told me that is not the case.

I also felt an odd personal connection to the Austrian athlete’s feat, the sort of connection that comes from family lore: my great-uncle, my grandmother’s older brother, was the first man to parachute from the stratosphere.

headline: E-Book Releases Are Coming for ‘Diary of a Wimpy Kid’ Novels
text: The personal journals of a young Greg Heffley, the not entirely wimpy protagonist of Jeff Kinney’s best-selling “Diary of a Wimpy Kid” book series, are getting an electronic upgrade. The Amulet Books imprint of Abrams said on Monday that it would release the first six volumes of the illustrated “Wimpy Kid” novels in e-book — or is that wimp-e-book? — format on Oct. 30, leading to the simultaneous hardcover and electronic publication of a new seventh book, “Diary of a Wimpy Kid: The Third Wheel,” on Nov. 13.

headline: CNH Rejects Merger Deal From Fiat Industrial
text: LONDON – The agricultural and construction equipment company CNH on Monday rejected a proposed merger with its Italian majority shareholder, Fiat Industrial.

headline: For Baby Boomers, the Perils of a Reverse Mortgage
text: It sounds like a good deal for boomers. A reverse mortgage that allows homeowners 62 and older to borrow money against the value of their homes and not pay it back until they move out or die. Perhaps the money could be used to pay off other debts, or take that vacation that was never possible while people were working fulltime.

headline: As Prices Soar to Buy a Luxury Address, the Tax Bills Don’t
text: The shimmering limestone tower at 15 Central Park West, where apartments routinely trade for upward of $20 million, has become symbolic of the most luxurious upper reaches of New York’s real estate market. Its architect, Robert A. M. Stern, is the dean of the Yale School of Architecture. The views stretch out over the expanse of Central Park. And earlier this year, a single penthouse sold for $88 million.

headline: Which Transit-Fare Increase Seems Fairest?
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority unveiled on Monday four proposals for a scheduled fare increase next March, introducing the possibility of raising the base fare on subways and buses to $2.50 from $2.25 or increasing the cost of a 30-day MetroCard by as much as $21.

headline: A Risky Financial Lifeline
text: Business Day Live: Reverse mortgages are costing some older Americans their homes. | Sprint to sell a controlling stake to SoftBank of Japan. | A reversal in fortunes for high-speed trading firms.

headline: Daily Report: Joining the Party, Not Crashing It
text: You’re at a dinner party, and conversation stalls over an urgent question — like how tall is the Statue of Liberty? What do you do? You pull out your phone and Google the answer, of course.

headline: Basil L. Plumley, Veteran of Three Wars, Dies at 92
text: Night had fallen as American and North Vietnamese soldiers exchanged sheets of gunfire during Operation Landing Zone X-Ray in the Ia Drang Valley in November 1965. Illumination flares attached to parachutes floated from American aircraft.

headline: Europe Urged to Revamp Education
text: BERLIN — Some European countries are cutting back on education spending to help their budgets at a time when it seems like Europe needs skilled and educated workers more than ever, a subject I write about in my Letter from Europe this week.

headline: Merchant Plaintiffs Line Up Against Credit Card Settlement
text: In July, The Times reported on the controversy surrounding a proposed settlement between merchants, on one side, and Visa, MasterCard and many of their issuing banks on the other. Now a majority of the named merchant plaintiffs in the suit have announced opposition to the settlement.

headline: The Data-Mining Industry Kicks Off a Public Relations Campaign
text: The Direct Marketing Association, a trade group in Manhattan, introduced a $1 million public relations campaign on Monday morning with a lofty title: the “Data-Driven Marketing Institute.”

headline: Bookshelf
text: The Swiss novelist Robert Walser (1878-1956) wrote in a scrawl so infinitesimal, it was once believed to be a secret code. “Microscripts” (New Directions / Christine Burgin, $25), a gorgeous paperback illustrated by Maira Kalman, collects some of his original drafts, including a short story that he squeezed onto a business card. For her rich ensemble novel “Eight Girls Taking Pictures” (Scribner, $25), Whitney Otto mined the real lives of 20th-century photographers like Imogen Cunningham and Ruth Orkin, creating linked fictional portraits full of glamour and grit. And Viktor & Rolf’s weirdly charming storybook, “Fairy Tales” (Hardie Grant Books, $20), began as letters that the Dutch designers exchanged with each other while traveling.

headline: With New Sanctions, European Union Tightens Screws on Iran Over Nuclear Work
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union toughened sanctions against Iran over its disputed nuclear program on Monday, banning trade in industries like finance, metals and natural gas, and making other business transactions far more cumbersome.

headline: Lusty Libertines in France
text: When the disgraced former banker Dominique Strauss-Kahn indulged in orgies, was he simply a free-spirited libertine following in a notorious tradition dating back centuries and pervasive in French culture?

headline: Giants Show Yankees What a Dynasty Looks Like
text: If there really is such a thing as a New York minute — best description: the length of time between a light turning green and a cabby honking at you — one of them happened over the weekend. It provided a snapshot of two New York sporting institutions heading in entirely different directions. In one tiny sliver of time, the Yankees got old. They also fell behind the Tigers, two games to none, with Justin Verlander set to pitch next on full rest, but to be sure, their crisis is not about just this series and season. They no longer look like a former or potential dynasty, but a big budget calamity that managed to put together one triumphant playoff run in 2009 and has been leaking oil ever since.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Red Bull Scores One-Two Finish in Korea
text: On the Formula One race circuit, it’s beginning to look a lot like 2011.

headline: Cycling Becomes a Cleaner Sport, Not a Safer One
text: A child’s sporting dream is precious. My dream to become a professional cyclist fueled a childhood of thrilling excursions, a healthy adolescence and lifelong friendships. Many of my peers in the professional peloton shared the dream. But, as I realized my goals, I found reality was far from what I had imagined.

headline: Image of the Day: Oct. 15
text: Hindu devotees performed a ritual, paying obeisance to their forefathers in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: We’re Three!
text: Some may commemorate the occasion with parties and presents, but we prefer to celebrate our birthday each year with a (festive?) look at our analytics.

headline: In Haryana, Hundreds Protest State’s Response to Rape
text: In Haryana, where a number of high-profile rape cases have attracted national attention in recent weeks, 800 protesters took to the streets on Monday to demand better policing and a safer environment for women.

headline: Some Spaniards Blame the Germans
text: MADRID — While many blame the Spanish prime minister for the delay in requesting aid from Europe, some point to Germany.

headline: Spain Waits, and Europe Frets
text: MADRID — It has become Spain’s version of Godot: waiting for Rajoy.

headline: Questions and Answers on How The Times Handles Online Comments From Readers
text: It may seem a bit circular, but it’s true: One of the topics that receives the most questions and comments to the public editor is online commenting itself. So what you’ll find below are answers to some of the most frequently asked questions on The Times’s policies and practices on this subject. The answers were provided by Sasha Koren and Bassey Etim, who manage social media and online commenting for The Times. The questions were assembled by my assistant Joseph Burgess, who often fields these reader queries as he combs through the public editor e-mail each day. Many thanks to all of them.

headline: Inside Christoph Niemann’s Potato Workshop
text: In this past Sunday’s Food & Drink Issue, Christoph Niemann, our contributing artist, relays the German legend of how potatoes became a staple of the local diet. He tells the tale using stamps that he carved out of potatoes. While he was at work, he sent along this snapshot from his studio. “It’s the anti-Photoshop,” he said. “The potato shop.”

headline: Stir-Fries for Crisp Autumn Days
text: I love stir-frying with the seasons. Right now I’m phasing out summer’s tomatoes and corn, green beans and zucchini and picking up Chinese broccoli, mushrooms, cabbage and carrots at the farmers’ market. I’m still finding an array of peppers and beautiful Asian eggplants to brighten my wok. Stir-fries can be adapted to any number of ingredients that may be lingering in your refrigerator, or in your freezer, like the frozen peas that liven up a fish and mushroom stir-fry that is one of this week’s recipes.

headline: Vi Hart: Fun with Hexaflexagons
text: Discover the wonders of hexaflexagons with Vi Hart.

headline: Getting That Extra Mile Out of Plastic
text: HONG KONG — Six decades ago, plastic erupted onto the world stage. By now, life without it is almost unthinkable.

headline: HPV Vaccine Doesn’t Increase Risky Behavior
text: In one study of parental attitudes toward the vaccine against human papillomavirus, or HPV, a sexually transmitted disease that raises the risk of some cancers, researchers found that concern that the vaccination would promote promiscuity was the single biggest factor in a parent’s decision not to vaccinate.

headline: Justices to Review Voter Law in Arizona
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether Arizona may require proof of citizenship in order to register to vote in federal elections. The federal appeals court in San Francisco blocked the state law in April, saying it conflicted with a federal one.

headline: On the Deficit
text: The latest Washington Post/ABC News national poll and New York Times/CBS News/Quinnipiac swing state poll both give President Obama the edge on health care, helping the middle class, Medicare and handling international crises. And they both show either a tight race or a slight advantage for the president on taxes and energy issues.

headline: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
text: A lot of boomer musicians with birthdays this week — Wynton Marsalis, Tom Petty, Richard Carpenter — and one who is not a boomer, but had an enormous impact on our generation’s music.

headline: Business Day Live: A Risky Financial Lifeline
text: Why reverse mortgages are costing some older Americans their homes. | Sprint to sell a controlling stake to SoftBank of Japan. | A swift reversal in fortunes for high-speed trading firms.

headline: AeroVironment E.V. Charger Goes Portable
text: AeroVironment, whose hard-wired 240-volt EVSE-RS charger is the official preferred home charger for the Nissan Leaf and other electric vehicles, is expanding its product line with a portable version. The retail price of the EVSE-RS Plug-In is $1,099, or $100 more than the static charger.

headline: American Politics and Chinese Data
text: In the midst of increasingly heated election rhetoric about China, Beijing has released some important economic data as its currency hits record highs.

headline: Face Time | Norman Reedus
text: In the AMC thriller “The Walking Dead,” which is broadcast on Sunday nights at 9 p.m., the actor Norman Reedus plays Daryl Dixon, who skillfully dispatches legions of zombies with a nifty crossbow. If zombie slaying isn’t you’re thing, he’s set to appear on the big screen soon in “Sunlight Jr.,” with Naomi Watts and Matt Dillon. Read on to find out what he finds most attractive in a woman and how he stays so lean and mean. Plus, the hair and makeup artists for “Walking Dead” weigh in on a few product picks and share their thoughts on Reedus.

headline: Putin’s Party Dominates Russian Regional Elections
text: MOSCOW — Candidates from the pro-Kremlin party United Russia won nearly all of the municipal and regional elections held across the country, according to results released on Monday, though analysts said the party’s success owed much to low voter turnout.

headline: Street Style: Graphic Prints
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Oct. 8.

headline: SoftBank’s Deal for Sprint Is One for the Books
text: Japanese companies have made a string of deals in the United States this year, but the pact announced on Monday is one for the record books.

headline: Myths, More than Traditional Medicine, Driving Rhino Slaughter
text: 5:02 p.m. | Updated below |Rhinoceros populations from Asia through Africa are plummeting in the face of burgeoning illicit trade in their horns, much of it driven by myths promoted by criminal smuggling syndicates and targeting the new wealthy in China and Vietnam. The Green blog and Dot Earth have explored these issues, but it’s worth a slightly deeper dive, here provided in a “Your Dot” contribution from Matthew Wilkinson, the founder and editor of the informative Safaritalk blog.

headline: Try to Focus on Your Personal Economy
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: 73,000 Political Ads Test Even a City of Excess
text: LAS VEGAS — No one comes here expecting anything in moderation. But to turn on the television these days is to shatter even Vegas-size notions of excess.

headline: Declining U.S. High-Frequency Trading
text: Once the hottest thing to hit Wall Street in years, high-speed or high-frequency trading — known as H.F.T. — is now struggling to make gains in today’s stock maket.

headline: Fed Official Says Monetary Steps Were Too Timid
text: The Federal Reserve’s recent expansion of its economic stimulus campaign was announced as a course correction. It wasn’t that economic circumstances had changed, officials said. They simply had concluded that they needed to do more. The implication, of course, was that the Fed had failed to do enough.

headline: Obama Campaign Feels ‘Good’ About State of Race
text: WILLIAMSBURG, Va. – The Obama campaign insisted Monday it remained sanguine about the state of the presidential race, a day before President Obama was to meet Mitt Romney in Hempstead, N.Y., for a second high-stakes debate.

headline: Mayoral Hopeful Switches to G.O.P.
text: The field of likely Democratic candidates for New York City mayor narrowed by one on Monday when Tom Allon, a newspaper publisher waging a long-shot bid, announced that he would switch to the Republican Party to increase his odds of making it to the 2013 general election ballot.

headline: Gerhard Richter Painting Sets Record Auction Price for a Living Artist
text: After the critical success of a recent retrospective at the Tate Modern in London and the Pompidou Center in Paris this year, the prices of paintings by Gerhard Richter have been soaring. They climbed higher still at Sotheby’s in London on Friday, when “Abstraktes Bild (809-4),” one of the German artist’s abstract canvases from 1994, sold to a mystery telephone bidder for $34.2 million. (It had been estimated to bring $14.1 million to $18.8 million.)

headline: Caught on Camera | The Architecture & Design Film Festival
text: It seems like only yesterday that the Architecture & Design Film Festival made its debut, but this year marks its fourth season. At the Tribeca Cinemas in New York from Oct. 18 to Oct. 21, this year’s festival includes more than 25 films from 11 countries, as well as discussions with filmmakers, architects and designers. Opening night brings the world premiere of “Design Is One: Lella & Massimo Vignelli,” Roberto Guerra and Kathy Brew’s look at the renowned husband-and-wife designers. Also showing that evening (at the Allen Room at Time Warner Center) is Richard Hankin’s “16 Acres,” which tells the story of the plans for rebuilding the World Trade Center site. Among the other diverse offerings are “Mission Statements: The Architecture of Dutch Diplomacy,” Jord den Hollander’s examination of a program that commissioned embassy buildings around the world from prominent Dutch architects; a short film about a group of young architects who build a lighthouse on a remote Scottish island; documentaries on both Long Island and West Coast Modernist houses; a look at Diller Scofidio + Renfro’s work on Lincoln Center and the High Line; a chamber opera based on the life and work of Louis Kahn; and “Paraiso,” Nadav Kurtz’s short about three immigrant window cleaners who spend their days rappelling down some of Chicago’s tallest buildings.

headline: Lots of Ways to Run a Race
text: These elite runners, taped at the 2012 Olympic trials, show a wide variety of footstrikes.

headline: In Maine, Independent Streak Complicates Political Landscape
text: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of each state’s political landscape and how it’s changing. Here is Maine, the Pine Tree State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Amy Fried, a political science professor at the University of Maine; and Ethan Strimling, who served as a Democrat in the Maine Senate for six years and now works as a political analyst for The Bangor Daily News.

headline: Holden Caulfield to Roam Manhattan in New Novel
text: The young-adult author Mary O’Connell’s first novel for grown-ups will feature perhaps the most famous young adult in literary history: Holden Caulfield.

headline: Rothschild Resigns from Board of Mining Company
text: LONDON – The British financier Nathaniel Rothschild resigned on Monday from the board of Bumi, the mining company that he helped to create.

headline: Disney Sets Dates and New Details for Marvel Superhero Movies
text: Having made a huge dent at the box office with its summer superhero adventure “The Avengers,” which has sold more than $1.5 billion in tickets globally, Walt Disney on Monday announced an updated release calendar that was heavy on Marvel Comics characters and packed with enough colorful costumes to put David Bowie’s wardrobe to shame.

headline: Devices Go Nose to Nose With Bomb-Sniffer Dogs
text: SAINT-LOUIS, France — Denis Spitzer wants to beat dogs at their own game.

headline: In New Orleans, a Coach With a Steady Hand
text: In the first installment of its “Real Training Camp” series, NBA TV traveled to New Orleans, where the Hornets aim to forge a fresh identity in the still choppy wake of Chris Paul’s departure.

headline: California Food Dreaming
text: I am a California-phile; I have been visiting for 40-plus years, and I lived in L.A. for a couple of years too. The state is endlessly fascinating.

headline: On College Essay, Write About Something That Made You ‘Feel Deeply’
text: The essay rules may be changing on the Common Application, but that doesn’t change some basic rules about creative writing.

headline: Parsing of Data Led to Mixed Messages on Organic Food’s Value
text: A team of scientists laboriously reviewed decades of research comparing organic fruits and vegetables with those grown the usual way. They found that, as many had suspected, the organic produce, farmed without synthetic fertilizers or pesticides, was more nutritious, with more vitamin C, on average, and many more of the plant-defense molecules that in people help shield against cancer and heart disease.

headline: Wall Street’s Fund-Raising Push for Romney
text: The Wall Street supporters of Republican candidate Mitt Romney are making a last fund-raising push as the election heads into its final three weeks.

headline: New Feature: What’s Going On in This Picture?
text: For our new “What’s Going On in This Picture” feature, we’ll collaborate weekly with Visual Thinking Strategies (V.T.S.). In this video, Philip Yenawine, one of the founders of the organization, conducts a live V.T.S. discussion about a work of art.

headline: Really? Tinted Contact Lenses Can Improve Athletic Performance
text: THE FACTS

headline: Allergies on the Move
text: Q. People say that about five years after moving to Austin, Tex., you start to get your “Austin allergies.” Is that possible?

headline: Redesigns Create Deals on New-Car Leftovers
text: Fall is usually a good time to buy a car because it’s the end of the model year, but even better deals are available if you’re willing to buy a model that is about to be discontinued or redesigned, Edmunds.com advises.

headline: Defendants in Sept. 11 Case Cooperate as Proceedings Resume at Guantánamo
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — The Sept. 11 war-crimes case before a military commission at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, resumed relatively smoothly on Monday as five men accused of being co-conspirators in the attacks were calm and cooperative in the first session of a weeklong pretrial hearing.

headline: Prenatal Mercury Exposure and A.D.H.D.
text: A new study suggests that prenatal exposure to mercury is associated with symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, but the greater a mother’s consumption of fish — a source of mercury — the less likely her child is to suffer these symptoms.

headline: Options in Treating Incontinence
text: The most common treatment for urinary incontinence is a daily dose of an anticholinergic medicine that alters the action of certain nerves. Botox injections are also used, often in cases where the medicine does not work.

headline: Lycopene Linked to Reduced Stroke Risk
text: Could eating tomatoes help prevent strokes?

headline: Showcasing the Power of Music, Even in War
text: Logitech, the Swiss company that makes computer mice, remote controls and other personal peripherals as well as videoconferencing products, is introducing onMonday a digital campaign in the United States and Europe for its new line of music-related products.

headline: For Rise of Blocked Punts, Go Back to Off-Season
text: There are many confounding details about this N.F.L. season, ones that make you wonder why anyone would be willing to put money on an outcome. The team that looked like the best in the league Sunday — the Giants — is 0-2 in its division. The entire A.F.C. East is the very definition of mediocrity: 3-3, although on the bright side, it’s the first time since the divisions were realigned in 2002 that all teams in a division are tied for first place this late in the season. The N.F.C. West, which just two years ago sported a sub-. 500 division champion, is filled with teams at or above .500, even though only one of them won Sunday.

headline: Growing Concerns About Reverse Mortgages
text: In The Times today, a cautionary tale about an increasingly popular income alternative for older people: reverse mortgages.

headline: Heat-Seeking Missiles in Syria: The SA-7 in Action with Rebels
text: Throughout this year, as fighting intensified in Syria and antigovernment fighters grew in numbers and in strength, it had seemed inevitable that they would acquire heat-seeking shoulder-fired missiles and turn them against the Syrian military aircraft.

headline: Steroid Shot Near Spine Gives Illness an Opening
text: One of the many troubling aspects of the national meningitis outbreak caused by a tainted steroid drug is that so many people are at risk: 14,000 are thought to have been exposed, mostly through injections near the spine for back or neck problems. The drug was contaminated with a fungus that causes a severe form of meningitis that can result in stroke.

headline: Answers to Readers’ Questions About Wittenberg and the Marathon
text: 10:21 a.m. | Updated The New York City Marathon, the marquee event of New York Road Runners, will be held this year on Nov. 4. The organization is led by Mary Wittenberg, one of the most influential women in sports.

headline: Debates and the Power of Live Event TV
text: TimesCast Media + Tech: The debates’ influence on the broadcasters. | Cory Doctorow, digital activist and novelist. | Social media meets spoken word poetry.

headline: Ambushed on the Road to Manhood
text: With “The Round House,” her 14th novel, Louise Erdrich takes us back to the North Dakota Ojibwe reservation that she has conjured and mapped in so many earlier books, and made as indelibly real as Faulkner’s Yoknapatawpha County or Joyce’s Dublin. This time she focuses on one nuclear family — the 13-year-old Joe Coutts; his mother, Geraldine; and his father, Judge Antone Coutts — that is shattered and remade after a terrible event.

headline: Myths of Running: Forefoot, Barefoot and Otherwise
text: It’s a topic of endless debate among runners. Is there a best way to run, so that you use the least energy and go the fastest? And does it help to run barefoot or in minimalist shoes?

headline: Bulls and Bears Fight It Out, in Courts
text: 5:17 p.m. | Updated with Silvercorp office declining to comment, and closing stock price.

headline: Obamas to Vote Early, Hoping Others Do the Same
text: WILLIAMSBURG, Va. – President Obama and his wife, Michelle, announced on Monday that they would both vote early, and Mrs. Obama was photographed holding an absentee ballot for Illinois that she later dropped in the mail. Mr. Obama followed up her announcement by saying that he would vote early, in person, on Oct. 25, the next time he planned to be in Chicago.

headline: Romney Raises $170 Million to Finance Final Push
text: Mitt Romney and the Republican Party have begun a late push to raise tens of millions of dollars in the closing weeks of the election, cash that will finance a last-minute barrage of advertising that Mr. Romney’s aides believe is critical to beating President Obama.

headline: Look of The Moment | Marion Cotillard
text: The Look: French Noir. An L.B.D. and matching nails get some Gallic flair from asymmetrical two-tone heels and a poppy trimmed clutch.

headline: Stoudemire Returns to Knicks Practice
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. – Amar’e Stoudemire returned to practice Monday and said he would play in the Knicks’ next preseason game, against the Toronto Raptors on Friday in Montreal.

headline: Tax Proposal in Mongolia Threatens Rio Tinto Project
text: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia — Rio Tinto’s biggest new mining project is under threat after the government of Mongolia said it was considering whether to renegotiate an investment agreement involving the $6 billion Oyu Tolgoi copper mine.

headline: A Spotlight on Compounded Medicines
text: When Julie Auslander’s son was sick and struggling to take his pills, she turned to a pharmacist, who made medicated patches for him to use instead. A few years later, when Ms. Auslander’s mother, who had dementia, needed anti-anxiety drugs but couldn’t swallow, Ms. Auslander turned again to a pharmacist, who prepared a special tablet that dissolved under the tongue.

headline: Clearwire Investors Bet on Inevitability of a Deal With Sprint
text: Sprint Nextel may have found its financial savior in SoftBank of Japan, thanks to a $21.3 billion deal that will provide ballast to the struggling cellphone service provider.

headline: A Crucial Child-Rearing Lesson From an Understanding Cow
text: “His mother saw that he was not lonesome, and because she was an understanding mother, even though she was a cow, she let him just sit there and be happy.”  “The Story of Ferdinand,” by Munro Leaf.

headline: The Chemistry Behind Great Food Pairings
text: Red wine and steak, soda and burgers, pickles and pastrami sandwiches — these are combinations that just work. Now researchers provide a scientific explanation for why these unions are appealing to the tongue. Astringents like red wine and pickles balance out the grease of steaks and pastrami.

headline: High-speed Trading Feeling the Pinch
text: High-speed trading firms struggle to maintain gains.

headline: A 700,000-Year Trip From Mars to Morocco
text: A meteorite that landed in the Moroccan desert last summer was ejected from the surface of Mars 700,000 years ago, a new study reports. The meteorite is composed of an abundance of black glass, with noble gases trapped inside.

headline: The Doctor Can See You Now. Really, Right Now.
text: Often the worst part of a visit to the doctor isn’t the awkward hospital gown, needle sticks or embarrassing physical exams — it’s the drawn-out wait, camped out in the reception room in the company of sick patients and old magazines.

headline: Mile 7: Where a Battle Was Fought in 1776
text: With all the cheering and the music, with runners dressed in tuxedos, tutus and Superman outfits, marathoners may be excused if they are not focusing on the American Revolution and the American pastime.

headline: F.D.A. Warns of Further Risk From Tainted Drugs
text: Health officials are warning that more people may be at risk from contaminated drugs made by a Massachusetts company linked to a growing meningitis outbreak.

headline: Prime Minister Emphasizes His Belief That Greece Will Stay in European Union
text: ATHENS — Even as talks with international creditors stalled, the Greek prime minister expressed optimism on Monday that an agreement would be reached that would end once and for all speculation that the country will leave the euro zone.

headline: A Tango Partner’s Light Touch, and Other Late Night Intimacies
text: Dardo Galletto Studios are on the 11th floor of an ordinary office building near Times Square. Metal folding chairs hug the perimeter of the room; a mirror covers one wall, and windows look out onto other office buildings. Exposed along the low ceiling are sprinkler pipes, strung with white Christmas lights — the place’s one touch of elegance and romance.

headline: TimesCast Media + Tech: Twitter and the Debates
text: The debates’ influence on the broadcasters. Cory Doctorow, digital activist and novelist. Social media meets spoken word poetry.

headline: Then as Now, Businessmen Bent on Power
text: The titans of the early industrial age get a professional-wrestling sort of treatment in the slickly made docu-series “The Men Who Built America,” which begins on Tuesday night on the History channel.

headline: Science Times Podcast
text: This week: an outbreak of fungal meningitis, a controversy over giving free samples of formula to new mothers, and detecting explosives with technology that mimics a bomb-sniffing dog.

headline: H.I.V./AIDS: Methadone Treatment for Addicts Is Linked to Lower H.I.V. Risk
text: Offering methadone treatment to drug addicts substantially reduces the risk that they will get H.I.V. or give it to anyone else, a new study has found.

headline: The Caucus Click: A Future Voter Considers Ryan
text: A child dressed in an elephant costume watched Representative Paul D. Ryan speak at a campaign town hall event on Monday at Carroll University in Waukesha, Wis.

headline: A Chemist Comes Very Close to a Midas Touch
text: In a lab in Princeton University’s ultra-sleek chemistry building, researchers toil in a modern-day hunt for an elusive power: alchemy.

headline: Hershey and Caffeine and Carburetors: A Tale of Two Car Shows
text: NEW CANAAN, Conn. — As he directed traffic on Sunday for Caffeine and Carburetors, the informal automotive gathering in this suburb about 40 miles north of Midtown, Doug Zumbach, the event’s founder, described the origins of his coffee klatch.

headline: Miami’s Ultra Music Festival Expands to Two Weekends
text: When a big music festival becomes successful, it clones itself. Just ask Coachella, which this year expanded to two weekends from one (and later to a Caribbean cruise). Or Lollapalooza or Electric Daisy Carnival, a dance event that started in Los Angeles and is now held in Las Vegas, Puerto Rico, New Jersey and Florida.

headline: Walkabout — 10/15: Putting Through the Statues and Getting Lost of Your Own Accord
text: Mini Golf, Big Ideas At Big Stone Mini Golf in Minnesota, 13 holes feel more like a tour through a sculpture garden. (The New York Times)

headline: Single Arachnid Fathers Attract More Mates
text: Single fatherhood isn’t easy, but for one type of arachnid, it comes with a few benefits. Among them is that females find single fathers more attractive than gallivanting bachelors.

headline: The Tastes of Myanmar
text: For fans of Southeast Asian cuisines like Thai and Vietnamese, discovering Burmese food is the adult equivalent of finding a new playground, right in your neighborhood.

headline: But How Do You Really Feel? Someday the Computer May Know
text: In a Cairo school basement, two dozen women analyze facial expressions on laptops, training the computers to recognize anger, sadness and frustration.

headline: In Myanmar, True Comfort in the Food
text: EACH time the Canadian photographer and writer Naomi Duguid traveled to Myanmar from 2008 to 2011, researching the country’s food traditions, she knew she had to cram in as much eating and learning as possible.

headline: ‘Walking Dead’ Sets Ratings Record on AMC
text: “The Walking Dead,” AMC’s hugely popular drama, became the biggest hit of the fall television season on Sunday night, with the premiere of its third season posting ratings that surpassed every other nonsports program on television in most viewing categories.

headline: Q and A: Tracking a Worrisome Dead Zone
text: For more than a quarter of a century, the marine ecologist Nancy Rabalais, the executive director of the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium, has worked to understand and to spread awareness of the so-called dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: When Life in a Hospital Feels Like High School
text: Did someone call for a young female doctor? Apparently so, because Mindy Kaling (“The Mindy Project”) and Jordana Spiro (“The Mob Doctor”) have already shown up this fall, joining Rachel Bilson (“Hart of Dixie”), who’s still hanging around from last season. Now it’s a quartet with the arrival of Mamie Gummer in “Emily Owens, M.D.,” making its debut on Tuesday night on CW.

headline: Olga Smirnova on Her Toes
text: You would notice her on any street, in any room in the world. Even here, in downtown Moscow, where half the women look like supermodels and the other half are merely very pretty; even here, in the gilded lobby of the offices of the Bolshoi Ballet, where dancers drift weightlessly across the inlaid marble floors. When Olga Smirnova appears, you know that she’s quite unlike anyone else. It isn’t just that she’s beautiful, though she is; with her long thin limbs, wide and raking cheekbones, and huge almond eyes, she looks like a runaway from Roswell, N.M., a lovely extraterrestrial who landed among us. But more than that, she carries the mysterious self-possession of someone who’s simply better at what she does than anyone else, a sense that she’s wrapped in her own dimension.

headline: McCaskill Spends Heavily to Ward Off Akin Threat
text: Senator Claire McCaskill, the Missouri Democrat fighting to keep her seat, spent nearly $7 million over a three-month period through the end of September and her campaign had more than $2.1 million in the bank for her race against Representative Todd Akin, according to quarterly disclosure reports her campaign released on Monday.

headline: Warren Among Top Senate Fund-Raisers of All Time
text: BOSTON — With a haul of $12.1 million in the last quarter, Elizabeth Warren has become one of the five most successful Senate fund-raisers of all time, surpassing the amount Hillary Rodham Clinton raised in her first Senate bid in 2000.

headline: Book by Disgruntled Ex-Salesman Offers His Analysis of the Culture at Goldman
text: During Greg Smith’s first week at Goldman Sachs, he was issued an identification badge and an e-mail address and each morning he had to scramble to make sure he got an 18-inch folding stool.

headline: Live Streaming: TimesTalks With Yoko Ono
text: Beginning at 6:30 p.m. Eastern time, watch a live stream of TimesTalks with Yoko Ono. She will discuss her work and her latest book, “An Invisible Flower,” with Michael Kimmelman, the New York Times architecture critic and global columnist.

headline: Adele Leads Record Label to $67 Million Profit
text: Over the last 20 months, as Adele’s album “21” spent week after week in the Top 10 — a total of 79 weeks in the United States, with 24 of them at No. 1 — envious record executives have, between salivations, wondered what kind of profit all those sales would bring.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Xbox Music, and H.P. Going Astray

headline: Eataly Coming to Chicago
text: Eataly, the bustling high-end food hall that Mario Batali, Joseph Bastianich, his mother, Lidia, and their partners opened in Manhattan more than two years ago, has reached an agreement to open its second United States store in Chicago, Mr. Bastianich said.

headline: They Plan to Dominate the World, but First They Want to Have Sex and Find Jobs
text: There were reasons to be curious about “Underemployed,” MTV’s latest fictional series. It was created by Craig Wright, whose previous show, “Dirty Sexy Money,” was a hoot. And it was billed as a story about the anomie of the just-post-college generation, in the same general category as Lena Dunham’s “Girls” on HBO and the underrated “I Just Want My Pants Back” on MTV.

headline: A Spectacle, Narrative and Acrobatic
text: If you forget to turn off your cellphone during “Urban,” don’t worry — no one will hear it if it rings. With a heavy hip-hop beat thumping throughout nearly the whole show, you won’t even notice if it’s set to vibrate.

headline: Rescued Owl Is Getting ‘Cage Rest’
text: The grounded saw-whet owl we wrote about on Friday after it was dropped off at the parks department’s headquarters in a shoe box is recovering quietly at a wildlife rehabilitation center on Long Island.

headline: ‘Obama Phone’
text: Last month the Drudge Report hyped a video of an African-American woman at an Ohio rally claiming the president had given her a free phone. “Everybody in Cleveland, low minorities, got Obama phones…Keep Obama in president, you know! He gave us a phone, he’s gonna do more.” Dozens of news sites took it upon themselves to explain that the Obama campaign was not in fact operating an electronics-for-votes ring in swing states, but that there is in fact a government program that provides low-income people with free or cheap phones. It started under George W. Bush, not his successor.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct.15

headline: Why the Debate Over Big Bird Is a Sign of Progress
text: This past Sunday in the magazine, Adam Davidson argued that, for all the surface discord that characterizes the Obama and Romney campaigns, the candidates hold surprisingly harmonious views on the economy. They back similar policies on free trade, Social Security and welfare. Perhaps their biggest disagreement centers on slightly different tax rates for corporations and investors. “For someone who lived in the first 150 years or so of this country,” Davidson wrote, “it might be hard to see what’s so different about the economic policies of Barack Obama and Mitt Romney.”

headline: No Indian Point + No Fracking = More Coal Burning?
text: The science writer John Horgan (who’s also a friend and Hudson Valley neighbor) has written a piece for Scientific American laying out the tradeoffs that face New York State, and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, if campaigners succeed in shutting the Indian Point nuclear plant and preventing gas drilling using hydraulic fracturing, or fracking.

headline: The Envelope, Please: Will Walker
text: Will Walker, a student at University School in Hunting Valley, Ohio, doesn’t feel like “lightning struck” at any of the colleges he visited. But he’s chosen apply binding early decision anyway.

headline: Romney Is Attacked by His Father’s Longtime Aide
text: A longtime aide to George W. Romney issued a harshly worded critique of Mitt Romney, accusing him of shifting political positions in “erratic and startling ways” and failing to live up to the distinguished record of his father, the former governor of Michigan.

headline: Giants Outfielder Exceeds Fill-In Status and Leaves Cabrera’s Shadow
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Because baseball is a meritocracy, not a democracy, personal affinity means little when it comes to matters of roster construction. For the better part of the summer, this fact presented Gregor Blanco, the San Francisco Giants’ left fielder, with a conundrum. Desirous of nothing more than the chance to prove his mettle, he found his path to playing time blocked by his best friend on the team.

headline: Six Hopefuls Worth Watching at the CMJ Music Marathon
text: This week thousands of musicians swarm into New York City for the annual CMJ Music Marathon, looking to advance their careers. During six days of high-decibel chaos, starting on Tuesday, 1,300 acts from dozens of countries will vie for attention from a legion of journalists, music executives, booking agents, promoters and ordinary fans, all traipsing through Manhattan and Brooklyn nightspots with laminated badges and a hunger to hear something fresh.

headline: Olmert Plans Comeback to Challenge Netanyahu
text: TEL AVIV — Ehud Olmert, the former prime minister who has spent the last several years battling corruption charges, is plotting a comeback that analysts say offers the best hope of uniting Israel’s fragmented political center, but also shows the opposition’s desperation in trying to block the seemingly inevitable re-election of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Goldman Names Ogunlesi to Board
text: Goldman Sachs announced an addition to its board late Monday, appointing Adebayo O. Ogunlesi as an independent director of the bank.

That matters, particularly now that Oracle is making direct forays into cloud computing.

headline: Hey, That’s My Professor Cursing on the Stage
text: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — David P. Schmidt stood center stage at the Quick Center for the Arts at Fairfield University here and glowered through his glasses at the audience before leaping into a corrosive, expletive-laden monologue from “Glengarry Glen Ross.” His character, Blake, is a hotshot manager, sent by the home office to inspire a handful of real estate salesmen with a contest: First prize, an Eldorado. Second prize, a set of steak knives. Third prize, you’re fired.

headline: Where Hungry Rats Will Do the Dirty Work
text: The “uncanny valley” is the phrase Masahiro Mori, a Japanese roboticist, used to describe the revulsion people feel when a robot or an image of a person is almost, but not quite, human. It’s the feeling we get when we begin to focus on a representation’s inhuman aspects — its vacant eyes, its eerie rictus — instead of projecting our humanity onto it. R2D2 is adorable because he looks nothing like a person. But animatronic wax figures? Totally creepy.

headline: App Smart Extra: A Look at Some Popular iPhone Apps

headline: Susie Bubble Thinks Pink
text: Susie Lau, a k a Susie Bubble of the fashion blog Style Bubble, took to the pavement in San Francisco for the Nike Women’s Marathon on Saturday in the name of the battle against breast cancer. Nike invited Ms. Lau to run the half-marathon (13.1 miles) to benefit the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. (Last year her mother received a diagnosis of breast cancer and has been receiving treatment since.) When Ms. Lau told her mother of her plans to run a half-marathon, Ms. Lau said: ”First she laughed, then finally was touched by the idea. This is pretty normal behavior from Chinese parents.” Susie accepted Nike’s invitation and has raised money with a Just Giving page, an online donation Web site.

headline: Paul Ryan, Catholic Dissident
text: DURING last week’s vice-presidential debate — the first time two Catholics have shared such a stage — a question about abortion was inevitable. To some viewers, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s stance — that he personally opposes abortion but does not believe in imposing those beliefs on others — came across as a wishy-washy mélange of moral intuitions. In contrast, Representative Paul D. Ryan, who laid out his ticket’s policy to “oppose abortion with the exceptions for rape, incest and life of the mother,” appeared to represent the principled, Catholic anti-abortion position.

headline: Doctor’s Bath for Corpses Reinvigorates Cold Cases
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — Alejandro Hernández Cárdenas took a scorched-looking, decomposed head and five stiff, bloated hands and gently submerged them in his secret solution. After they soak for three days, he said, any scars, lesions or birthmarks the victim might have had will reappear.

headline: Fed Governor’s Plan to Limit Bank Size Fuels Debate
text: Since the financial crisis, academics, politicians and even former bank chieftains have called for the nation’s banking behemoths to be broken up or shrunk — calls that appear to have fallen largely on deaf ears among Washington’s policy makers.

headline: Mr. Romney Needs a Working Calculator
text: To the annoyance of the Romney campaign, members of Washington’s reality-based community have a habit of popping up to point out the many deceptions in the campaign’s blue-sky promises of low taxes and instant growth. The latest is the Joint Committee on Taxation, an obscure but well-respected Congressional panel — currently evenly divided between the parties — that helps lawmakers calculate the effect of their tax plans.

headline: Adolescents in Grown-Up Jails
text: The practice of confining young people to adult jails and prisons is both counterproductive and inhumane. Adolescents who are locked up with adults are more likely to be raped, battered or driven to suicide than young people who are handled through the juvenile justice system. After the trauma of doing hard, adult time, young people often return home as damaged individuals who are more likely to commit violent crimes and end up back inside.

headline: Rules for Craftsmen
text: Voters have been astonishingly clear. In 2000, they elected George W. Bush after he promised to change the tone in Washington. In 2008, they elected Barack Obama after he promised to move the country beyond stale partisan debates. In this year’s first presidential debate, surveys show that viewers loved Mitt Romney’s talk of professionalism and bipartisanship.

headline: Pop Goes the President
text: To the clamor for administration records concerning embassy security, I’d like to add my own request. I hereby subpoena President Obama’s iPod.

headline: 2 Officers Being Investigated After Video Shows Them Beating Man

text: A prominent lawyer who has been involved in some of New York City’s most controversial criminal cases said he would run for Brooklyn district attorney, a move that would expand the field running against Charles J. Hynes, a longtime incumbent whose hold on the office has weakened amid mounting criticism.

text: It is no secret that Mitt Romney and his running-mate, Representative Paul Ryan, are opponents of abortion rights. When Mr. Ryan was asked at last week’s debate whether voters who support abortion rights should be worried if the Romney-Ryan ticket were elected, he essentially said yes.

headline: Manhattan Borough President Seeks Bonds to Expand Early Education
text: Piggybacking on a recent Bloomberg administration initiative, Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, plans to propose on Tuesday that New York City experiment with an innovative method to help pay for early education.

headline: Suicide ‘Insider’ Attack Kills Six in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A member of the Afghan intelligence service detonated a suicide vest Saturday, killing two Americans and four Afghan intelligence agency colleagues, Afghan and international officials said Monday.

headline: After a Childhood Pouring Refills, Reaching Beyond the Past
text: ELYRIA, OHIO — Bridgette the waitress glides through morning at Donna’s Diner with an easy, familiar air, as though she were born somewhere between the cash register and the coffee maker. She is a constant, like pancakes on the menu.

headline: A Twitching Nose at Security, Not Sniffing for Danger
text: MY job as owner and executive chef of my culinary company, Blu Aubergine, has me traveling all the time. I’d better like to fly. It’s the only way my business will work. Sure, flying is a lot less fun than it used to be, but all the annoyances are just part of the adventure of getting to where you’re going. I do a lot of events in the United States, but I also have to travel all over Europe, and have also been to South America, Asia and the Middle East, and I split my time between Rome and New York. Every place I go, I can find some culinary inspiration.

headline: Speedy Amos

text: Bridgette Harvan has been pouring coffee at her grandmother's place, Donna's Diner, since childhood. But now, approaching her 21st birthday, Bridgette is forging a new path away from the grill.

headline: Bed, Bathrobe and Beyond
text: The monogrammed bathrobes, the bedding and pillows? Hotels are now going far beyond that in offering products to remind guests of their stay or draw them back for another visit.

headline: Giants Pleased With All-Around Play Against 49ers
text: Coach Tom Coughlin hammered his Giants players throughout the preseason with the slogan “Build the Bridge,” urging them to continue to display the qualities that allowed them to sweep their final six games last season and emerge as Super Bowl champions.

headline: Giuliani Criticizes Obama on Handling of Benghazi Attack

Giuliani, the former mayor of New York City, had harsh words for President Obama’s handling of the situation in the Middle East, calling it “a policy of provocative weakness.”

headline: Seeking Aid, School Districts Change Teacher Evaluations
text: LONGMONT, Colo. — In an exercise evoking a corporate motivation seminar, a group of public school teachers and principals clustered around posters scrawled with the titles of Beatles songs. Their assignment: choose the one that captured their feelings about a new performance evaluation system being piloted in their district.

headline: The BlackBerry Stigma
text: BlackBerry devices, once the phone of movers and shakers, have become a punchline.

text: Rachel Crosby speaks about her BlackBerry phone the way someone might speak of an embarrassing relative.

headline: Fenway-Style Makeover Would Befit a Soccer Landmark
text: In English soccer, there is no place where history and tradition are valued, respected and cherished more highly than at Anfield, the home of Liverpool F.C.

headline: U.N. Envoy Seeks Pause in Syria for Holiday
text: The new Syria peace envoy from the United Nations and Arab League enlisted Iran’s help on Monday in an effort to negotiate a cease-fire in observance of a three-day holiday dear to all Muslims, hoping that such a religious reprieve could become the basis for a dialogue.

headline: A Short Defense of Literary Excess
text: The novelists I find myself attracted to are those who cannot resist the extra adjective, the additional image, the scale-tipping clause. It feels necessary to assert and celebrate this, for we are living in puritanical times. The contemporary preference seems to be for the economical, the efficient, for simple precision (though there is of course such a thing as complex precision). Books, it appears, should be neat and streamlined. Language shouldn’t be allowed to obscure a good story. There is a craving for easily relatable and sympathetic characters. Among critics and reviewers, the plain style is more likely to be praised than the elaborate or sprawling. Embellished prose is treated with suspicion, if not dismissed outright as overwritten, pretentious or self-indulgent. Drab prose is everywhere.

headline: Debate Fever on Campus Helps Lift Hofstra’s Image
text: David Zuniga, 21, is just the kind of student Hofstra University is looking for. A senior from West Palm Beach, Fla., with a mania for politics, Mr. Zuniga was deciding where to apply to college when he watched the presidential debate between Senators John McCain and Barack Obama at Hofstra in 2008.

headline: 2nd Presidential Debate Is Less Formal, but Little Is Left to Chance
text: The format for the second presidential debate is designed to be a little less stiff — a free-flowing question-and-answer session between the candidates and a studio audience.

headline: Lewis Is Out for Season, Leaving Hole in Middle
text: The Baltimore Ravens are 5-1 and might be the best team in the A.F.C. despite the absence of their best defensive player. But on Monday, they suffered a crushing blow to their psyche and persona when the team announced that another key defender, the star linebacker and leader Ray Lewis, would miss the rest of the season with a torn right triceps muscle, an injury that could imperil his career.

headline: New Rule Leads to Old School Politics in South Carolina, Critics Say
text: ATLANTA — What began as a gap between the digital revolution and the way South Carolina’s candidates had long filed for office has blown up into a legal battle that many say reflects a state whose politics have been raucous since the day it fired the shots that started the Civil War.

headline: A Yankees Rally? Precedents Are Few but Memorable
text: The Yankees head into Comerica Park on Tuesday night for Game 3 of the American League Championship Series having to confront the Detroit Tigers’ ace, Justin Verlander, and plenty of unwelcome precedent in the record books.

headline: S. Ward Casscells, Pentagon Medical Chief, Dies at 60
text: Dr. S. Ward Casscells, a nationally prominent cardiologist who astonished himself and those who knew him by joining the Army Reserve at 54 and volunteering to go to Iraq before being appointed the Pentagon’s top medical officer, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 60.

headline: Amy Poehler and Tina Fey to Host Golden Globe Awards
text: After the recent announcement that the “Family Guy” creator Seth MacFarlane will host the Academy Awards in February — an appeal, perhaps, to the Y-chromosomes out there in TV land — the organizers of the Golden Globe Awards are offering their own form of counterprogramming: on Monday night, they announced that Amy Poehler and Tina Fey, the former “Saturday Night Live” co-stars and now mainstays of NBC’s Thursday night comedy lineup, will host the Golden Globes in January.

headline: Where Mayor Sees Clear Fiscal Skies, Clouds Gather

Jackson Jr., who has stayed out of public view for much of the past four months while undergoing treatment for bipolar disorder, is being investigated by federal authorities for the possible misuse of campaign money, a federal official confirmed on Monday.

headline: Proposals to Redraw School Lines Raise Alarm

Kahn designed it, a monument to Franklin Delano Roosevelt is scheduled to be dedicated on Wednesday on Roosevelt Island. Among those expected to take part are Tom Brokaw, Bill Clinton, the West Point Band and the singer Audra McDonald.

text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Mitt Romney will again debate their visions for the next four years on Tuesday night, and if the campaign so far is any guide, they will not acknowledge that the winner’s agenda could depend on the fiscal showdown between Election Day and Inauguration Day.

text: ALBANY — While the nation’s unemployment rate has been declining over the last year, New York State’s has been rising sharply, presenting a challenge for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo as he tries to build an image as a fiscal centrist who can transform the state’s business climate.

headline: Do Good C.E.O.’s Make Good Presidents?
text: With only a few weeks remaining until the election, it’s still not clear how Mitt Romney would manage our jobs crisis. There aren’t many lessons from his term as the governor of Massachusetts — the economy was comparatively healthy back then, and the unemployment rate was fairly low. His current economic platform lays out broad principles (Principle No. 1: Don’t be Barack Obama) but is light on specifics. All that’s certain is that Romney has promised to use decades of business savvy to create jobs, which raises the question: how do you apply business strategy to a jobs crisis? No business views hiring as an objective. When a crisis hits, the response of many executives is to let workers go.

headline: In a Time of Hidden Crisis, President Visits Main Street
Sharing Life and Liquor on a Changing Bushwick Street
text: In 1996 Brenda Ann Kenneally moved into a Brooklyn neighborhood that had many abandoned buildings, empty lots strewn with garbage and what was essentially an open-air crack market. She was just looking for an affordable place to live, but her new home proved to be fertile ground for making her socially concerned photography.

headline: Paul Ryan Can’t Lose
text: On a Monday night in late September, Paul Ryan sat on the edge of a couch in his suite at the Cincinnatian Hotel, his left fist clenched so tightly around the neck of his bottle of Miller Lite that I could see the veins bulging in his hands. It was the end of a long day that began at Ryan’s home in Janesville, Wis., where he’d spent the weekend preparing for the vice-presidential debate. Early Monday morning, he flew to the first of two fund-raisers, on top of which he did three local TV interviews and a brief chat on Fox Business Network and also a town-hall meeting, plus a half-hour phone call with Mitt Romney, after which he finally settled in on the couch to watch his Green Bay Packers play the Seattle Seahawks on “Monday Night Football.” A few minutes after kickoff, Ryan’s traveling press secretary, Michael Steel, led me into the suite where Ryan was watching the game with his older brother Tobin, his campaign adviser Dan Senor, the Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus and Senator Rob Portman of Ohio.

headline: Goldman Beats Expectations
text: GOLDMAN BEATS EXPECTATIONS  |  Goldman Sachs may be getting its groove back. The Wall Street firm said on Tuesday that it swung to a profit in the third quarter, reporting net earnings applicable to common shareholders of $1.46 billion, compared with a loss of $428 million in the quarter a year ago. The third-quarter profit amounted to $2.85 a share, beating the $2.12 a share analysts were expecting. Goldman also said it was increasing its dividend to 50 cents from 46 cents. (The conference call to discuss the results is at 9:30 a.m. Dial 1-888-281-7154 to listen in the United States.)

headline: The Great Hanging at Gainesville
