headline: CMJ: It Begins. Brace Yourselves.
text: The grass-roots music business spills out onto the streets this week with the 31st annual CMJ Music Marathon. From Tuesday through the wee hours of Sunday morning, it brings some 1,300 acts — bands, rappers, songwriters, laptoppers and no doubt some ukulele players — in search of attention and its dividends. There once were thoughts that the Internet, where nearly every CMJ band can be sampled at leisure (and in higher fidelity), would make a mass live showcase like CMJ obsolete. Instead, paradoxically, more and more musicians arrive, eagerly hoping that a 25-minute set in some firetrap basement might be witnessed by someone useful — or, now, recorded and uploaded to YouTube.

headline: Obama-Backed Battery Maker Files for Bankruptcy
text: An electric car battery maker that President Obama touted as part of a vanguard of a new American electric car industry has filed for bankruptcy and is selling its major assets, the company announced on Tuesday.

headline: In Setback for Military Tribunals, Bin Laden Driver’s Conviction Is Reversed
text: A federal appeals court on Tuesday threw out the terrorism conviction of a high-profile former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, Salim Hamdan, a Yemeni who served as Osama bin Laden’s driver and bodyguard and whose case led to a landmark 2006 Supreme Court ruling striking down the Bush administration’s first version of military commissions.

headline: In Citigroup Shake-Up, a New Show of Power by Boards
text: The departure of Vikram S. Pandit shows clearly who is in charge of Citigroup: the board of directors. For good or for bad, boards are increasingly taking charge of corporate America. The reign of the imperial chief executive is over.

headline: Town Hall Format Poses Risks for Obama and Romney
text: As President Obama and Mitt Romney prepare for their debate on Tuesday night, they face an unpredictable variable that was not a factor in their previous encounter: the common voter.

headline: If You Like Heart’s Hard Rock. . .
text: Ann and Nancy Wilson of Heart and Grace Potter of Grace Potter & the Nocturnals have a riveting  a stage presence, distinctive voices and ample guitar riffs.

headline: Why Private Medicare Plans Don’t Cost Less
text: Dana P. Goldman is the director of the Leonard D. Schaeffer Center for Health Policy and Economics at the University of Southern California. Adam Leive is a graduate student at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. Daniel McFadden is a senior fellow at the Schaeffer Center and the 2000 Nobel winner in economic science.

headline: The People Who Make Up Citi’s Board
text: Vikram S. Pandit’s sudden exit from Citigroup appears to have much to do with tension with the bank’s board.

headline: Ranting Elmo Finds Prosperity Out West
text: Following the tradition of Broadway performances that strike out on national tours, the man known for dressing up in an Elmo costume and shouting anti-Semitic rants in New York City seems to have taken his show on the road.

headline: Women on the Verge of a Political Breakthrough
text: NEW YORK — Already American women are setting records in this election cycle, running for office in ground-breaking numbers, as I write in my latest Female Factor column. But beyond the sheer numbers, among the scores of veterans and newcomers, several women stand on the brink of making history.

headline: Five Players to Watch This Season
text: With the N.B.A.’s season only weeks away, teams are settling in to a regular routine of training camp practices and exhibitions, while fans get their first full look at the newest additions to their teams. With the league back to its standard 82-game schedule, which players can we expect to make the leap from rising star to household name? Here are five likely candidates.

headline: Raising Snails
text: To raise delicious snails, you need to know what makes them tick.

text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Arrests of 2 U.S. Sailors in Rape Case Threaten to Fan Okinawa’s Anger
text: TOKYO — Two United States Navy sailors were arrested on Tuesday on suspicion of raping a woman in Okinawa, local news reports said, an episode likely to fan anger on an island increasingly outraged over the presence of a large American base.

headline: The Snail Wrangler
text: STRATHMORE, Calif.

headline: Justices Clear the Way for Early Voting in Ohio
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday cleared the way for early voting in Ohio the weekend before Election Day. The justices, in a one-sentence order without noted dissents, let stand an appeals court ruling that had blocked the efforts of officials in Ohio to restrict early voting there. The Supreme Court’s action was a victory for the Obama campaign, which had sued to overturn the restrictions.

headline: Superheroes Occupy New York
text: Growing up, I never collected comic books. That doesn’t mean I didn’t enjoy comics. The Sunday funnies brought me Hal Foster’s “Prince Valiant” and “Ripley’s Believe It or Not.” The one superhero of my childhood was Superman, and he was in a black-and-white TV. This might explain my current fascination with New York Comic-Con.

headline: Art Theft Strips Dutch Museum of Masterpieces
text: Works by Matisse, Monet and Picasso were taken from a Rotterdam museum.

headline: Rainbow Room Is Given Landmark Status
text: Now it is official: The Rainbow Room, a personal landmark for New Yorkers who proposed there or dreamed of putting on their finest and dancing away the night there, is a city landmark.

headline: No Guarantee of Obama Rebound in Second Debate
text: President Obama was soundly defeated in the first presidential debate in Denver, contributing toward about a four-point swing toward Mitt Romney in head-to-head polls — enough to turn the race from one in which Mr. Obama had a clear lead into a very close contest.

headline: Energy Price Increases Pose Challenge for Merkel
text: BERLIN — In the aftermath of the tsunami and nuclear meltdown in Japan last year, Chancellor Angela Merkel announced perhaps her most sweeping domestic ambition, a plan to shutter Germany’s 17 nuclear reactors and switch to 80 percent reliance on wind, solar and other renewable sources by 2050.

headline: Left Unsaid
text: Tonight marks the last chance to hear the presidential candidates debate domestic issues, since their third and final debate next week will concern foreign affairs.

headline: Disney’s Magic Kingdom Will Be Dry No More
text: The Magic Kingdom Park at Disney World in Florida is about to get even more enchanting, for those 21 and older. Next month, it is ending its 41-year-old policy of no alcohol by serving wine and beer during dinner hours at Be Our Guest, its new “Beauty and the Beast”-theme restaurant. The park’s executives have realized, apparently, that no French meal is complete without a glass of Chablis or Bordeaux.

headline: Preview of Second Presidential Debate
text: TimesCast Politics: Looking ahead to the town hall debate. | The challenges of direct voter interaction. | Two incumbents face off in Iowa.

headline: A Memorial for Robert Hughes at the Met
text: The life of Robert Hughes, the art critic and historian who died in August at the age of 74, will be remembered by a group of writers, editors and fellow critics who knew him, as well as family members, at a ceremony on Thursday at 2 p.m. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The memorial, in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, will include remarks by Tina Brown, Leon Wieseltier, Peter Carey, Simon Schama, Michael Kimmelman and Mr. Hughes’s longtime editor at Knopf, Peter Gethers, and by Mr. Hughes’s wife, Doris Downes, and stepson, Fielder Jewett. (Mr. Gethers, Ms. Downes and Mr. Jewett are new additions since the roster of speakers was announced on Tuesday; Peter Mathiessen, who was originally announced as a speaker, will not be appearing.) Jeremy Denk will perform at the piano. The ceremony is open to the public.

headline: CNN to Interview Reddit’s Violentacrez: A Troll Comes Out From Under the Bridge
text: Last week’s article on Gawker that outed Violentacrez, the moderator of several controversial forums on the online community of Reddit, hit all the Web’s hot buttons: Freedom of speech versus privacy, anonymity versus accountability, and community versus the broader community.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Looking Ahead to the Second Presidential Debate
text: Getty Images

headline: A Trip Down the Short, Sad Path of Old Lane
text: Perhaps the best trade Vikram Pandit made as a hedge fund manager was selling his firm to Citigroup.

headline: Conservative Group Calls for Tennessee Republican’s Resignation
text: Tennessee’s oldest and largest conservative organization is mounting a campaign to force the resignation of Representative Scott DesJarlais after a taped phone call of Mr. DesJarlais, an anti-abortion Republican, appeared to show him pressuring a mistress to terminate a pregnancy.

headline: Nominees for the Clive Barnes Foundation Awards Are Announced
text: Joaquina Kalukango (“Hurt Village”), Derek Klena (“Dogfight”), Rob McClure (“Chaplin”) and Stephen Tyrone Williams (“My Children, My Africa”) are the nominees in theater and Lauren Lovette (New York City Ballet), Steven Melendez (New York Theater Ballet) and Ashley Murphy (Dance Theater of Harlem) are the nominees in dance for the Clive Barnes Foundation Awards, the organization announced on Tuesday. The awards are given to two talented young professionals, one in the field of theater and one in the field of dance. The winners will be honored at an awards ceremony on Dec. 10 at the Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center.

headline: Fresh Ricotta
text: Rich, homemade ricotta that’s done in an hour, courtesy of Mark Bittman.

headline: Holmgren’s Browns Tenure Ends With a Thud
text: As it became official on Tuesday that new ownership for the Cleveland Browns means Mike Holmgren exits stage left, the only real question is whether getting bounced from the hapless Browns is a good or a bad thing. No one likes to get fired, but on the plus side for Holmgren, he no longer has to absorb his team’s weekly “Three Stooges” routine as a personal affront.

headline: The Get | Rebecca Minkoff’s Earrings
text: Playing off her prim-with-an-edge aesthetic, the designer Rebecca Minkoff took her first step into the jewelry business with a costume bijoux collection that follows suit: punky bangles in yellow gold with a faux pavé trim come with matching studs; black crystals set on silver metal mimick a rivière-style necklace; and neon yellow enamel earrings mix Art Deco modernism with space-age slickness. Our favorite pieces are these pavé earrings that can be worn forwards or backwards and cling to the ears like little glittering claws. Consider us captured.

headline: A Woman From the Country in Mitterrand’s Kitchen
text: PARIS—As truffle season in France inches closer and the smell of damp leaves in the forest evokes the seasonal change in food, a film called “Les Saveurs du Palais” is arriving in Paris. The film’s English title, “Haute Cuisine,” misses a beat: “Palais” means palace as well as palate in French. The story is based on a two-year period when François Mitterrand, then president of France, hired a personal cook, ruffling the feathers of the official in-house Elysée chef.

headline: Here Today, Gone Tomorrow: Preserving Culture in Changing Times
text: Overview |  What aspects of our lives deserve saving for future generations? What relics and traditions are in danger of disappearing forever, and should be preserved? In this lesson, students examine a range of efforts to preserve history and culture, from rural India to the Apollo lunar missions. Students can take the role of preservationist, investigate cultural theft and play referee on local and international preservation debates.

headline: Hip-Hop Meets Hipster in Bed-Stuy
text: We spotted Lance Fresh, sporting a leather jacket and a retro hat, taking photos with his friends on the corner of Nostrand Avenue and Halsey Street.

headline: Ted Turner Cited for ‘Place-Based’ Media Efforts
text: Ted Turner is known for his pioneering efforts in cable television, founding channels like CNN and TBS. He was honored on Tuesday for his leadership role involving other types of screens.

headline: Hollywood Moguls Pledge $90 Million to Organization Supporting Workers
text: Following in the philanthropic footsteps of entertainment moguls like Barry Diller and Rupert Murdoch, a trio of Hollywood heavyweights – David Geffen, Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg – pledged on Tuesday that they would each donate $30 million to the non-profit Motion Picture & Television Fund.

headline: Spain Nears a Decision on Asking the European Union for a Bailout or Loan
text: LONDON — After months of delay, the Spanish government is edging closer to making a decision about whether to ask for European financial assistance.

headline: Neil Young: One Show Well Worth Our Time and Money
text: Like most families, we try to keep a tight rein on discretionary spending. But when I heard that the musician Neil Young would be touring with the band Crazy Horse, I decided that if he played anywhere near where we live, we’d certainly buy tickets.

headline: Something in a Sleeve for Spring
text: From the look of the spring shows last month, fashion has had a wake-up call. Designers who routinely cater to stringy adolescents, or parade arm-baring sheaths that only Michelle Obama could love, suddenly seemed to get that their most devoted clients — women well over 40 with upscale tastes and incomes to match — view the first lady’s biceps with serious pangs of envy.

headline: $11 Million Severance Reported for Murdoch Aide
text: LONDON — Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of News International, Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper group, received about $11 million when she resigned last year in the midst of the scandal over phone hacking and other malpractice at two of the company’s tabloid newspapers, people familiar with the terms of her severance agreement say.

headline: A Picasso and a Gauguin Are Among 7 Works Stolen From a Dutch Museum
text: PARIS — With impeccable timing and taste, thieves in the wee hours of Tuesday morning plundered an art museum in the Netherlands that was celebrating its 20th birthday and made away with seven borrowed paintings, including valuable works by Picasso, Monet, Gauguin, Matisse and Lucian Freud.

text: Part 7: The economist and Op-Ed columnist explains why the Federal Reserve doesn’t have the power it once did.

headline: Krugman: The Awesomeness of This
text: Part 2: The economist and Op-Ed columnist explains the single “intellectual failure” keeping our economy from roaring back to full health.

text: Part 13: The economist and Op-Ed columnist reflects on why he thinks his fellow economists failed in response to the financial crisis.

text: Part 9: The economist and Op-Ed columnist explains why the politicians considered the most “serious” about fiscal matters are also often the most wrong.

text: Part 3: The economist and Op-Ed columnist explains why the idea that austerity can rescue the economy from a downturn is reasonable but wrong.

headline: A Gratifying Adventure in Group Cooking
text: THERE is the potluck, but there is also collective cooking. And given a willing helper or two, it can turn a fairly standard weeknight meal into a rocking party. The pace is not necessarily relaxed, but it’s fun.

headline: Mile 8: Where the Nets Now Roam
text: Once athletes cross the Mile 7 mark, there’s less than a mile to go on Fourth Avenue before the complexion of the course changes dramatically.

headline: Suspect in Lower East Side Killing Surrenders to Police
text: The suspect in the Oct. 6 fatal shooting outside a Lower East Side barbershop was arrested on Monday after turning himself in at the neighborhood’s police precinct house, the police said.

headline: A Second Act, Stuffed With Pie
text: It was the glass ceiling that drove Alicia Scotti into the kitchen full time. This 54-year-old mother of two from the Riverdale section of the Bronx had a career in entertainment marketing for television, but finally quit to follow her love of baking. She grew up with 10 siblings in Rhode Island in a family that cooked and baked; with her own family, she cooks dinners from scratch most nights. She started her pie business a little over a year ago, baking to order at a commercial kitchen in the Bronx. Her pies, which are outstanding, include honey-pine nut, chocolate-walnut and pear-butterscotch from a list of more than three dozen. Her old-fashioned Nesselrode pie is not made in the style that was popular in New York — a gelatin custard studded with candied fruits — but with a chestnut cream filling, the original European recipe. She also bakes cookies, bars and cakes.

headline: After a Ban, Wagyu From Japan Returns
text: After an absence of nearly three years, wagyu is being allowed back into the United States from Japan. Imports of the beef had been discontinued because of an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Japan, and so restaurants and shops sold beef from wagyu cattle raised in the United States, and many will continue to do so. But there is a big difference. The genuine Japanese version, bottom, is as costly for one steak as a cashmere sweater and is much more densely marbled with fat. Its muscle is paler in color than its American counterpart, top. There are grades of Japanese wagyu, the highest being 10 to 12. It has a more complex flavor, think “umami.” And when cooking it to medium, it’s essential to put a good bit of sear on the buttery fat.

headline: Beer Turns to Whiskey
text: Richard Stabile, an electrical engineer, has been making vodka on the North Shore of Suffolk County for the last four years. His Long Island Spirits is the first distillery to open on the Island since Prohibition. Now, in the handsome 100-year-old stone-and-shingle horse barn that houses his distillery, he is also making a whiskey and a brandy. Though he starts his vodka from raw materials (local potatoes that are cooked and mashed), for the base of his whiskey he uses a strong beer, Old Howling Bastard, made by Blue Point Brewing in Patchogue on the South Shore.

headline: Students Pepper-Sprayed by Classmate at Queens School
text: Thirty-four Queens middle school students were pepper-sprayed by a classmate at lunch on Tuesday, according to the city’s Department of Education.

headline: Iran Sanctions May Cut Supply of Currency
text: Western economic sanctions imposed on Iran over its disputed nuclear program have severely depressed the value of its national currency, the rial, causing higher inflation and forcing Iranians to carry ever-fatter wads of bank notes to buy everyday items. But the sanctions have also presented a new complication to Iran’s banking authorities: they may not be able to print enough money.

headline: Pandit, a Low-Paid C.E.O. Among Wall Street Peers
text: Vikram S. Pandit worked as Citigroup‘s chief executive for just under five years. But during that time, he earned a good deal less than what other Wall Street chieftains made.

headline: A Little Taste of Time Travel
text: When it comes to our senses, vision and hearing get us through the bulk of our workaday lives, but to reach deeper into our spiritual selves, nothing jogs the memory or jars the soul like smell and taste. And nothing stirs long-forgotten feelings like food, which is why “Culinary Quests,” the globe-trotting culinary experiences in our Food & Drink Issue, is such a remarkable collection of anecdotes. As you read dispatches of delicacies from the far corners of the world, not only does it make you hungry (I gained 40 pounds while copy-editing the thing) but it also transports you back to your own journeys.

headline: Now in New York: Delhi’s Moti Mahal and a ‘Dosateria’
text: Indian restaurant openings in New York City aren’t always newsworthy, but the two new eateries this fall stand out — they’re neither the typical nondescript corner curry joint, nor are they the new breed of Michelin star-aspiring, high-end boîtes.

headline: Michel Richard to Move In to Le Cirque’s Old Home
text: The French chef Michel Richard has announced that he will open a multifaceted restaurant in New York this summer. The restaurant, as yet unnamed, will be installed in the New York Palace hotel, 455 Madison Avenue (50th Street), in the rooms whose landmark interiors were once home to Le Cirque.

headline: Romney Donors Meet to Schmooze . . . and Raise More
text: So just what did Mitt Romney’s high-dollar donors come to the Waldorf-Astoria to do this week?

headline: Lies, Damned Lies, and Jobs
text: Aha. Via Greg Sargent, the Romney campaign is lying about its jobs plan.

headline: Asked & Answered | Swizz Beatz
text: The Grammy-award winning artist and hip-hop producer Swizz Beatz, born Kasseem Dean, is all about “moments,” he says. And he’s had quite a few. His first was in 1998, when he produced a hip-hop ballad for the rapper DMX, entitled “Ruff Ryders Anthem” for his uncles’ label on Def Jam. The track stupefied hip-hop lovers and haters alike with its sitar-looping sound. Then, in 2001, he started his music label Full Surface, which helped start the careers of musicians like Bone Thugs-n-Harmony and Eve. At the time Dean was 23. “When someone goes right, I go left,” he says of his career choices, which brought him next into the world of design with Kidrobot in 2006, and then into fashion four years later when he collaborated on a sneaker line with Reebok. Even the automobile industry came knocking — he became the face of the sports and racing brand Lotus Cars.

headline: After 42 Years, a Lichtenstein Goes Home
text: In 2006 the Roy Lichtenstein Foundation put an image of a lost painting by Lichtenstein, “Electric Cord,” on its holiday greeting card. The foundation used the occasion to ask for help in tracking down the work, and the fruit of that effort was on display on Tuesday when Preet Bharara, United States Attorney in Manhattan, finally returned “Electric Cord,” gone for 42 years, to its owner.

headline: From the White House, Beer We Can Believe In
text: IT may well have been the most famous home-brewing experiment in history. The White House chefs, using a kit bought last year by President Obama, produced their own beer with honey harvested at the White House.

headline: Seldon Seen
text: And now for something completely different (and fun): The Folio Society has just issued a deluxe new edition of Isaac Asimov’s Foundation trilogy. And they picked an unusual person to write the introduction (pdf).

headline: In a Slow Market, Intel Exceeds Lowered Expectations
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel crossed an earnings bar it lowered for itself last month, but the problems plaguing its main market for semiconductors — personal computers — seemed no closer to ending.

headline: The Caucus Click: Spin Room Prep
text: Stephanie Cutter, an Obama campaign spokeswoman, sat for early interviews in the spin room at Hofstra University before the start of the second presidential debate on Tuesday.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct.16
text: A view of the day in sports, including surfing in Indonesia and 2014 World Cup qualifying soccer matches.

headline: Murdoch Hears Critics as His Board Wins Election
text: 8:20 p.m. | Updated For a second year in a row, Rupert Murdoch faced shareholder critics of his News Corporation at the company’s annual meeting. And for a second year in a row their proposals for management changes were shot down.

headline: The Envelope Please: Chandler Buckingham
text: Chandler Buckingham, a student at Rogers High School in Rogers, Ark., warns fellow students to “write everything down!”

headline: Alain Ducasse to Close Adour in New York
text: Alain Ducasse and the St. Regis New York have agreed to terminate their partnership, and Mr. Ducasse plans to close Adour, his five-year-old restaurant there, with the final dinners scheduled for Nov. 17. Mr. Ducasse said that he had been considering this move since the spring, but he would not elaborate on his reasons.

text: 5:08 p.m. | Updated

headline: On Television, Nets Are a Hit
text: The Brooklyn Nets have already set a record: Monday night’s 98-88 victory over the Washington Wizards was the new-look, new-city team’s highest rated preseason game ever on the YES Network.

headline: Happy Birthday, Clean Water Act
text: Thursday, Oct. 18, marks the 40th anniversary of the Clean Water Act, a critical  turning point in the nation’s efforts to rescue its rivers, streams, lakes and wetlands from centuries of industrial, municipal and agricultural pollution. But what should be a moment of celebration is also a moment of apprehension: Republicans in the House have spent the last two years trying to undercut the law, and should they gain control of the White House and Congress in next month’s elections, they could well succeed.

headline: Chevrolet Tries to Spark Curiosity at New York Comic-Con
text: 5:34 p.m. | Updated

headline: Medvedev Calls for Public Smoking Ban in Russia by 2015
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev voiced support on Tuesday for a proposed ban on public smoking by 2015 in Russia, where close to a third of the population smokes.

headline: America, Soccerland
text: That guy up there may just be the best expression of the state of soccer in America right now. I don’t mean Clint Dempsey, who’s being impersonated by the Lego-ish figure. “Deuce” is pretty integral at the moment, to be sure — in fact, tonight, in a qualifying match against Guatemala, he may well be the driving force that keeps the U.S. men’s team on track to make the next World Cup. (We really don’t want to lose this game.)

headline: Sketch Released in Sexual Abuse of 10-Year-Old Inside Queens Library
text: The police released a sketch Tuesday of a man they say sexually abused a 10-year-old girl on Monday inside the Pomonok branch of the Queens Public Library on Jewel Avenue.

headline: I.B.M. Squeezes Out a Profit as Its Revenue Declines
text: I.B.M. delivered a mixed and somewhat unsettling quarterly performance on Tuesday. Profits barely exceeded Wall Street’s expectations, while revenue fell well below.

headline: 7 Manhattan Hotel Rooms for $150, More or Less
text: Can you get a decent hotel room in Manhattan for under $150 a night?

headline: Blanca
text: Inside the 12-seat restaurant located on the grounds of Roberta’s in Bushwick.

headline: Decoding Apple’s Media Invitation
text: It’s game time! No, we’re not talking about the football game, or the baseball game. This is the nerds’ game: an Apple media event.

headline: Alvin Ailey Dance Foundation Names New Executive Director
text: The Alvin Ailey Dance Foundation chose the man in charge of its fund-raising, marketing and public relations to become the next executive director, the foundation said on Tuesday. He is Bennett Rink, who joined Ailey in 1994 as special events manager and rose to become senior director of development and external affairs. Mr. Rink succeeds Sharon Gersten Luckman, who joined the institution in 1992 and became executive director in 1995. She will step down at the beginning of next year. The foundation’s centerpiece is the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater company, and includes a large school and educational programs. Mr. Rink’s appointment will complete a turnover in the foundation’s artistic and executive leadership. Robert Battle succeeded Judith Jamison, the long-time artistic director, last year. Mr. Battle could also be considered an insider, having choreographed many works for the company since 1999.

headline: Hilary Mantel Wins a Second Booker Prize
text: LONDON — The British novelist Hilary Mantel won the 2012 Man Booker Prize on Tuesday night for “Bring Up the Bodies,” the second book in her planned trilogy about the life and machinations of Thomas Cromwell, King Henry VIII’s chief minister and master manipulator.

headline: Instruments From Past Eras, Played for Modern Ears
text: Normally it is not news when an orchestra sounds like, well, an orchestra.

headline: A Tiny Stage Full of Song in Bushwick
text: ACCORDING to this newspaper’s longtime tradition, I had to eat at the Brooklyn restaurant Blanca at least three times before reviewing it. I secured one reservation simply by phoning on the first day of the month, when Blanca opens and then closes its reservation book for the coming weeks. That tactic never worked again.

headline: N.H.L. Offers Players a 50-50 Division of Revenue
text: The N.H.L. made a surprise offer in talks for a new collective bargaining agreement on Tuesday in Toronto, proposing a 50-50 split of hockey-related revenue with the N.H.L. Players’ Association and a mechanism guaranteeing that current contracts would be honored without rollbacks.

headline: Game 3 Highlights and Analysis: Tigers 2, Yankees 1
Beyoncé to Headline Super Bowl Halftime Show
text: The halftime performance at the next Super Bowl, the ultimate star turn for pop divas, will go to Beyoncé, the National Football League confirmed on Twitter on Tuesday. The official announcement came after The Associated Press reported earlier in the day that Beyoncé, the Houston-born R&B singer, was this season’s pick for the job.

headline: The Adelson Phenomenon Spreads Among Donors
text: There is more than one Sheldon Adelson-type donor in the world of “super PACs,” according to new filings with the Federal Election Commission.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ivory Coast and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ivory Coast, Pakistan, France and Brazil

headline: Home-Schooling, Comic Con Style (Part 1)
text: Ask your average Comic Con vendor if he’s got any educational titles, and prepare to be met with the rather-too-swift assertion that his cyborg-superheroes and rotting zombies “promote literacy.” Mmm. Actually, what my 12-year-old home-schooled son and I were in the market for was something closer to the “Epic Battles of the Civil War” series we picked up at the New York Historical Society. I was surprised to learn it was published by Marvel Entertainment, something that failed to spark any recognition or even interest in those working Marvel’s huge Javits Center booth last Sunday. In their defense, it was the final day of a well-attended convention, and the cacophony of the surrounding video game demo stations rivaled that of the Kid’s Day throng. Surely that’s why they treated me like the nun who blundered into a porn shop, in search of Holy Host. I mean, it’s not as if  I was wearing a nun costume … or any costume, for that matter.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Holy Motors'

headline: Deal Is Reached on Placement of Donors’ Names at a Roosevelt Monument

headline: Fête Accompli | All Heart

headline: Intersection: Hip-Hop and Hipster Styles Converge in Bed-Stuy
text: Lance Darrell, also known as Lance Fresh, decided early in his life that he would never blindly follow trends. Mr. Darrell, 26, a native of Bedford Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, said that for years Jordan’s, team jerseys and pretty much whatever Jay-Z wore dominated the direction of street style in Bed-Stuy. His closet was not without those items, but Mr. Darrell was known to mix it up, so much so that his peers often called him out in school for style choices. As the years passed his look continued to evolve, much like the neighborhood.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Holy Motors’
text: In “Holy Motors,” the latest film from the French director Leos Carax, a man is chauffeured around the streets of Paris in a limousine while taking on different roles. Denis Lavant plays the shape-shifting character and, in this scene, he encounters a woman from his past, played by Kylie Minogue. Above, Mr. Carax discusses the scene’s location and how he came to cast Ms. Minogue in his film.

headline: Sit Back, Relax and Turn the Page
text: THE phrase “literary salon” has a whole new meaning.

headline: Predebate Scenes From the Postdebate Spin Room
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. – Four hours before the candidates step on the stage at Hofstra University here, the cavernous spin room is already crackling with narratives and counternarratives – most about how pugilistic President Obama is likely to be.

headline: The Truth That Was Obscured After Protesters Were Killed
text: Sociopolitical themes are invariably woven into the fabric of the great contemporary Irish dramatist Brian Friel’s works, but few are as direct in their focus as “The Freedom of the City,” which is being given a trenchant revival at the Irish Repertory Theater.

headline: World Cup Qualifying: U.S. 3, Guatemala 1
text: The United States can advance to the final round of Concacaf World Cup qualifying with a win or a tie against Guatemala on Tuesday night in Kansas City, Kan (7 p.m., ESPN2). A loss could complicate things a bit, if Jamaica posts a big win over Antigua and Barbuda, and that is naturally what the glass-is-half-full crowd has focused on since Friday’s lackluster, last-minute win at Antigua.

headline: With Bare Feet, Bringing Gods and Beasts to Life
text: When an aging performer returns after an absence of several years, the question naturally arises, “Has he still got it?” Such was the case on Saturday, when the Indian dancer Pandit Birju Maharaj appeared at Symphony Space (courtesy of the World Music Institute) in his first New York performance since 2008. Mr. Maharaj is nearly 75, but moments after he walked onstage, his age seemed irrelevant.

headline: Excerpt: 'Falling'
text: Daniel Everidge, Julia Murney and Celia Howard in a scene from Deanna Jent’s drama about an 18-year-old boy with autism.

headline: A Family Dynamic Dictated by Autism
text: The Martin family in Deanna Jent’s “Falling” tries to lead a normal life: the father, Bill (Daniel Pearce), would like more time alone with his wife, Tami (Julia Murney); their teenage daughter, Lisa (Jacey Powers), wants to adopt a dog; Bill’s mother, the Bible-toting Grammy Sue (Celia Howard), is coming to visit for a few days. Their suburban home (convincingly conjured by the set designer, John C. Stark) reflects their seemingly mundane affairs. But everyone’s schedule (and patience) is strained by the 18-year-old Josh (Daniel Everidge), who is severely autistic.

headline: Who Knows What Evil Lurks in the Hellish Sanitarium?
text: “American Horror Story” starts over again on Wednesday night, with 17 Emmy nominations in the bank for its first season last year on FX. That it won only two awards — for hairstyling and for Jessica Lange’s supporting performance as the psycho granny of the Antichrist — can be taken as a sign that people thought there was something there but weren’t sure what it was.

headline: It’s Not About the Destination, but About the Dizzying Ride
text: “Holy Motors,” from the French filmmaker Leos Carax, is a dream of the movies that looks like a movie of dreams. It is a reverie that begins, appropriately, with a seated audience waiting in the dark (like us) and then cuts to a dimly lighted room, where a man (Mr. Carax) rises from a bed that he shares with a dog. He lets the sleeping dog lie (no need for trouble just yet) and creeps over to a mysterious door hidden in a wall. With a strange metal key that’s apparently grafted to one of his fingers, he unlocks the door and — like Little Nemo tumbling into Slumberland, Dorothy crossing over the rainbow and Alice falling down the rabbit hole — leaves one world for another.

headline: When Sure Proof Proves to Be Unsure
text: The world is flat. The Sun revolves around the Earth. Yes, today’s certainty is tomorrow’s oops, a realization that is particularly alarming when applied to criminal investigation techniques, as it is in “Forensics on Trial,” Wednesday night’s episode of “Nova” on PBS.

headline: With an Eye to Digital, Music Publishing Agency Appoints a New Chief
text: The Harry Fox Agency, one of the main licensing clearinghouses of the music publishing business, has appointed a new chief executive, in a move that may signal a push into new forms of business as traditional revenue sources diminish.

headline: Romney Campaign Makes $12 Million Ad Buy
text: The Romney campaign, flush with cash from its impressive haul of $170 million last month, is reserving large quantities of airtime for the coming week.

headline: Sad Songs, at Their Wit’s End
text: The breezy, smart cabaret duo Eric Comstock and Barbara Fasano are not the first performers who come to mind when you think of heavy-duty ballads steeped in mystery, seduction and obsession. Mr. Comstock is a conversational pop-jazz pianist and singer with impeccable enunciation who observes lyrics from afar and savors their wordplay, but is too fastidious to roll around in emotional mud.

headline: Bin Laden’s Driver
text: The story of Salim Hamdan, a Yemeni man who worked as a driver for Osama bin Laden and today won a significant court battle, is the story of how little President George W. Bush cared about the rule of law.

headline: Reading to Drinkers and Drinking to Books
text: Until Kara Newman, author of “The Secret Financial Life of Food,” invited me to participate in tonight’s drink.think event, I didn’t know that there was a New York City reading series entirely devoted to writing about drink. Further proof that this is a great town. I look forward to reading with a gaggle of my fellow drinkcentric writers.

headline: For the Crowded Masses, a Push to Provide More Escape Patches
text: MUMBAI, India — Not far from where Anusaya Nair lives, a room that measures barely 5 feet by 5 feet, is her main escape: a 9,200-square-foot park, boxed on three sides by a ramshackle garage, tenement housing and an apartment complex. A few women take their evening stroll on the walking track circling the park; elderly companions exchange gossip on a handful of scattered benches; neighborhood children play on a swing set at the back.

headline: Even at Home, All Their World’s a Stage
text: Partly reverent, mostly sendup, “Just 45 Minutes From Broadway” depicts theater folk as those lovably quirky people who can’t stop performing in life, for better or worse. This film might be perfect for a preteen acting camp, or anyone whose eyes have that glowing, cultlike spark of the stage-obsessed.

headline: After 15 Years, a Roadside Performer Is Getting the Spotlight
text: Before social media made it easier to reach an audience, Otis Houston Jr. had already figured out a way to catch the attention of thousands of people every day.

headline: Economic Health? It’s Relative
text: With financial markets careening around the world, in January 2009 a newly inaugurated President Obama acknowledged he had to fix the problem pretty fast. “If I don’t have this done in three years,” he told NBC’s Matt Lauer, “then there’s gonna be a one-term proposition.”

headline: Just the Thing for Those Who Have It All
text: SO you’ve earned it. Now, how to spend it? We have a few ideas. These products may be in the fantasy realm. But, as the interior designer Miles Redd says, sometimes luxe pleasures and products can have outsized effects. “When great wealth is attached to creativity, what it can render can be extraordinary,” said Mr. Redd, the author of “The Big Book of Chic.” Unusual, for sure. — STEPHANIE CLIFFORD

headline: A Guiding Hand for Bequests, Beyond the Grave
text: THERE is a QTIP that is not for people with delicate cleaning problems. It is for those with a very different problem — the delightful problem of expecting to leave substantial assets to heirs.

headline: In Demanding Homes, Help in High Demand
text: DELORES BETHELMIE seemed perfect to work as a nanny for the 1 percent.

headline: High Returns and a Tax Break in One Investment
text: WITH payouts on conventional investments miserly and tax increases looming on Jan. 1, financial advisers are talking up an alternative investment that offers much greater income and tax breaks: master limited partnerships, or M.L.P.’s.

headline: The Best Seats in the House, or Maybe Ballpark
text: AS a boy in Tennessee, F. Perkins Hixon said he “grew up listening to recordings of Maria Callas.” So after he moved to New York, he subscribed to box seats at the Metropolitan Opera, gradually upgrading to the top class, a parterre center box of eight seats, at more than $16,400 a season.

headline: Courting the Next Generation of the Rich
text: ON most weekday afternoons, Jason Franklin is frenetically busy in his crowded office on West 38th Street in Manhattan, fielding calls or pushing projects forward as the executive director of Bolder Giving, a nonprofit organization that promotes philanthropy.

headline: A Private Office on the Highway
text: AS the favored car customizer for many moguls and movie stars, Howard Becker fields plenty of unusual requests from exacting clients.

headline: Off the Beaten Track and Away From the Crowd
text: MORE wealthy travelers are skipping packaged tours and choosing tailored trip itineraries that fit individual interests, needs, schedules — and even whims.

headline: Parceling Out a Nest Egg, Without Emptying It
text: MANY people nearing the end of their working lives may have resigned themselves to cutting back in retirement. But for the affluent and the wealthy getting on in years, this is a time to figure out how much to spend so that they neither run out of money before they die or leave too much to their children when they’re gone. For the affluent, say, those who have accumulated a nest egg of $500,000 to $5 million, maybe even $10 million, the calculation is stark: how much should they budget to spend each year when they could live another 20, 30, perhaps 40 years?

headline: Financial Survival in a Time of Fiscal Peril
text: BETWEEN now and the end of the year, investors who are paying even the slightest bit of attention to the news will hear the term “fiscal cliff” repeated so often that it will surely either strike fear into their hearts or numb them to possible risks ahead.

headline: Falling Prey to the Dangerous Temptation to Cherry-Pick Polls
text: This post appears in Wednesday’s paper. It is a revised version of a post that was published online Monday. The full version is here.

headline: Time, Pen and Paper, and Now the Ear of the Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — Kim Millbrook, an inmate at a federal prison in Pennsylvania, has 31 years of hard time on his hands. He has been using it to sue people.

headline: Gritty Koreatown Block Turns Hot With a Taste of Home
text: When Ja-Bun Kwak opened Kang Suh, her two-level, 24-hour restaurant almost 30 years ago at the base of 1250 Broadway, at 32nd Street in Manhattan, there was just a spare handful of Korean businesses on the block catering to the Korean garment industry and import-export laborers.

headline: Las Vegas Project Survives a Case of Bad Timing
text: LAS VEGAS — An $8.5 billion city within a city called CityCenter Las Vegas — built in this gambling town’s heyday but opened after the recession had set in — continues to struggle, though it is benefiting from growing numbers of visitors to the area.

headline: Second Presidential Debate Fact-Checks and Updates
text: President Obama and Mitt Romney square off on Tuesday night in Hempstead, N.Y., for the second of three presidential debates. Live coverage begins at 8 p.m. Eastern. The Times will be providing updates and analysis on our live dashboard. You can also follow along on Twitter @thecaucus, or follow our list of Times journalists covering the debate.

headline: Trial Run
text: Richly hued matte lips graced many a model on the fall runways earlier this year, and now several beauty brands have introduced intensely pigmented liquid lipsticks. These bold shades have a lip-gloss-style wet application but dry within seconds into a velvety, glamorous-looking finish. They’re meant to be long lasting and moisturizing at the same time, with only one coat. We put three new collections to the test.

headline: Michael Namer
text: Mr. Namer, 58, is a founder and a principal of Alfa Development/Management, a New York company that specializes in residential and hospitality developments. Its projects include Chelsea Green and 151 Wooster Street, and it will soon begin construction on the Mott Hotel in NoLIta.

headline: Despite Its Problems, Dodd-Frank Is Better Than the Alternatives
text: Repeal Dodd-Frank? It sounds so simple. But repealing the Dodd-Frank Act won’t end “too big to fail” banks, and it may even make things worse.

headline: High-Speed Trading Executives Shut Firm
text: A high-frequency trading firm founded less than two years ago by former Citigroup executives is ending operations as the industry confronts a slowdown.

headline: N.Y.U. Law Plans Overhaul of Students’ Third Year
text: There is an old saying that in the first year of law school they scare you to death; in the second year, they work you to death; and in the third year, they bore you to death.

headline: After a Bullet in the Head, Assaults on a Pakistani Schoolgirl’s Character Follow
text: Last Updated | Wednesday, 5:26 p.m. As a Pakistani schoolgirl who was shot in the head by Taliban militants last week fights for her life in a British hospital, a battle to tarnish her reputation is being waged on social networks and news sites in Pakistan.

headline: Daughter of Mexican Drug Lord Detained in California, U.S. Says
text: MEXICO CITY — A daughter of Mexico’s most-wanted drug lord is in custody in the United States after she tried to cross the border illegally into California to give birth in Los Angeles, an American law enforcement official said Tuesday.

headline: China: Committee May Strip Bo of Immunity
text: Xinhua, the Chinese state news agency, has reported that the standing committee of the National People’s Congress was scheduled to meet for four days next week “to review a report on the qualifications of certain national delegates,” which analysts say could mean stripping Bo Xilai, the senior politician, of his congress membership and immunity from prosecution. The review announced by Xinhua on Monday is to begin on Oct. 23; Mr. Bo was expelled from the party last month and is expected to stand trial on a wide range of criminal charges. Mr. Bo is a delegate to the congress, which gives him immunity from prosecution. A cancellation of his membership would pave the way for an indictment and a trial. Earlier, Wang Lijun, the former police chief of Chongqing and an associate of Mr. Bo, had his congress membership canceled before he was put on trial. Mr. Wang received a 15-year prison sentence in September for various crimes, including defection.

headline: Georgia: Incoming Premier Favors Joining Russia Olympics
text: The incoming prime minister, Bidzina Ivanishvili, said Tuesday that Georgia should participate in the 2014 Winter Olympics in the Russian resort of Sochi. President Mikheil Saaakshvili, whose party was soundly defeated by Mr. Ivanishvili’s coalition in this month’s parliamentary elections, has said he planned to boycott the games as an act of protest against Russia, whose troops have controlled two Georgian enclaves since a brief war in 2008. Mr. Ivanishvili promised, as part of his campaign, that he would work to improve relations with Russia, but he has also said he does not plan to abandon his predecessor’s course toward integrating Georgia into NATO, and indicated his warmth toward America by saying his first foreign trip will be to Washington.

headline: John Hoffman, a Force in Energy Efficiency, Dies at 62
text: John Hoffman, who helped shape an international treaty in the 1980s to protect the ozone layer and later developed  the Energy Star program, a widely recognized government stamp of approval for energy-efficient products, died on Sept. 24 in Washington. He was 62.

headline: New Jersey Sports Betting Law Spurs Move by N.C.A.A.
text: The N.C.A.A. is planning to relocate six championships from New Jersey, blaming a new state law there allowing sports betting on collegiate and professional games.

headline: California: Money Found for Move of Duroville Residents
text: Riverside County and state officials reached a deal this week for the state to release $10 million to complete the court-ordered relocation of residents of a squalid trailer park on tribal land, known as Duroville, to a new housing development. The move had been in jeopardy because the state eliminated the agency that was financing the plan.

headline: An Unlikely Cheddar Is Suddenly Boastful
text: STEVEN JENKINS, author of “Cheese Primer,” was visiting his mother on the coast of Alabama recently when he discovered a package of Cracker Barrel Cheddar in her refrigerator.

headline: Murdoch Hears Critics as His Board Wins Election
text: For a second year in a row, Rupert Murdoch faced shareholder critics of his News Corporation at the company’s annual meeting. And for a second year in a row their proposals for management changes were shot down.

headline: Dismissal of Gun Suit Is Sought
text: The Justice Department has asked a federal court to dismiss a lawsuit by the House oversight committee seeking to compel the Obama administration to release more internal records involving the botched gun-trafficking case known as Operation Fast and Furious. The judiciary should play no role in a dispute like this one between the executive and legislative branches, the department said in a brief filed Monday night in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. In this case, the White House has asserted executive privilege over its internal deliberations, and the House of Representatives has voted to hold Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. in contempt for refusing to comply with the committee’s demands.

headline: Cholesterol Is Falling in Adults, Study Finds
text: Cholesterol levels in adults are falling, and changes in the amount of trans fats in the American diet may be part of the reason, new research suggests.

headline: Will Privacy Go to the Dogs?
text: New Haven

headline: Filling Seats Is Challenge for Yankees
text: On the heels of a playoff weekend in which the Yankees played in front of thousands of empty seats in the Bronx, the team now appears concerned that it will be unable to sell out next weekend, either, if the Yankees do make it to Games 6 and 7 of the American League Championship Series.

headline: Baggage Handler Who Smuggled Cocaine in Planes Is Sentenced to Life
text: An airline baggage handler who was convicted of trafficking millions of dollars’ worth of drugs in the bellies of commercial jets was sentenced to life in prison on Tuesday, putting an emphatic stamp on a case that revealed rampant theft and corruption by some airline employees.

headline: Ryan and the Catholic View of Abortion
text: To the Editor:

headline: Public Health, and the Role of Government
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pregnant Workers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Protests on Easter Island
text: To the Editor:

headline: Presidential Debate, Take Two
text: With three weeks until Election Day, President Obama and Mitt Romney squared off in a tense town-hall style debate.

headline: Before a Nun Is Sainted, Honoring Her Upstate Past
text: UTICA, N.Y. — But for a wooden sign at its edge, the vacant field resembled any other in a neighborhood of factories and worn-out buildings here, not far from the Erie Canal: a few trees scattered across thick green grass, a patch of shaggy weeds growing beside a boarded-up garage at its rear.

headline: Which Changed First, the Polls or the Markets?
text: While Wall Street has thrown the bulk of its donations behind Mitt Romney, it is not viewing his potential ascent as an entirely good thing for the markets.

headline: Venezuela’s Opposition Struggles for Unity
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Ramón Guillermo Aveledo has been something of chief herder of cats for Venezuela’s political opposition, cajoling, arm-twisting and pleading to keep a contentious gaggle of parties all across the political spectrum from going their separate ways.

headline: Taxi-Hailing App Pulls Out of New York After 6 Weeks
text: Six weeks after its debut inside yellow cabs roiled New York’s taxi industry, a cab-hailing app company said Tuesday that it would shut down the service, citing “obstacles and roadblocks” placed before it by the city.

headline: Reid Cuts Losses While He Still Can
text: It was just a few days after training camps had opened, and Andy Reid was noticeably jovial and relaxed. He was starting his 14th season as Philadelphia’s coach — 14 years, he said at one point for emphasis, maybe with a touch of wonder — and was convinced that the team that jelled at the end of last season had carried over its momentum into this one.

headline: Investors Hope for Clarity, Quickly
text: As Michael L. Corbat takes up the reins at Citigroup, analysts and investors have a message for him: Shrink your bank fast, and be a lot more transparent as you do so.

headline: Share Your Reactions to the Second Presidential Debate
text: Mitt Romney and Barack Obama meet tonight in the second presidential debate of 2012. The town-hall style debate, moderated by CNN’s Candy Crowley, features questions from uncommitted voters selected by Gallup. Do you think swing voters will be persuaded by either candidate tonight? Have they persuaded you?

headline: Debating Points: Obama vs. Romney, Round Two
text: The editors of Campaign Stops asked contributors to weigh in with their early reactions to the second presidential debate. Tune in here for regular updates.

headline: Yankees Shake Things Up, but Don’t Call It Panic
text: DETROIT — All season long, when one of his players struggled at the plate, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi would defend his decision to stick with him, insisting the player would come around because he always did in the past.

headline: New Planet in Neighborhood, Astronomically Speaking
text: Bringing the search for another Earth about as close as it will ever get, a team of European astronomers was scheduled to announce on Wednesday that it had found a planet the same mass as Earth’s in Alpha Centauri, a triple star system that is the Sun’s closest neighbor, only 4.4 light-years away.

headline: In the Hard Fall of a Favorite Son, a Reminder of a City’s Scars
text: ELYRIA, Ohio

headline: The Never-Ending Conversation
text: Ike Maxwell was Elyria's high school football hero in the 1971 season. Now, at 59, he walks the town a troubled and damaged man, a reminder of glory and regret and of the vexing subject of race.

headline: Alex Leighton, The Drum Major
text: “Everybody has their own thing. And they’re all traditions that just kind of got passed on. I mean, I can’t tell you how old some of them are because I’m sure they outdate a lot of us.”

headline: Members of Brooklyn Motorcycle Gangs Arrested on Weapons Charges
text: During the secret meetings at their clubhouse in Brooklyn, the members of an outlaw motorcycle gang, the Forbidden Ones, secured themselves with assault rifles, pistols and even grenades to protect themselves from intruders, the authorities said. But their first — and most imposing — line of defense was a cannon, at the ready with .50-caliber rounds, aimed at the door should anyone dare to infiltrate their ranks.

headline: Driving to Detroit for a First Date With the Tigers’ Park
text: Road trip, thy name is trepidation.

headline: Investigators Visit Company Tied to Meningitis Cases
text: Criminal investigators from the Food and Drug Administration were at the New England Compounding Center in Framingham, Mass., on Tuesday, officials said, in the first public indication that the federal government was preparing a case against the company linked to a deadly meningitis outbreak.

headline: Talks on Euro Zone Approach, This Time Under Calmer Conditions
text: PARIS — The steam has gone out of the euro crisis for now, but many of the deeper structural problems of the euro zone remain, and several changes meant to address them will be the subject of the next European Union summit meeting in Brussels on Thursday and Friday.

headline: Full Transcript of the Second Presidential Debate
text: The following is a transcript of President Obama and Mitt Romney’s remarks at the second presidential debate in Hempstead, N.Y. on Oct. 16, 2012. (Transcript courtesy of Federal News Service)

headline: Maker of Batteries Files for Bankruptcy
text: DETROIT — The troubled battery maker A123 Systems filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday, dealing a blow to the Obama administration’s program to jump-start a domestic battery industry and spur development of electric vehicles.

headline: Obama and Romney on the Auto Industry
text: President Obama and Mitt Romney questioned each other's approach toward the bailout of the United States automotive industry.

headline: How to Score the Debate
text: I had to write this column before the presidential debate was finished, so I thought the most useful thing I could do is to offer the scoring system I’ll be using to determine who did best. You can fill in your own scores. My system is not based on zingers or extra points for energizing the base, but rather on what I believe many Americans really want from the next president. You see, I believe this time is different — that many Americans understand something is very wrong, that we could go the way of Greece or Japan if we don’t shape up, and that they will embrace a candidate who trusts them with the truth, that is, an honest diagnosis of where we are and how we get out of this mess. Up to now, neither candidate has been willing to do that.

headline: Armored Vehicles That Save Lives
text: Providing the best armored vehicles to protect our troops fighting in wars abroad is a moral imperative. Still, there has been argument among analysts over the high cost of mine-resistant ambush protected vehicles, or MRAPs.

headline: Politics and the Courts
text: The winner of the presidential election will have scores of federal judgeships to fill and the chance to shape the courts — even aside from potential Supreme Court vacancies should one or more of the current justices retire.

headline: The Exclusive Eight
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York City was distressingly dismissive this month when a coalition of civil rights groups filed a complaint with the United States Department of Education over the admissions policies of the city’s eight “specialized” high schools — prestigious, highly competitive institutions that are among the best high schools in the country.

headline: No ‘Thomas Crown Affair’
text: Boston

headline: Obama and Romney on U.S. Energy Policy
text: President Obama and Mitt Romney challenged each other on how their respective energy policies would help lower the cost of gas.

headline: In New Ad, Romney Stresses Moderate Positions on Reproductive Issues
text: Mitt Romney’s campaign, in an effort to appeal to women who hold more moderate views on reproductive issues, is releasing a new commercial that highlights his support for contraception and abortion in limited circumstances.

headline: Obama Attacks Romney on Tax Policy
text: President Obama challenged Mitt Romney’s approach toward tax cuts.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Symbol of October Struggles
text: Detroit

headline: Home Loans From Washington?
text: Should the government consider cutting out the middleman, as it does with student loans, and issue mortgages itself?

headline: Trademark of 1899 That’s No Longer Protected
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — As the weather gets colder, there is nothing better than a nice, hot bowl of soup, and at first while solving Peter Koetters’s puzzle, I thought we were in for a nice meal (or gardening experience, as Mr. Koetters explains later.) As it turns out, there is math involved. I didn’t see that one coming at all.

headline: Corrections: October 17, 2012
text: NATIONAL

headline: Playwright Presented as Poet
text: Though he’s wearing a precisely tailored black suit, Julian Sands is on occasion about as naked as an actor can be in “A Celebration of Harold Pinter,” the one-man show that opened on Tuesday night at the Irish Repertory Theater, directed by John Malkovich. That happens whenever Mr. Sands has no part to play except Julian Sands, the handsome sometime British movie star and our host for the evening.

headline: Oracle Boat Being Tested for America’s Cup Capsizes
text: The America’s Cup defender Oracle Team USA sustained a devastating blow Tuesday when its 72-foot carbon fiber catamaran flipped over and broke to pieces in the churning waters of San Francisco Bay.

headline: A Mixed Performance
text: Even though the United States economy has fared relatively well compared with that of some other countries after the financial crisis, employment here has been lagging.

headline: Romney on How He Is Different From Bush
text: Mitt Romney tried to change the subject when presented with a question on how his policies were different from those of George W. Bush.

headline: A.L.C.S. Game 3: Yankees vs. Tigers
text: The Yankees-Tigers series switched to Detroit after the Tigers won the first two games in the Bronx.

headline: Rivals Bring Bare Fists to Rematch
text: President Obama and Mitt Romney engaged Tuesday in one of the most intensive clashes in a televised presidential debate, with tensions between them spilling out in interruptions, personal rebukes and accusations of lying as they parried over the last four years under Mr. Obama and what the next four would look like under a President Romney.

headline: Romney Addresses Economy’s Last 4 Years
text: Mitt Romney answered a voter’s question and described President Obama’s failures on the economy during the past four years.

headline: First Plaintiffs Testify in Federal Challenge to Police Stop-and-Frisk Policy
text: Charles E. Bradley stood outside his fiancée’s fifth-floor apartment at about 5 p.m., the agreed-upon time, and began drumming on the door, he testified Tuesday, re-creating the sound in Federal District Court in Manhattan, his knuckles rat-a-tatting on the witness stand. She did not respond, he said, and so after waiting a moment — she is deaf in one ear — he left.

headline: Excerpts of Wiretaps in Liu Case Are Released
text: “How much are we short?” the fund-raiser asked the New York City official.

headline: Whose Pension Is Bigger?
text: In a back and forth exchange, President Obama gave a quick reply on the size of pensions in answering a question from Mitt Romney.

headline: Confident U.S. Swaggers Past Guatemala in Qualifier
text: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — Around and around the energetic Americans went, slicing apart the Guatemalan resistance and tearing to shreds the notion that they might gun for anything but a victory Tuesday night.

headline: Obama and Romney on Attack in Libya
text: President Obama and Mitt Romney challenged each other on the Obama administration’s response to the attacks in Libya.

headline: ‘Rebecca’ Producer Explains How Trust Betrayed His Dream of Manderley
text: Broadway survives on the suspension of disbelief: Actors lose themselves in roles, audiences accept characters singing in mid-pratfall, and investors put millions of dollars into shows knowing that few ever turn a profit.

headline: A Town Abuzz Over Prostitution and a Client List
text: KENNEBUNK, Me. — The summer people who clog the roads here are long gone and the leaves have turned crimson and orange, but the prevailing sentiment in this postcard-perfect coastal town these days is one of dread.

headline: Obama Brings Up Romney’s Change on Guns
text: President Obama answered a question about gun control and brought up Mitt Romney’s change on an assault weapons ban.

headline: Bell Sounds on Lifetime Spent in the Ring
text: LAS VEGAS — As the referee Joe Cortez lifted Saul Alvarez’s right hand as the winner of his junior-middleweight title bout against Josesito Lopez, Cortez was surprised to have his other hand hoisted in the air by Oscar De La Hoya, a former champion who is now a promoter. Alvarez then placed the champion’s belt around the referee’s waist. In front of a capacity crowd here at MGM Grand Garden Arena, De La Hoya leaned toward Cortez and told him, “You’re the champion.” “It was very touching,” Cortez, 69, said. “I will treasure it forever. When do you see a championship fighter say this to a ref?”

headline: Attack Ads, by Outside Groups With Murky Ties, Shape 3 New York Senate Races
text: In Westchester County, a television advertisement accused a Democrat running for the State Senate of using campaign money to treat himself to fancy dinners. In Rochester, a commercial branded a Republican candidate as anti-women. And in Queens, a mailer attacked a Democratic incumbent for providing taxpayer money to a nonprofit organization that facilitates parrot adoptions.

headline: Romney on Operation Fast and Furious

headline: IDs for Illegal Immigrants Take a Step in Los Angeles

Then, this month, the police chief announced that the department would stop handing illegal immigrants charged with low-level offenses over to federal authorities for deportation.

headline: Raoul De Keyser, Intuitive Abstract Painter, Dies at 82

headline: FIAC, Next Stop on the Art-Fair Go-Round
text: PARIS—Art is popping up all over Paris on the eve of the opulent International Contemporary Art Fair known as FIAC, which runs Thursday through Sunday in Paris. The 1900 Grand Palais becomes a giant art emporium designed to attract contemporary art collectors, museum curators and international dealers. This year the 182 participating galleries include a lineup of major and rising French and international names, including Gagosian, Thaddeus Ropac, Marian Goodman, Matthew Marks, Emmanuel Perrotin, White Cube and Bugada & Cargnel.

headline: Obama’s Narrow Victory
text: Just by showing up energized, by hemming and hawing less often and by going after Mitt Romney more directly, President Obama ensured himself a better showing than the disaster he endured in Denver two weeks ago. But the narrow win he gained in the second presidential debate also owed something to Romney’s performance, which, though highly effective in stretches, also showcased more of his flaws, both as a debater and as a candidate.

headline: Which Open Spaces Should Mumbai Protect?
text: MUMBAI–In Mumbai, a metropolis teeming with more than 13 million people, activists and ordinary citizens alike lament the dearth of places to get a simple breath of fresh air.  A new study demonstrates just how scarce open space is: a mere 6 percent of the city is reserved for it, and of that area, approximately 60 percent is neither developed nor accessible to the public.

headline: Liberty or Debt

Capital, a subsidiary of the investment firm Elliot Capital Management, a judge in Ghana has barred the Argentine Navy’s training frigate, A.R.A. Libertad, from leaving the eastern port of Tema since Oct. 2. The fund, run by the billionaire Paul Singer, seeks payment from Argentina’s record debt default a decade ago and is demanding $20 million to let the 100-meter-long vessel go — a fraction of the more than $1.6 billion it is owed according to U.S. courts.

headline: The Jade War
text: MYITKYINA, Myanmar — This is the road to the treasure — the pot-holed road that leads to Hpakant, a town in northern Myanmar famous for producing the best quality jade in the world. But if just three months ago it was lined with cars loaded with jade hunters, today it is mostly empty.

headline: Social Change’s Age of Enlightenment
text: One of the benefits of writing a column about solutions is that it offers an alternative lens through which to view the world. This week is the second anniversary of Fixes. Much of my time over the past few years has been spent talking to people about the creative responses to social problems that are emerging across the country and around the globe. It turns out there’s no shortage of these stories. I’m often struck by how much ingenuity is out there and being directed to repair the world, and how little we hear about it.

headline: The Pressure Is On at Citigroup
text: PRESSURE IS ON AT CITI  |  The new chief executive of Citigroup, Michael L. Corbat, “may have to impress quickly, given the pent-up frustrations among shareholders,” DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. With the stock price having fallen 89 percent under Mr. Corbat’s predecessor, Vikram S. Pandit, investors want the new leader to speed up the bank’s overhaul and be more transparent about the process. But it was not clear on Tuesday what his actual plan was. “Today’s changes do not alter the strategic direction of Citi, which we believe is a good one,” Mr. Corbat said during his first public conference call as chief executive. Still, he suggested the personnel change itself signaled change: “I wouldn’t minimize the impact you can have on a place.”

headline: Breakfast Meeting: A Moderator’s Lot Is Not a Happy One
text: You can’t please everyone, and that is never more true than when you are moderating a presidential debate. Candy Crowley of CNN discovered that on Tuesday night when she served as master of ceremonies for Round II between President Obama and Mitt Romney. Ms. Crowley tried, mostly unsuccessfully, to keep the candidates within the guidelines of the debate’s format, and was criticized by conservative commentators for seeming to favor President Obama, especially when she fact-checked an assertion Mr. Romney made about Mr. Obama’s handling of the attack in Libya last month.

headline: Armstrong Is Dropped by Nike and Steps Down as Foundation Chairman
text: His career as a competitive athlete already in shambles from a doping scandal, Lance Armstrong fell further from grace Wednesday. He announced he was stepping down as the chairman of Livestrong, his cancer foundation, and Nike, the sports brand most closely associated with his racing days, was among several companies severing ties with him.

headline: Cambodia, Mourning, Casts an Eye to the Future
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Mourners packed the roadsides here on Wednesday to witness the final return of Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian king and a pivotal figure through much of the country’s troubled recent history.

headline: Daily Report: I.B.M.’s Somewhat Unsettling Quarterly Performance
text: I.B.M., as the world’s largest supplier of information technology to corporations and governments, is closely watched as a gauge of technology spending trends. It delivered a mixed and somewhat unsettling quarterly performance on Tuesday. Profit in its third quarter barely exceeded Wall Street’s expectations, while revenue fell well below.

headline: Debate Moves Women to Fore in Race for the White House
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama charged that Mitt Romney’s policies are economically threatening to women, as the candidates in their second presidential debate on Tuesday night clashed repeatedly over who would best serve the interests of the country’s largest and most critical constituency.

headline: Bank of England Is Divided on More Stimulus Measures to Counter Weak Growth
text: LONDON — Policy makers at the Bank of England are divided over the future of their multibillion-pound program of bond purchases to stimulate the economy, according to minutes of their discussions released on Wednesday, suggesting that prospects for an expansion of the program in the near term may be fading.

headline: Home-Schooling, Comic Con Style (Part 2)
text: As noted yesterday, my 12-year-old home-schooled son and I braved the crowds at the New York Comic Con last Sunday, looking for any materials that might qualify as educational. Also, a Minecraft pickaxe, which we found. The hunt yielded far more than I was expecting. Modest as our takeaway may be when compared with the number of clammy-handed men and boys of the geeky persuasion yearning after buxom Manga goddesses in the flesh, I think we did all right for ourselves.

headline: T Exclusive Video | Wild Belle’s ‘Backslider’
text: Once the brother-sister duo Wild Belle — Elliot Bergman plays saxophone and keyboards; Natalie (Belle) Bergman sings — starts making noise, it’s easy to understand why Alexa Chung handpicked them to play parties for cool fashion labels like Mulberry and, most recently, Maje. The Bergmans have a funky island twang backed up nicely by jazz and African music influences.

headline: Ownership of Blue Bottle Coffee Changes Hands
text: Blue Bottle Coffee, the respected California coffee micro-roaster that introduced the Japanese-style siphon bar to San Francisco before opening shops in Chelsea, TriBeCa, Rockefeller Center and Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has a new owner.

headline: Adam Gopnik vs. Paul Ryan
text: Last week’s vice presidential debate ceased to matter at about 8:59 PM last night, but before it disappears from our memories entirely I should say something about one of the stranger reactions that the Biden-Ryan showdown provoked: A peculiar mini-tirade from the New Yorker’s Adam Gopnik about Paul Ryan’s putatively theocratic tendencies. Gopnik is a wonderful writer, one of the finest prose stylists on the New Yorker’s long roster of such talents, and he’s also the author of a number of non-terrible, agnostic-but-sympathetic essays about religion, which is more than can be said for certain of his peers. But time and partisanship happeneth to all men, and something in the combination of Ryan’s fairly anodyne comment about how “our faith informs us in everything we do” and the Republican VP nominee’s description of seeing his daughter as an embryo via ultrasound inspired Gopnik to hyperventilate as follows:

headline: Multivitamin Use Linked to Lowered Cancer Risk
text: After a series of conflicting reports about whether vitamin pills can stave off chronic disease, researchers announced on Wednesday that a large clinical trial of nearly 15,000 older male doctors followed for more than a decade found that those taking a daily multivitamin experienced 8 percent fewer cancers than the subjects taking dummy pills.

headline: Yankees Enter the Panic Room

From the United States men’s team initially falling behind, 1-0, to that great soccer power Guatemala and risking a humiliating ouster from World Cup qualifying to Eagles Coach Andy Reid throwing his defensive coordinator overboard midseason when it is his offense that should have been fitted for scuba gear to the current headquarters of desperation: the Yankees dugout.

This was community gardening, and it was a workout.
