headline: Cuomo’s Medicaid Changes Are at Washington’s Mercy
text: Depending on who is doing the talking these days, New York State is either a national model of how to curb Medicaid spending, or the nation’s prime example of Medicaid abuse.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Town’s Passion for Football, a Retired Doctor’s Concern
text: DOVER, N.H. — The agenda for the Oct. 1 school board meeting did not call for anything particularly exciting. But during a segment called “Matters of Interest,” Paul Butler, a retired doctor and relative newcomer to the board, floated an idea: end the football program at Dover High School.

headline: U.S. Disavows Patent at Center of Apple-Samsung Dispute
text: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has decided that one of the smartphone patents at the center of the legal dispute between Apple and Samsung Electronics — which resulted in a jury award to Apple of $1.05 billion — should never have been granted.

headline: Simple but Local, Queens Slots Are Hurting Gambling Meccas
text: A casino that opened a year ago at the fading Aqueduct horse racing track in Queens has emerged as the country’s highest-grossing slot parlor, helping to reshape the gambling landscape in the Northeast as patrons chose less opulent, more local casinos instead of traditional gambling meccas in Atlantic City and Connecticut.

headline: Sterility Found Lacking at Drug Site in Outbreak
text: BOSTON — The compounding pharmacy blamed for a deadly national meningitis outbreak repeatedly failed to follow standard procedures to keep its facility clean and its products sterile, Massachusetts officials said Tuesday, painting a harrowing picture of a company that flouted crucial rules as it hurried to ship drugs around the country.

text: For a moment it looked as if Mitt Romney’s chances of becoming the next president were up, way up.

headline: Tigers vs. Giants Was a Century in the Making
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The last time the Detroit Tigers won the World Series, in 1984, the final out nestled in the glove of their left fielder, Larry Herndon, who caught a pop fly from San Diego’s Tony Gwynn. Herndon gave the ball to the Tigers’ closer, Willie Hernandez, but wears his championship ring every day.

headline: Your Mom Just Died. Let’s Go to Disney World.
text: “Mothers are dead in fairy tales,” snaps Gil, the snap-happy protagonist of “Wild With Happy,” a sweet, funny and forgivably sentimental new play written by and starring Colman Domingo. Gil’s mother is dead too, but his life is no fairy tale. At 40 he’s still recovering from a breakup with a boyfriend, he’s all but given up on his career as an actor, and he’s the sourpuss spreading gloom at Disney World.

headline: Their Bodies Breaking, They Still Can Dance
text: The body in extreme states — of power, of virtuosity, of distress — is a potent, politically charged metaphor in hip-hop. Though the culture has long since become a worldwide pop phenomenon, its South Bronx roots are inextricably bound with histories of resistance, struggle and celebration.

headline: Small-Town Americans, Street by Street to Eternity
text: Somewhere between the snug burg of Thornton Wilder’s “Our Town” and the wine-dark seas of Homer’s “Odyssey” lies the brave new world where Richard Maxwell has set up camp. In “Neutral Hero,” the remarkable new play that opened on Tuesday night at the Kitchen, Mr. Maxwell is hunting for the epic in the Everyday.

text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I got the theme of Ian Livengood’s puzzle before I got the payoff at 37 Across, which was confusing for me. text: At work in Cairo during the early 1980s, Steve Hindy found himself drinking beer that had been brewed at home by other American expatriates. They had picked up the skill living in parts of the Middle East where alcohol was banned. It was pretty good, and Mr. Hindy learned to make it himself when he and his family moved back to New York in 1984. Their old neighborhood on the Upper West Side of Manhattan had gotten too expensive, so they found a two-bedroom apartment in a part of the city that a family with young children could afford. It was Park Slope.

headline: China: Tibetan Advocates Report Self-Immolation

Tibetan activist groups contend that the Chinese government represses the Tibetan people and denies them religious freedom, allegations that Beijing officials strongly deny. The self-immolations this week followed dozens of others by Tibetans since 2009.

headline: Sanctuary for Abused Bears in Vietnam Is Facing Eviction
text: HONG KONG — Animals in the wild in Vietnam and China don’t have a lot going for them. Their habitats are being steadily demolished as cities and human populations expand. And all manner of animal organs and body parts are still prized in traditional medicines — tiger penis, deer musk and antlers, snake blood and hearts, bear bile and paws. Elephants in Vietnam have been hunted so aggressively for their ivory that only a few dozen remain.

headline: A Conversation With: Polio Expert Naveen Thacker

The country will be certified “polio-free” in January 2014 by the World Health Organization if no new cases are reported between now and then, and has already been removed from a list of countries with “active transmission of wild poliovirus.”

headline: The Island Where People Forget to Die
text: In 1943, a Greek war veteran named Stamatis Moraitis came to the United States for treatment of a combat-mangled arm. He’d survived a gunshot wound, escaped to Turkey and eventually talked his way onto the Queen Elizabeth, then serving as a troopship, to cross the Atlantic. Moraitis settled in Port Jefferson, N.Y., an enclave of countrymen from his native island, Ikaria. He quickly landed a job doing manual labor. Later, he moved to Boynton Beach, Fla. Along the way, Moraitis married a Greek-American woman, had three children and bought a three-bedroom house and a 1951 Chevrolet.

headline: Heart of Brass
text: Carl Auböck has a venerable history and more than 4,500 products to its name, yet the century-old Viennese design company remains relatively obscure. “It always struck me as strange that people in design who seem to know everything about everything don’t know anything about this,” says Brian Janusiak of Project No. 8, who worked with the Austrian photographer Clemens Kois on “Carl Auböck: The Workshop,” out this month from powerHouse Books. Even those who have made a sport of hunting for Auböck’s signature brass hands and bookends may be surprised to learn that since 1912, the company has been led by four Carl Auböcks, one of whom palled around with Walter Gropius. Or that their wares encompass a staggering range of typologies, from paperweights to oddities like sculptural pipe racks, cookie holders and paintbrush stands. As Kois points out, after World War II “we weren’t allowed to be loud. No one realized we were making such cool things.”

headline: The Family Doctor, Minus the M.D.
text: The Family Health Clinic of Carroll County, in Delphi, Ind., and its smaller sibling about 40 minutes away in Monon provide full-service health care for about 10,000 people a year, most of them farmers or employees of the local pork production plant. About half the patients are Hispanic but there are also many German Baptist Brethren. Most of the patients are uninsured, and pay according to their income — the vast majority paying the $20 minimum charge for an appointment. About 30 percent are on Medicaid. The clinics, which are part of Purdue University’s School of Nursing, offer family care, pediatrics, mental health and pregnancy care. Many patients come in for chronic problems: obesity, diabetes, hypertension, depression, alcoholism.

headline: For Whom Golden Parachutes Shine
text: Golden parachutes, those packages that reward top executives if their company is acquired, have attracted much attention from investors and public officials for more than two decades. Defenders of golden parachutes believe that they provide executives with incentives to facilitate a sale of their companies. While the evidence confirms this, it indicates that golden parachutes have significant costs as well and might fail to serve the interests of shareholders over all.

headline: Human-Size Meals to Satisfy ‘Hobbit’ Hungers
text: When your hobbit-hole has been used as a stomping ground by 13 unruly dwarves and an enigmatic wizard, and your weeks of wild adventures with them have introduced you to goblins, trolls, elves, wargs, Gollum and a sinister dragon, what you need next is a big breakfast. For those fans of J. R. R. Tolkien’s fantasy novel “The Hobbit” — whose appetites have been whetted by months of promotion for Peter Jackson’s coming film adaptation but cannot wait for the Dec. 14 release date of the first movie (of three) — the restaurant chain Denny’s has stepped in to fill the void with a promotional menu offering food that they may or may not really have been eaten in Middle-earth. “Is it nice, my precious? Is it juicy? Is it scrumptiously crunchable?” Well, according to the science-fiction and pop-culture Web site io9.com, this special Denny’s menu features authentic items like Bilbo’s Berry Smoothie; Gandalf’s Gobble Melt (a turkey sandwich); Radagast’s Red Velvet Pancake Puppies; and the Ring Burger (topped with what appear to be three onion rings to rule them all). Now, one does not simply walk into Denny’s and order these “Hobbit”-related foodstuffs — at least not until Nov. 6, when participating restaurants will start offering them.

headline: Under One Picasso, Another
text: Picasso was just 22 through most of 1904, the year he is thought to have painted “Woman Ironing,” a haunting image in muted tones of blue and gray of a skeletal woman, her eyes hollow, her cheeks sunken, pressing down on an iron with all her might. Money was tight for him. He was living in Paris, and he would often start a painting, abandon it and begin another using the same canvas, a practice he continued throughout his career.

headline: Art in Residence
text: Undulating and forbidding, Oscar Niemeyer’s 1966 Edifício Copan in the heart of downtown São Paulo is one of the largest residential buildings in the world. It is home to thousands of people, about 70 businesses, and, as of September, a contemporary art center, Pivô. “The space was abandoned for the last 20 years,” says the artist Fernanda Brenner, who founded Pivô with a small team that includes the art historian Marta Ramos  and the producer Tyaga Sa Brito. The labyrinthine layout, pieced together from a former storage space, a dental clinic and a storefront, may have made the location a hard sell, but at 38,000 square feet, it is an interesting place to display artwork. For the first round of shows, Pivô enlisted two local galleries and an independent curator to present projects that largely respond to or intervene with the architecture of the site. “Pivô is dedicated to process and experimentation rather than to finished products,” Brenner says, “and to promoting a dialogue between contemporary art and its place in the city.”

headline: The Burden of Justice: Louise Erdrich Talks About ‘The Round House’
text: Louise Erdrich’s 14th novel, “The Round House,” was recently named a finalist for the National Book Award. It’s set on the North Dakota Ojibwe reservation that is so familiar to her readers, and it tells the story of Joe, a 13-year-old who seeks justice after his mother is brutally attacked. In her review, Michiko Kakutani wrote that the novel “opens out to become a detective story and a coming-of-age story, a story about how Joe is initiated into the sadnesses and disillusionments of grown-up life and the somber realities of his people’s history.” In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Erdrich discussed the difficulty of obtaining justice on reservations, the influence of her father on her fiction and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: American Ballet Theater Signs On for Three Years at the David H. Koch Theater
text: American Ballet Theater, which presents a spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House, will have a second Lincoln Center home starting next fall. The company announced yesterday that it would move its fall season from New York City Center to the David H. Koch Theater, also home to New York City Ballet. The move is part of a three-year agreement under which the company will present two weeks of performances at the theater every fall through 2015. The first season, which includes 12 performances, runs from Oct. 30 to Nov. 10, 2013. The move was hinted at in May.

headline: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
text: The Sonderbund, a gathering of young German artists and art lovers, organized its third and last exhibition in Cologne in 1912, of more than 600 paintings and sculptures by 173 artists from the post-Impressionist and German Expressionist movements. Now, at the Wallraf-Richartz Museum & Fondation Corboud in that city, an exhibition called “1912 — Mission Moderne: The Centennial Retrospective of the Sonderbund Exhibition,” has 100 of the works from that 1912 show on display, including Vincent van Gogh’s 1890 painting “Die Grabenden,” shown here. Through Dec. 30.

text: The right to eat junk for lunch, or let’s get vending machines out of schools.

headline: How Bill Clinton May Have Hurt the Obama Campaign
text: When the histories of the 2012 campaign are written, much will be made of Bill Clinton’s re-emergence. His convention speech may well have marked the finest moment of President Obama’s re-election campaign, and his ads on the president’s behalf were memorable.

headline: Shifting Mood May End Blank Check for U.S. Security Efforts
text: WASHINGTON — Last week, a Bangladeshi student was charged in an F.B.I. sting operation with plotting to blow up the Federal Reserve Bank in New York. A Somali-American man was convicted of sending young recruits from Minneapolis to a terrorist group in Somalia. In Libya, extremists responsible for the killing of four Americans last month in Benghazi remained at large.

headline: Mile 16: Where Runners Go Up, Up and Away
text: Funny thing, this marathon. We try to do everything right — the long runs, the speed workouts, the stretching – yet nothing fully braces us for the physical punishment and emotional test of race day.

headline: For Older Parents, Expert Advice About Financial Aid
text: A financial aid expert is revisiting Booming on Wednesday to answer financial aid questions from older parents.

headline: An Unspoken Risk of Vaginal Birth
text: As a writer, I’m not timid about women’s bodies. I’ve covered teen sex, vibrators, and transvaginal ultrasounds, but vaginal tears are different. It’s not a phrase that rolls easily off the tongue or out of the keyboard. Unlike many child-related topics, there is a strange moratorium on discussing the complications of vaginal births. Coverage of birth injuries are often buried under studies about the escalating rates of C-sections and the “too posh to push” women fueling them, as well as more “progressive” reports suggesting that if only women relaxed better, oiled better, breathed better, all births would be just grand.

headline: Space Out: Modeling the Solar System
text: Overview | Space is enormous. How can we conceptualize the vast distances between objects in our solar system and beyond? In this lesson, students calculate the relative distances between planets in our solar system, build a model illustrating those distances to scale and compare the model with standard solar system illustrations. Note to teachers: Be prepared to extend this model throughout the school and the school grounds.

headline: Apple Takes On Smaller Tablets
text: TimesCast Media+Tech: Apple reveals the iPad Mini. | David Pogue reviews the Microsoft Surface in 60 seconds. | The Mr. GIF artist collective.

headline: Recent Spinal Shots May Pose Greatest Meningitis Risk
text: The more recently a patient received a spinal injection with the contaminated steroid implicated in a nationwide outbreak of fungal meningitis, the higher the risk of developing the disease, federal health officials are reporting.

headline: Insights Into the Koala’s Genetic Challenge
text: Scientists have long been aware that Australia’s beloved koala suffers from low genetic diversity. The assumption has been that this genetic flat line is relatively new, a result of the 19th-century fur trade, which nearly decimated the koala population before the species rebounded. But a study published this week in the journal BMC Genetics suggests that this low diversity predated the fur trade, meaning that whatever thinned the genetic soup may have occurred much further into the past.

headline: What Obama Said About Immigration in His Off-the-Record Interview
text: Curious about what President Obama might say when he believes he is off the record and can therefore afford to be “very blunt?”

headline: TimesCast Media + Tech: Apple’s Smaller Tablets
text: Apple reveals the iPad Mini. David Pogue reviews the Microsoft Surface in 60 seconds. The Mr. GIF artist collective.

headline: For Regular Guys, a Look of Combat
text: WATCHING the fanfare that follows any new product announcement from Apple, like the one on Tuesday that included a smaller version of the iPad, the thought occurs that fashion designers are not doing enough to foster innovation in their field. People just don’t seem to get as excited about a new pair of pants as they do a faster computer processor.

headline: Fed Pledges to Maintain  Stimulus
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve said Wednesday that it would continue its economic stimulus campaign, aimed at reducing unemployment, amid fresh evidence of a housing recovery that could help to bolster those efforts.

headline: The Third-Party Debate
text: Few voters realized there was another presidential debate on Tuesday. Even fewer watched it. The biggest “name” there wasn’t a politician, but the moderator, Larry King, who called the candidates “Don Quixotes.”

headline: Warriors Choosing a Path to Relevance: Offense or Defense?
text: Whether it be jumping from the doldrums to playoff relevance, or from there to true contention, making a true leap in the N.B.A. requires that most everything go right. It’s a delicate balancing act to achieve it and at least temporarily maintain it.

headline: Another Notch in His Belt at Coach
text: TAKE a deep breath at the rail yards on the West Side of Manhattan. If you don’t smell leather, you’re not thinking like Reed Krakoff.

headline: Past Forward: Paul Ryan’s Love of Cheese, Organics and the Green Bay Packers
text: Looking back at a Q. and A. with Ryan in 2010, it would seem that food and football come up a lot when you’re hanging out with the Wisconsin congressman.

headline: Memorial to Roma Holocaust Victims Opens in Berlin
text: BERLIN — Germany paid tribute on Wednesday to the hundreds of thousands of Romany people killed in the Holocaust, opening a long-awaited place of remembrance for a minority still plagued by discrimination.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: Russian Opposition Figure Says Abductors Threatened His Children
text: MOSCOW — A jailed Russian opposition leader who disappeared from Kiev, Ukraine, on Friday was held for three days by men who threatened to kill his children if he did not sign a lengthy confession, according to an interview published on Wednesday.

headline: College Prices, Once Stable, Are Reportedly Up Again
text: The college prices that most students actually pay are going up again, after having been stable for several years, according to a report from the College Board.

headline: Ai Weiwei Covers ‘Gangnam Style’ Video
text: Last Updated | Thursday, 12:54 p.m. As my colleagues Jeff DelViscio and Shreeya Sinha reported last month, “Gangnam Style,” a music video by a South Korean rapper known as PSY with more than 530 million views on YouTube, has been “remixed and redone by motivated fans” around the globe. On Wednesday, Ai Weiwei, the Chinese dissident and artist, joined in, uploading his own cover version of the rap video to YouTube.

headline: Social Neckwork
text: Climate change and shifting population patterns are not typically fashion fodder — which makes two new scarf collections all the more intriguing. For the latest Sportmax Carte Blanche collaboration, the creative consultant and Design Miami and Design Miami/Basel co-founder Ambra Medda tapped the illustrator Ying Wu, a Royal College of Art graduate whose work she discovered at the most recent Salone del Mobile in Milan. Wu’s silk foulards comment on the unforeseen side effects of unbridled economic growth, a phenomenon that the Chinese-born artist has experienced firsthand and frequently alludes to in her work. With their poster-art palette and Maurice Sendak-ish animal imagery, Wu’s scarves are highly decorative. But if you look closer, says Medda, “you start to realize that there is a whole other dimension that brings you back to a starker reality.” The limited-edition collection will be available at the Sportmax flagship store in Milan in January.

headline: Taylor Swift and Nicki Minaj to Perform at American Music Awards
text: Taylor Swift, Nicki Minaj and the band Linkin Park will be the featured performers at the American Music Awards next month, organizers announced on Wednesday. All three acts are also nominated.

headline: Jason Aldean Tops Billboard Album Chart
text: The country singer Jason Aldean has reached the top of the Billboard chart for the first time with his new album, “Night Train” (Broken Bow), which sold 409,000 copies in its first week out, according to the tracking service Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘Halloween’ Returns
text: Austin Hinderliter saw his first “Halloween” movie when he was just 6. “My parents didn’t really crack down on that too much,” he observed.

headline: 36 Hours in New Haven, Conn.
text: IT wasn’t long ago that New Haven was the poster child for the troubled college town, a place where the graduates of prep schools rubbed shoulders with the trauma of the mid-’80s and early-’90s crack epidemic. While New Haven’s hard luck reputation lingers, it’s no longer fully deserved. The city’s historic center, which fans out around twin lawns planted with towering elms, maintains an old New England character, with neo-Gothic towers, well-aged dive bars and working-class neighborhoods of faded but elegant Victorian houses. While town and gown have worked to attract brand-name businesses to downtown (among them a new Apple Store and Shake Shack), New Haven remains complex and layered — a city of taco trucks and barbecue shacks as well as high-end clothiers and stylish cocktail lounges.

headline: Illinois Debt Takes Toll, Study Finds
text: For years, Illinois has racked up billions in public debt to plug budget holes, pay overdue bills, and put money into its mismanaged pension funds. And for the people who live there, this has resulted in decrepit commuter trains and buses, thousands of unsound bridges, 200 hazardous dams and one of the most inequitable public school systems in America.

headline: Taking Back Her Tweets
text: POOR Lena Dunham. Whether the 24-year-old creator of HBO’s “Girls” is posting a photo of herself wearing a Muslim veil or cracking jokes, she can’t catch a break on Twitter. She deleted the offending tweets, but that hasn’t stopped others from judging.

headline: New Sentence Is Imposed in Bomb Plot From 1999
text: SEATTLE — A terrorism case that predated the 9/11 attacks, but then became bound up by courts wrestling with the altered post-9/11 landscape of threat and deterrence, was back before a federal judge here on Wednesday. And the judge tried, for a third time, to impose a prison sentence that would stick.

headline: Keeping Cash on Hand, Just in Case
text: Earlier this year, I joked in a post that interest rates were so low on savings accounts that it might make sense to store cash under your mattress — or at least somewhere safe in your home.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Book Thief'
text: Mark Ulrich and Rae Gray in a scene from Heidi Stillman’s stage adaptation of Markus Zusak’s novel set in Germany during World War II.

headline: Smithsonian to Auction Artifacts from H.H. Richardson House
text: The 19th-century Boston architect Henry Hobson Richardson’s only major surviving work in Washington, D.C., a turreted 1888 townhouse designed for the farm machinery tycoon Benjamin H. Warder, has survived numerous demolition threats. Now chunks of it are coming on the market.

headline: Posed to Turn Up the Volume
text: EVERY generation gets the shock art it deserves. Today’s version is on display in a renovated garage on Crosby Street, just south of Houston.

headline: Tom Cruise Sues Tabloids Over Claims He Abandoned His Daughter
text: 5:39 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES—You can pan his movies, write about his love life or question his involvement with Scientology. But you’d better have the goods if you’re going to call Tom Cruise a bad dad.

headline: Buckyball Comes to Madison Square Park
text: Madison Square Park Conservancy’s Mad. Sq. Art program announces a new, monumental sculpture by world-renowned artist Leo Villareal.

headline: Stone Links: Beauty in Our Time
text: Kant set the terms of modern aesthetics. In his hands, the field became centered on the study of aesthetic judgment, in particular, judgments of the beautiful and the sublime. But if it’s plausible to think that each era’s aesthetic judgments take on more particularized forms, what might the defining aesthetic categories of our age be? This is Sianne Ngai’s question in her new book, “Our Aesthetic Categories,” reviewed by Rebecca Ariel Porte at LARB. Her tripartite answer: the zany, the cute and — most interesting — the interesting.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Oct. 25
text: The combination of shoe, sandal and boot is among the latest trends in footwear; Ace & Jig’s cotton blanket coat will travel effortlessly; and other retail news.

headline: First Look: ‘Buckyball’ in Madison Square Park
text: The artist Leo Villareal is installing a 30-foot tall, illuminated sculpture, titled “Buckyball,” in Madison Square Park. The piece, inspired by the work of Buckminster Fuller, is made up of 180 LED tubes arranged in a series of geometric shapes — the lights are designed to emit a variety of colors and dynamic sequences. “Buckyball” will make its official debut on Thursday and will be on display until Feb. 1.

headline: The All-Star Center Is Officially Extinct
text: The notion of an All-Star center is officially defunct — at least on the ballots that determine N.B.A. All-Stars.

headline: Cocktail Bodega
text: WHILE Cocktail Bodega is not the first bar to open at 11 a.m., it might be the first where the drink menu calls for it. This is not a spot for martinis, or for sparklers and tiki huts. It is, plainly, a juice and smoothie place where you can get whiskey with your flaxseed.

headline: J.D. Power: Consumers Increase Their Use of Smartphones in Car Shopping
text: Consumers’ reliance on their smartphones to obtain information about new cars is growing, according to the 2012 Automotive Mobile Site Study, released Tuesday by J.D. Power and Associates, the market research company.

headline: Even Beauty Items Face the Aging Process
text: SHOULD beauty products be stamped with expiration dates like cartons of milk, indicating how long they will last before turning?

headline: Lawmakers Rated on Food and Farm Policy Votes
text: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress are used to having their votes graded. Dozens of interest groups, from the National Rifle Association to the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, keep score, grading lawmakers on how they vote on issues ranging from gun control to legislation that would repeal laws that make marijuana use illegal.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: Plus One? Ask Carefully

text: 9:37 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Final Frenzy
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa – The “48-hour fly-around campaign marathon extravaganza,” as President Obama called it, began today with his crowd-pleasing “Romnesia” routine and familiar pledges of more teachers and bridges.

headline: In Pomerania, a Modern-Day Manor
text: A seven-bedroom property near Gdansk, built in 2011 to resemble a traditional Polish manor, is on the market for $2.5 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Poland
text: A CONTEMPORARY MANOR HOUSE NEAR GDANSK IN POMERANIA

headline: Obama’s Aura of Defeat
text: In an argument that was echoed and amplified around the liberal twittersphere yesterday, New York’s Jonathan Chait made the case that the Romney campaign has bluffed the press into covering the last two weeks of the campaign as though Obama’s losing. Like George W. Bush in 2000, who famously (and probably foolishly) campaigned in California to lend himself an air of inevitability in the closing days of the campaign, Team Romney’s current brash confidence is designed to persuade the media to overlook the underlying numbers that still point to an advantage for the incumbent. And it’s working, Chait argues: The “widespread perception that Romney is pulling ahead,” he writes, “is Romney’s campaign suckering the press corps with a confidence game.”

headline: Beauty Spots
text: Eye shadow is often overlooked as a way to freshen a tired face. Toss one of these new palettes into your bag for a quick autumn pick-me-up.

headline: An Energy Extravaganza
text: The special Energy section of The Times explores how the marketplace, Middle East politics and other factors are pushing President Obama and Mitt Romney to take some similar stances on the nation’s energy future.

headline: After All, the Islanders Will Still Be on an Island
text: John Donne wrote that no man is an island. Two of New York City’s boroughs are (Manhattan and Staten Island), but not Brooklyn. So why would a hockey team called the Islanders keep its name when it moves there from an arena in Uniondale?

headline: A Popular Twist on Putting Hair in Its Place
text: SOME Americans travel to Tokyo for omakase sushi or karaoke. But three years ago, a few members of the Goody marketing department went there for, according to the company, “inspiration.”

headline: Champions League: Matchday 3(B)
text: With games on Matchday 3(A) of the group stage of the UEFA Champions League on Tuesday, we continue a new featurette in which we hope to bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals of the day, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: Simon Keenlyside in 'The Tempest'
text: Simon Keenlyside as Prospero in Thomas Adès’s “The Tempest” at the Metropolitan Opera.

text: Properties in Minneapolis, New Orleans and on Lake Tahoe.

text: MINNEAPOLIS

headline: Not Just Another Pretty Face
text: One of the four versions of “The Scream” made by Munch, which brought nearly $120 million at Sotheby’s in May, will be on view at the Museum of Modern Art, courtesy of its new mystery owner, for six months.

headline: Zynga, Survival at Stake, Beats Forecasts
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Zynga is putting all its chips on a game called survival.

headline: Obama Reminds Supporters About the 2000 Election
text: President Obama and his advisers are fond of reminding people just how close this election will be. Now they are putting those words into a new ad that reminds voters how the country could have taken a much different turn in 2000 had more of Al Gore’s supporters turned up at the polls.

headline: Tax Policy Center in Spotlight for Its Romney Study
text: WASHINGTON — A small nonpartisan research center operated by professed “geeks” has found itself at the center of a rancorous $5 trillion debate between President Obama and Mitt Romney.

headline: Seeking Love? Find Strength in Numbers
text: THE young, single women flocked to a dimly lighted wine bar in TriBeCa in their skinny jeans and stylish dresses. They were writers, lawyers and advertising types, among others, who were gathering for a most unusual how-to session, a primer of sorts on how to find love in the millennial age.

headline: The Get | Frends’s ‘Taylor’ Headphones
text: “I was standing in an electronics store when it dawned on me that almost every device for sale required headphones,” says Keir Dillon, the former pro snowboarder and winter sports announcer who co-founded Frends, a fly men’s audiowear line. “Then I looked around and realized that at least half of the people in the store were women buying smartphones and tablets, and that not one single headphone on the headphone wall was refined or stylish. Nothing exuded luxury or hinted at grace.” It was then that Dillon, who started Frends in Encinitas, Calif., with a group of fellow snowboarders in 2006, turned his focus to designing the “Taylor,” a cushy headset made of white lambskin and supersoft synthetic leather, finished with polished, gold-colored hardware. Named after the blues singer Koko Taylor, it is one of the brand’s three new women’s styles. (The other two get their names from music greats as well; the “Ella” earbuds go out to Ms. Fitzgerald, and the “Layla” set is for the Eric Clapton song.) All will be available at Apple stores starting on Oct. 30. Says Dillon of the design process: “We discovered techniques that were being used in other categories, like jewelry, and once we started thinking along those lines the possibilities became limitless.” We hear that.

headline: Treacherous Mother Nature, Out to Get Us All
text: WHEN the villain of a horror film is an ax-wielding maniac, the doomed victims can at least beg for mercy. Reasoning with Freddy Krueger may not get you very far, but you can pray he has a conscience somewhere. What makes eco-horror films — from the 1954 sci-fi classic “Them!” to Steven Soderbergh’s 2011 thriller “Contagion”  — so terrifying is that the enemy is Mother Nature herself, and she is invariably merciless.

headline: Cambodian Contemporary Arts to Be Showcased in New York Festival
text: By the time the genocidal Khmer Rouge regime finished filling the killing fields in Cambodia in the 1970s, more than 90 percent of the country’s artists and intellectuals had been wiped out. In recent years, Cambodia’s artistic community has slowly been rebuilding itself, and this coming spring some of the results will be on display in New York City at the Season of Cambodia festival. This gathering of more than 125 artists, performers and scholars will present Cambodian film, dance, visual art, shadow puppetry and more at venues all around the city, including the Guggenheim Museum, the Asia Society and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The celebration is being hosted by Cambodian Living Arts, a nonprofit group based in Phnom Penh that was founded in 1998 by Arn Chorn-Pond, who survived the mass killings as a child and eventually came to the United States. “When I first returned to Cambodia in the ’90s after the Paris peace accord, my friends and I were finding master teachers living on the streets — poor, weak, without food and basic health care,” said Mr. Chorn-Pond, whose work in rescuing these artists was detailed in the PBS documentary “The Flute Player.” The festival will run from April 6 through May 31, 2013.

headline: A War of Words, Focused on One
text: In his new book about America’s most controversial dictionary, David Skinner refers to the lexicographer Noah Webster Jr.’s belief that a common language could keep the nation politically and culturally united. “If the Civil War had not proven him wrong,” Mr. Skinner writes, “the controversy over Webster’s Third certainly would have given him second thoughts.”

headline: Video: Tebow Is More Branding Than Scoring
text: Tim Tebow could be the Jets’ missing ingredient, but for now he’s just another brand name, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Tim Tebow: More Branding Than Scoring
text: Tim Tebow could be the Jets’ missing ingredient, but for now all he is is another brand name, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Some characters in this month’s crop of new novels find love where others have looked before — on a city street, in the arms of a fan. Others strike out for new territory: A mom falls for fast food, a kid pines for an exotic animal, and a woman is devoted to her arms-dealer boss.

headline: Gallerists to the People
text: ABOUT 90 minutes into a high-speed scouting expedition through the artists’ studios of Gowanus, Brooklyn, Alex Tryon paused. In a small subdivided studio taking part in an annual event known as the Gowanus Open Studios Tour, her eye fixed on some acrylic paintings of neon-colored plastic squirt guns. They had a weird presence, cheery but menacing.

headline: New Laws Add a Divisive Component to Breast Screening
text: In a move that has irked medical groups and delighted patient advocates, states have begun passing laws requiring clinics that perform mammograms to tell patients whether they have something that many women have never even heard of: dense breast tissue.

headline: Oct. 23: The Virtues and Vices of Election Prediction Markets
text: Tuesday featured what, on the surface, would seem to be a fairly neutral day of polling. Of the 11 national polls published on Tuesday, five showed President Obama ahead, four gave a lead to Mitt Romney and two had a tied race. On average among the polls, Mr. Romney led by 0.3 percentage points, the same as his average margin in the previous edition of the same polls.

headline: The Caucus Click: Going Separate Ways
text: Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan spoke on the tarmac in Denver before leaving on separate campaign planes on Wednesday morning. Mr. Ryan left for Ohio, and Mr. Romney’s next stop was in Nevada.

headline: Offering Page Turners to the Design Crowd
text: Last year, Steven Kroeter started Designers & Books, a Web site that asks design industry notables to share the titles that have inspired them. “On the one hand you can go to TED and spend four days and whatever that costs,” Mr. Kroeter said. Or you can “get a book list from people you really respect and read.”

headline: The Better to Hear You With
text: The Ear sofa by the Montreal design firm St Ely for Lerival is a clean-lined, contemporary sectional piece with a twist — or, more specifically, a set of folds. The top corners of each modular piece tilt inward, creating a backrest that supports different seating positions. “You can change your angle when you’re talking with someone,” said Hubert Pelletier, an architect who runs St Ely with the industrial designer Eugénie Manseau. “It may be subtle, but it also creates a sense of envelopment.”

headline: Our Man in Jaipur
text: “John Robshaw Prints,” published this month by Chronicle Books ($40), is as much a travel memoir as an overview of the textile designer’s career thus far.

headline: Light My Fire
text: Chris Lehrecke is no one’s idea of a dainty designer; he makes furniture with solid presences and prices to match. But now he’s designing in miniature. Speaking of the knobby shapes of his new candlesticks, which come in three styles and a choice of five woods, he noted that “they look reminiscent of other things I’ve done.” (Peppermills were also an inspiration.)

headline: Everything but the Kitchen Sink
text: West Elm opened its first New York store almost 10 years ago and, to the surprise of many, it was in Dumbo, Brooklyn, not Manhattan. The neighborhood was auspicious enough to serve as the site of the West Elm Market, a new venture the company says will give customers a “total home tool kit” for the kitchen, garden, home repair and personal care.

headline: Sales at BoConcepts, Judy Ross Textiles and Others
text: This Saturday, Oct. 27, BoConcepts will offer up to 70 percent off its warehouse goods (the Serena high-back dining chair in black leather, regularly $149, will be $69); 20 Pulaski Street, Bayonne, N.J.; (201) 433-4461.

headline: 2 Convicted in Cabby’s Death Are Freed After a Long Fight
text: More than 17 years after they were imprisoned for a murder they have long said they did not commit, Eric Glisson and Cathy Watkins walked free on Wednesday outside the Bronx County Hall of Justice, prompting an emotional scene there and ending a chapter in what may come to be seen as an extraordinary breakdown in criminal justice.

headline: One Ring, Right Under Your Nose
text: The next time someone says there are no sure things in life, just point to the Big Apple Circus. This company, now in its 35th year, has been consistently inspired, at least since I first saw it some 20 years ago. And its newest offering, “Legendarium,” isn’t about to break that long, superb streak.

headline: Richard Mourdock on God’s Intentions
text: Try as they might to present a centrist image for Mitt Romney’s sake, social issue zealots running on the Republican ticket can’t seem to contain themselves. The latest to articulate his extremism on abortion is Richard Mourdock, a candidate for the U.S. Senate in Indiana who said during a debate Tuesday that “even if life begins in that horrible situation of rape, that is something that God intended to happen.” In the ensuing uproar, Mr. Mourdock was quick to apologize without offering a retraction. But Mr. Romney’s camp was even quicker. They instantly denounced the comment.

headline: In Web Search, Be Efficient in the Terms You Use
text: By this point in the Internet era, everyone should know how to find information on the Web with a search engine like Google or Bing.

headline: A 1940s Brooklyn Team, on Home Ice in Manhattan
text: The Brooklyn Americans, major league hockey’s sole foray into the borough before the announcement on Wednesday of the semi-imminent arrival of the New York Islanders, were many things during their brief existence.

headline: Sensing Saturation, Ohio House Candidate Cancels Advertising Buy
text: Sensing that the target audience has reached its limits, Representative Jim Renacci of Ohio has canceled $850,000 in advertisement reservations for the final days of his campaign for re-election, going dark on network television as one of the most expensive House races draws to a close.

headline: Retrieving the Weather of the Past
text: For many years now, volunteers working from home —people like you&#8212 have been able to help scientists with important problems.

headline: A Mass to Console in Troubled Times Like Haydn’s, Like Ours
text: Haydn’s “Mass for Troubled Times” seems a fitting work for these tense pre-election weeks. Also known as the “Lord Nelson” Mass, Haydn wrote it in 1798 shortly after Horatio Nelson defeated Napoleon at the Battle of the Nile. Haydn composed the work without winds, since Nikolaus II, Prince Esterhazy, his patron, had dismissed the wind players in the court retinue because of financial woes.

headline: Knocking at the Gate of Heaven
text: Who could blame him for wanting to prolong the moment? Yannick Nézet-Séguin, having just concluded a heaven-storming performance of Verdi’s Requiem with the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Westminster Symphonic Choir on Tuesday evening in his Carnegie Hall debut, held the silence long enough for dramatic effect, and longer ... much longer.

headline: Into the Dawn of New Ideas
text: As names for new ballet companies go, Ballet Next is optimistic. Ambiguous too. Does it suggest that here is the next stage for ballet itself? Or simply that this is the next stage for the artists involved?

headline: ‘The Book Thief’ Receives a New Life on the Stage
text: CHICAGO — At home in Sydney, Australia, a few years ago Markus Zusak had a hard time believing anyone would read his forthcoming novel, “The Book Thief.”

headline: In Democratic Stronghold, Ryan Puts Focus on Poverty
text: Extending the Republican ticket’s lean toward the middle, Representative Paul D. Ryan expressed compassion for Americans in poverty and laid out a vision for fixing the broken engine of upward mobility.

headline: Shopping for Doorknobs
text: Gil Schafer, a New York architect who specializes in historical renovations, goes shopping for different kinds of doorknobs that work for different kinds of rooms.

headline: Philharmonic Extends Gilbert’s Reign
text: The New York Philharmonic has extended the contract of its music director, Alan Gilbert, for three years, keeping him at the helm through at least the 2016-17 season, the orchestra said on Wednesday.

headline: Changing Course at a Fork in the Show
text: In the slightly more than 20 years that Chan Marshall has been performing as Cat Power, putting her ruminative, wandering, mostly bridgeless songs in front of various kinds of bands, there have been good and bad nights.

headline: Mediator Resigns in Dallas Tower Dispute
text: The mediator assigned to help resolve a dispute between the Nasher Sculpture Center in Dallas and owners of the nearby Museum Tower, above, resigned on Wednesday. The tower, the center contends, sends excessive light into the Nasher galleries, designed by Renzo Piano, damaging plants in a garden and bothering visitors with glare. The Dallas Morning News reported that the mediator, Tom Luce, resigned via an e-mail to Richard Tettamant, the administrator of the Dallas Police and Fire Pension System, the tower’s owner. “Recent events have made clear that the conditions and spirit under which I agreed to serve to help find a mutually beneficial solution for all parties are not being adhered to by you,” Mr. Luce wrote. “This saddens me, because I believe this is such an important issue for our city as a whole together with the financial future for our wonderful police and fireman. From the sideline I will be hoping this situation can be mutually resolved.” Mr. Luce, who did not return calls seeking comment, was apparently frustrated by what he saw as the pension fund’s violation of an embargo against the parties’ talking publicly about the negotiations.

headline: Doorknobs
text: GIL SCHAFER is a New York architect who specializes in historical renovations and “new houses that look like old houses,” he said. He is also a self-described “hardware nut” who invests a lot of time trying to find just the right hardware to complete each project.

headline: Girardi Addresses His Growing To-Do List
text: As he does after every season, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi took a few days to decompress. He has not yet spoken with Andy Pettitte, who is mulling retirement. Nor has he spoken with Alex Rodriguez, whose postseason deteriorated into a series of embarrassing moments in which he was benched for entire games or withdrawn from the lineup for a pinch-hitter.

headline: Things He Saw: Jason Polan’s Journey Across the North
text: The artist Jason Polan loves road trips. Followers of his weekly online column for The Times, Things I Saw, are already familiar with his whimsical drawings from his excursions around New York and other parts of the country. But now they can see his first collection of photographs when Parts & Labor Books publishes “The Land Can Handle It” later this week.

headline: How Smart Is That Phone? Apps Unveil the Tricks
text: I confess to being one of those “never reads the manual” people, mainly because of impatience. This is true for nearly everything from Ikea furniture to the mystical script in the instructions for my robot vacuum cleaner. For folks like me, the arrival of touch-screen smartphones was a dream because they’re meant to be incredibly easy to use. I can pick one up and understand it instantly.

headline: Shoppers Roam Where Giants Once Did
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A couple of people walked into an Office Depot here last week and asked to use it as part of a scavenger hunt competition. They wanted to know if it would be all right if contestants, indulging their inner Willie Mays, ran into the store and slid on the floor where the Giants’ home plate used to be.

headline: Romney Plans Economic Speech in Iowa
text: Mitt Romney plans to deliver a closing speech framing the economic choice facing voters during a campaign visit to Ames, Iowa, on Friday, a top adviser to Mr. Romney’s presidential campaign said on Wednesday.

headline: Redskins Unimpressed by Giants’ Game-Winning Touchdown
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Most analysts raved about Eli Manning’s late-game prowess after his in-stride 77-yard bomb to Victor Cruz with 1 minute 13 seconds left rallied the Giants to a 27-23 victory over Washington last Sunday. Redskins cornerback DeAngelo Hall does not appear to be as impressed.

headline: Why Are States So Red and Blue?
text: Theories about our right-wing and left-wing mind-sets don’t explain why they are tied to geography.

Former Assistant Principal Penalized for Missing Work to Go to Second Job
text: A former assistant principal at a Brooklyn public school was penalized for leaving work early or not showing up on 32 occasions while she worked a second job, the city’s Conflicts of Interest Board announced on Wednesday.

headline: What Equality Sounds Like
text: DENVER – It went by quickly, but President Obama got a big roar from the crowds at both his rallies today when he mentioned equality for gay people.That used to be the kind of thing that politicians talked about in small settings, not in mass get-out-the-vote gatherings, like the one here in City Park Wednesday afternoon. The usual calculation was that it could alienate more voters than it attracted, so why take the risk? But the calculation has changed for the better.

headline: E-Mails Offer Glimpse at What U.S. Knew in First Hours After Attack in Libya
text: WASHINGTON — A series of three leaked e-mails sent by State Department officials beginning shortly after the fatal attack began on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, last month — including one that alerted the White House Situation Room that a militant group had claimed responsibility for it — stirred new debate on Wednesday about the Obama administration’s shifting positions on the cause of the attack.

headline: Libyan Forces Now Control Restive Town, Officials Say
text: CAIRO — Officials in Libya said on Wednesday that government forces had taken control of the western town of Bani Walid, after a deadly assault that lasted almost a week and led to accusations that the country’s new government was using indiscriminate force to punish a restive city.

headline: Iran Reports Arresting 50 on Money Trading Violations
text: Fifty people in Iran have been arrested on money trading violations since a crackdown on foreign-exchange dealings linked to the plunging value of Iran’s currency provoked a riot and antigovernment demonstration in Tehran three weeks ago, the country’s intelligence minister said Wednesday.

headline: Embedded With the Syrian Army
text: Janine di Giovanni, a Times contributing reporter, gets a rare glimpse at the grinding urban warfare in Homs, Syria.

headline: Amid Cutbacks, Greek Doctors Offer Message to Poor: You Are Not Alone
text: ATHENS — As the head of Greece’s largest oncology department, Dr. Kostas Syrigos thought he had seen everything. But nothing prepared him for Elena, an unemployed woman whose breast cancer had been diagnosed a year before she came to him.

headline: Bleary-Eyed Troops Fight a Building at a Time in Syria
text: HOMS, Syria — For more than 24 hours, President Bashar al-Assad’s soldiers fought their way through this city, bleary-eyed men, worn down by months of combat. Afraid to go into the streets, where snipers pick their targets, the government men snaked their way through “mouse holes” punched in walls of blown-out buildings. Their goal was to retake one building, just one, a former school controlled by the rebel Free Syrian Army.

headline: California: Gunman Sought in Shooting of 5 People
text: Three people were killed and two more injured in a pair of shootings on Wednesday in Downey, south of Los Angeles. Dean Milligan, a Downey police lieutenant, said investigators believed all of the victims were members of the same family. Police responded just after 11 a.m. to a 911 call reporting gunshots at a fire safety business where officers discovered three people who had been shot, two of whom later died. Minutes later, a call was made from a residence where two more people had been shot, one fatally. One of the victims at the residence said the gunman fled in a car owned by the family, Lt. Milligan said. The gunman’s identity was unknown.

headline: Georgia: Prayer Leader Killed During Service
text: A 52-year-old man was arrested on Wednesday in connection with the fatal shooting of a prayer service leader at a suburban Atlanta megachurch. The authorities said the suspect, Floyd Palmer, a former church maintenance worker, opened fire in the chapel on Wednesday morning, killing Greg McDowell, 39. The church, the World Changers Church International in College Park, is led by the Rev. Creflo Dollar, a televangelist, and says it has 30,000 members. Mr. Dollar was not at the church during the shooting and no one else was injured. Mr. Palmer was arrested at a mall in Atlanta five hours later, the United States Marshal’s Service said.

headline: Wall Street Leaders Peer Into Economic Gloom
text: Uncertainty seems to be the reigning theme on Wall Street these days. Just from looking at recent earnings reports, it is clear that executives are contending with a world that is not easy to figure out.

headline: Wilhelm Brasse Dies at 94; Documented Nazis’ Victims
text: There were images of living virtual skeletons; of prisoners standing shoulder-to-shoulder in striped uniforms; of people with deformities; of disemboweled victims of purported medical experiments.

headline: Blogger Facing Sanction Quits Mormon Church
text: A Mormon who edits a Web site critical of his church said he was resigning from the church rather than face a hearing that could lead to his excommunication. The editor, David Twede of the Web site MormonThink, was told in September by his bishop that he was being called to a church trial. Mr. Twede had posted articles on several Web sites criticizing Mormon beliefs and Mitt Romney, who is a Mormon.

headline: League Gives Union the Silent Treatment
text: At the Barclays Center news conference announcing the Islanders’ move to Brooklyn in 2015, Commissioner Gary Bettman was asked whether the league would agree to meet with the Players’ Association after the union offered Tuesday night to resume negotiations.

headline: Court’s Split Decision Provides Little Clarity on Surrogacy
text: Unable to conceive, the New Jersey couple did what an increasing number of 21st-century parents have done: they got an egg from an anonymous donor, and made an agreement with another woman to carry the child for them.

headline: Jeff Blatnick, 55, Dies; Won Olympic Gold in Wrestling
text: Jeff Blatnick, who overcame cancer to win a gold medal for the United States in Greco-Roman wrestling at the 1984 Olympics, died on Wednesday in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 55.

headline: Kentucky’s Egregious Death Penalty
text: The Kentucky Commission on Human Rights voted unanimously last week to recommend that the state abolish the death penalty. There is every reason for Kentucky to take the advice and become the 18th state to prohibit capital punishment.

headline: Betty Binns Fletcher Dies at 89; Liberal Stalwart on the Bench
text: Betty Binns Fletcher, a federal appeals court judge whose liberal record inspired conservative opposition in the Senate when her son was named to serve alongside her on the same Western court, died on Monday in Seattle. She was 89.

headline: F.D.R.’s Vision, Remembered in Stone
text: The upbeat tune identified with President Franklin Delano Roosevelt — “Happy Days Are Here Again” — wafted across the city’s waters at the recent dedication of the stunning F.D.R. memorial honoring his vision of a world founded on four essential freedoms, articulated during World War II. A bell tolled as the four were cited — freedoms of speech and worship and freedoms from want and fear — at the new four-acre park gleaming at the southern tip of Roosevelt Island.

headline: The Money Trail in Illinois
text: The Eighth Congressional District of Illinois, in Chicago’s northwest suburbs, is not the only example of this year’s post-Citizens-United-attack-ad wasteland. But it’s a good one. Representative Joe Walsh, a Republican freshman congressman known for legislation like the Save Christmas Act and for shooting off his mouth, is battling Tammy Duckworth, a Democrat and war veteran, in a race that stands out for its saturating quantities of rancor, negativity and outside cash.

text: Residents of Brooklyn have been called many things over the years: thugs, hopeless nostalgists, heavily accented bigots, and, much more recently, hipsters and arrivistes.

headline: Arrest of Brazil Financier Puts Focus on Small Banks
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazilian authorities have arrested the chief executive of a bank engulfed in an accounting scandal and detained him in prison, a rare step that has focused attention on the weaknesses emerging among an increasing number of small banks there.

headline: Basic Instruction
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Back in the day, kids, I was the very proud owner of an original generation Nintendo GameBoy. I was already an adult when it came out, but it was the coolest thing I had ever seen, so I indulged myself. Now, of course, you can play games on a device that is the size and weight of a postage stamp — bless your young and non-myopic eyes — but in the 1980s, if you were one of the cool kids, you lugged around a gaming device that both resembled and had approximately the same-quality graphics as a beige brick.

text: On the day he elevated Garth Snow from backup goaltender to general manager in 2006, Charles B. Wang, the Islanders’ owner, conceded that the move was unorthodox but said that much of his business career had been based on doing things differently.

text: ALBANY — The state capital has seen its share of drinking over the years. But rarely has the imbibing had such an imprimatur as on Wednesday, when Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo held a summit meeting devoted to alcohol.

headline: New Hope and Fresh Paint for Synagogue in Queens
text: Twenty years ago, it seemed that Congregation Tifereth Israel in Corona, thought to be the oldest synagogue in Queens, was headed for a date with a wrecking ball. Its Ashkenazi Jewish congregation — whose early members included the teenager who would become Estée Lauder — had dwindled to just a few. The wooden building, coated in 1929 with an unfortunate blanket of stucco, was in disrepair.

headline: Despair and Triumph of a Soldier and Player
text: The stories of baseball players who left the game to go to war often focus on what they lost by being away. Ted Williams and Willie Mays forfeited a shot at challenging Babe Ruth’s record of 714 home runs. Bob Feller, the greatest pitcher of his era, lost his chance at 300 victories.

headline: A South Jersey Town Grieves After a Girl’s Murder
text: CLAYTON, N.J. — For all of its real-world brutality — a young girl strangled, her body stashed in a southern New Jersey trash bin — the death of Autumn Pasquale this week also cast a shadow in the virtual world.

headline: Crucial Subset: Female Voters Still Deciding
text: DERRY, N.H. — Emmakate Paris was a one-woman tornado the other day, whipping through the racks at the thrift shop here, hunting for clothes for her children and one special item for herself: a green suit. For Halloween, she wants to dress up as Tippi Hedren in the Hitchcock movie “The Birds.”

headline: The Women’s Vote
text: Female voters in the swing state of New Hampshire discuss what issues are foremost in their minds in the closing days of the presidential campaign.

headline: N.B.A. Alters Ballot
text: The notion of an All-Star center is officially defunct — at least on the ballot that determines N.B.A. All-Stars. The N.B.A., bowing to new realities in a multi-positional era, has eliminated “center” from its All-Star ballots for the 2012-13 season. Instead, fans will vote for three frontcourt players and two guards. More at nytimes.com/sports.

headline: Prison May Be the Next Stop on a Gold Currency Journey
text: MALIBU, Calif. — High above the cliff tops and the beach bars, up a winding mountain road, in a borrowed house on someone else’s ranch, an unusual criminal is waiting for his fate.

headline: Vatican: Diverse List of New Cardinals
text: Pope Benedict XVI named six new cardinals on Wednesday, including Archbishop James Harvey, an American who heads the papal household that employed the pope’s former butler, who was convicted this month of stealing private documents and leaking them to the press. The new cardinals, who are expected to be appointed at a Vatican ceremony next month, are all younger than 80 and therefore eligible to vote in the conclave that elects new popes. Benedict was criticized in February for appointing too many Europeans, especially Italians, as cardinals. Two of the cardinals-elect named Wednesday are from countries with large Muslim populations: Lebanon and Nigeria. The others are from Colombia, the Philippines and India.

headline: Spotlight Put on Founders of Drug Firm in Outbreak
text: A $4.2 million, four-bedroom Boston penthouse overlooking the Charles River in the Back Bay neighborhood. A $3.5 million home in Southborough, Mass., with more than 11,000 square feet, a home theater and an indoor saltwater pool. A $2.35 million vacation home on Cape Cod.

headline: China Slows Development of Nuclear Power Plants
text: HONG KONG — Still responding to the partial meltdowns last year at nuclear reactors in Fukushima, Japan, the Chinese government has lowered its target for the construction of nuclear power plants by 2015, notably by not building more nuclear reactors at inland locations.

headline: Knicks Beats Nets on Night When Everything Seems Off
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — When next they meet, the Nets and Knicks will be in Brooklyn, playing in the Nets’ new $1 billion palace, presumably before a pro-Brooklyn crowd, in a game with tangible stakes. The basketball should be a little crisper, too.

headline: Reid’s Machine Powers Obama in Nevada Test
text: LAS VEGAS — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. sat onstage before a crowd of culinary workers here the other morning, listening intently to a man who is not on the ballot but might hold the key to a victory for President Obama in economically ravaged Nevada.

headline: Shot After Interrupting a Robbery, an Off-Duty Officer Kills a Suspect
text: An off-duty New York City police officer was shot in the chest on Wednesday evening after interrupting a robbery on a Bronx street, but he continued to pursue three fleeing suspects, fatally shooting one of them, the authorities said.

headline: Man Rejects Plea and Release, Choosing Trial in His Baby’s Death

text: In what sport, in what universe, could a team potentially win its second consecutive league title and then turn out the lights … for good?

headline: Colorado: Teenager Held in 10-Year-Old Girl’s Killing
text: A 17-year-old community college student was arrested Tuesday night in the kidnapping and murder of Jessica Ridgeway, 10, who disappeared this month while walking to school. The police in the Denver suburb of Westminster identified the suspect on Wednesday as Austin Reed Sigg, and an arrest report indicated that he lived about one and a half miles from where Jessica was kidnapped. The arrest report described Mr. Sigg as “cooperative,” and The Associated Press quoted Mr. Sigg’s mother as saying that he had turned himself in to the police.

headline: Why Women Can’t Do Pull-Ups
text: This column appears in the Oct. 28 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: Insurance Institute Awards Highest Rating to a Record Number of Booster Seats
text: Of 17 new-for-2012 booster seats identified by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, 15 received the organization’s top rating of Best Bet. Accounting for previously evaluated models on the market, the latest evaluation brings the total of Best Bet boosters to 47.

headline: Panel Says Medtronic Edited Product Studies
text: Officials of Medtronic, the medical device maker, edited studies by outside researchers about a controversial spine treatment sold by the company, inserting claims that their product was superior to a competing one, according to a Senate finance committee report released Thursday.

headline: Word of the Day | lien

headline: Down Goes Chandler
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The entire Knicks bench felt uneasy. The reserves rose to their feet after Tyson Chandler, the team’s defensive leader, went down and started grimacing when he looked at his leg. A single minute hadn’t gone off the clock in the Knicks’ preseason game with the Brooklyn Nets, a 97-95 overtime victory at Nassau Coliseum, when Chandler bumped knees with the Nets’ Gerald Wallace while trying to establish a pick.

headline: Study Says Gender Gap in Pay Starts Early
text: The pay gap between educated women and men begins as soon as they start their careers, a new study shows. The study, released on Wednesday by the American Association of University Women, found that in 2009, women who had graduated college a year earlier and worked full time were paid 82 percent as much as their male counterparts, a slight improvement from the 80 percent a similar study found in 2001. The pay gap has often been attributed to women entering lower-paying professions, but the study found that a difference persisted even after controlling for that factor.

headline: Sandoval Lifts Giants, Into the Stands
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It is brief and illustrious, the list of baseball players who have hit three home runs during a World Series game: Albert Pujols, Reggie Jackson and Babe Ruth, who achieved the feat twice.

headline: A Landslide for Obama (If the World Got to Vote)
text: HONG KONG — If the rest of the world got to vote, President Obama apparently would be re-elected in a landslide.

headline: Chester Hansen, a Rare Diarist of World War II, Dies at 95
text: Before dawn on June 6, 1944, as the cruiser Augusta headed toward the coast of Normandy, Chester Hansen was up and, as always, at the side of Gen. Omar N. Bradley. And as always, Mr. Hansen, a journalist by training and a top aide to Bradley, made notes in his diary:

headline: Islanders Timeline: From Expansion to Dynasty to Disaster
text: 1972 To head off a potential rival league, the N.H.L. awards New York a second team, the Islanders. William Shea, who helped bring the Mets to New York as an expansion team 10 years earlier, does the same with the Islanders. Roy Boe, the owner of the Nets, purchases the team. It goes 12-60-6 in the 1972-73 season.

headline: With Three Mighty Swings, a Slugger Announces His Presence

headline: Executed Texan’s Family Seeks Pardon
text: Two decades after a Texas man was convicted of murdering his three young daughters by setting his own house on fire, and eight years after a campaign to prove his innocence failed to stop his execution, his family petitioned on Wednesday for a posthumous pardon.

headline: Rape Remark Jolts a Senate Race, and the Presidential One, Too
text: WASHINGTON — The incendiary topic of rape and abortion re-entered the 2012 campaign Wednesday and threatened to singe Mitt Romney after an Indiana Senate candidate’s comments that pregnancies conceived by rape should not be aborted because “God intended” conception to happen.

headline: Russia: Three Militants Said to Be Killed
text: Russia’s police and security services said Wednesday that they had killed three Islamic militants suspected of organizing back-to-back attacks in July that wounded the chief mufti of Kazan, a city in the Republic of Tatarstan, and killed another local Muslim leader who had spoken out against religious radicalism. As the officers tried to arrest the militants, an explosion killed a security officer; officers then swarmed a first-floor apartment in Kazan where the suspects had barricaded themselves, according to the Investigative Committee, which handles criminal inquiries. Officers found guns and components for homemade explosives, according to officials quoted by Ria Novosti, Russia’s state-run news agency. The attacks in July wounded the mufti, Ildus Faizov, and killed the other leader, Valiulla Yakupov. The episode has unnerved federal officials who have long sought to contain Islamic fervor in the Caucasus to the south while saying that places like Tatarstan represented a moderate “Russian Islam.”

headline: Obama Weighs In on Mourdock Rape Comments
text: President Obama waded into the Richard Mourdock rape controversy on Wednesday, telling Jay Leno on “The Tonight Show” on NBC that “rape is rape.”

headline: Three Critical Aspects of a Killer Slide Presentation
text: TerraCycle’s business is to make nonrecyclable waste recyclable by creating national collection and solution programs for things like cigarette butts and chip bags. Today, we have more than 32 million people collecting waste in 22 countries. We offer free shipping and, typically, a small donation of 2 cents per piece of waste to the collector’s favorite school or organization. As you can imagine, this is an expensive undertaking. To make it work, we go to hundreds of major companies like Imperial Tobacco and Frito-Lay to gain their financial backing and sponsorship.

headline: Betty Hart Dies at 85; Studied Disparities in Children’s Vocabulary Growth
text: Betty Hart, whose research documenting how poor, working-class and professional parents speak to their young children helped establish the critical role that communicating with babies and toddlers has in their later development, died on Sept. 28 in Tucson. She was 85.

headline: Memoir of Qaeda Figure May Be Cited in Leniency Plea for Convict
text: He was one of Al Qaeda’s most elusive operatives, a master of disguise who helped to orchestrate the deadly 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa. He then stayed on the run for more than a dozen years until he was finally killed in 2011 in a shootout at a security checkpoint in Somalia.

headline: Images, Themes and Props in Presidential Campaign Ads
text: In the past few weeks, some media markets have been swamped with election advertising. A New York Times analysis looks at all the campaign ads that ran between October 4 and 21 — including those produced by outside groups.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Thursday, Oct. 25
text: NEWS The top health official for the European Union suddenly resigns. His plans to place marketing curbs on tobacco companies are put aside. The offices of antitobacco groups are burglarized. There is talk of cash payments of tens of millions of dollars by Big Tobacco. The swirl of rumors around events inevitably called “Tobaccogate” has a noirish tone that is unfamiliar in Brussels, the European Union capital better known for turgid debates about fish quotas. And much still remains mysterious and tangled in unproven accusations. James Kanter reports from Brussels.

headline: India Reacts to Gupta’s Sentence
text: The sentencing of Rajat Gupta, the Kolkata-born former Goldman Sachs director, to two years in prison for leaking confidential information has prompted shock and sadness among many of his longtime admirers and friends in India, some of whom even started a Web site to voice their support for him. But some younger Indians, business students who represent the future of corporate India, say they are torn between revering Mr. Gupta as a role model and viewing him as a criminal.Mr. Gupta was sentenced Wednesday in United States District Court in Manhattan for leaking corporate secrets to Raj Rajaratnam, a former hedge fund manager who himself is serving an 11-year sentence. Mr. Gupta was also fined $5 million.

headline: Santander Earnings Plunge 94% on Real Estate Woes

text: BEIJING — China announced the promotions of five generals this week, shaping the top leadership of the rapidly modernizing military as it becomes a more dominant player in Asia and challenges American dominance in the region.

headline: The Family That Cobras Together
text: Dropping in on the Killick family, 45 minutes outside Edmonton, Alberta, feels like dropping into a Wes Anderson movie about Canadian rustics. Glenna and Tyler Killick and their four children — Von, 21; Gil, 17; Sami, 15; Tobi, 13 — live off a dirt road in a farmhouse they built themselves. A 1965 Ford Galaxie 500 sits out front, near the cow trough where they all bathed straight through Canadian winters, before they installed indoor plumbing in 2005. Out back are raspberry bushes that won’t fruit, chickens that run away and corn that’s starting to bolt. “We’re terrible farmers!” Glenna says.

headline: The Heart of the Jack-o’-Lantern
text: You’re carving your jack-o’-lanterns now; soon you’ll buy canned pumpkin for pie. Join the club. Almost no one in this country cooks fresh pumpkin.

headline: My AdWords Debacle: Waiting for a Miracle
text: As I said in Wednesday’s post, my first theory of why my sales were dropping last spring was that the world was going down the drain again, just as it had in 2008. Or maybe my corporate clients were feeling bullish and decided to invest in hiring instead of burning profits on fancy conference tables. I could find plenty of evidence for either idea in the papers. At any rate, I convinced myself that something had shifted in the outside world and there simply weren’t as many shoppers looking for tables.

headline: Taking the Fright Out of Halloween Beauty
text: If the fear of monster blemishes and ghastly bumps is stopping you from heavy Halloween makeup (like a full face of zombie gore or fantastical, glittery fairy dust), perhaps reconsider. After all, Broadway stars wear gobs of makeup onstage and later arrive at premiere parties without a spot in sight. To find out how they do it, I called Angelina Avallone, a Broadway makeup designer whose credits include “Young Frankenstein,” “The Addams Family” and “Dr. Seuss’ How the Grinch Stole Christmas!” Here’s what she said.

headline: In the Land of Strip-Mall Massages
text: John Jeremiah Sullivan’s multiday massage-a-thon.

headline: My Multiday Massage-a-Thon
text: About a month ago, editors from this magazine, which employs me, and from which I am therefore loath to turn down assignments even when they are horrifying, assigned me to get a series of massages and other body treatments here in the coastal town where I live, Wilmington, southeastern N.C., Port City of Progress and Pleasure. There was a semi-legitimate journalistic impulse behind it, but it was also billed as an act of mercy. I’d been traveling and writing a lot for them, spending a lot of time in middle seats on international flights, and my body had reached new levels of vileness. The yellowish gray-green circles under my eyes had a micropebbled texture, and my skin gave off a sebaceousy sheen of coffee-packet coffee. My calves had developed a vague thrombotic throb. It was the kind of premature aging where you think, I’ll come back from this but not all the way.

headline: Fisheries Rule Could Limit Scientific Access to Data
text: A draft rule proposed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration may limit public access to fisheries data collected by independent observers on fishing vessels. The agency cites protection of confidential personal and business information as the reason, but some scientists and advocates fear that such a rule will limit their ability to examine and evaluate fisheries data for research purposes.

headline: Buoyed by Olympics, Britain Emerges From Double-Dip Recession

The shelves hold only a few dated copies of the Encyclopedia Britannica and a set of something called the Encyclopedia of Buddhism in an attempt to appear like a place of study.

But the Rams will host the Patriots as the home team in name only Sunday in Wembley Stadium, so they’ll forfeit the benefit of a familiar field and a friendly crowd.

headline: Souls Tangled Up in Time
text: In 1849 a businessman on a Melville-esque sea voyage in the South Pacific battles a mysterious illness and shelters a runaway slave. In 1936 Robert Frobisher, a penniless young composer, flees Cambridge for Edinburgh to join the household of a vain and temperamental maestro. Four decades later an alternative-press journalist risks her life investigating safety problems at a nuclear power plant.

headline: Tokyo’s Firebrand Governor Quits to Form New National Party

Because the phones have also become thinner and lighter, being able to hold them steady long enough to take the best photo can be a challenge, but some models have ways to get around this.

headline: A Repaired Lovey, and a Debt Unrepaid
text: All of my children have “loveys” in one form or another, and in varying degrees of wear and tear. Not one adopted the “lovey” presented to him or her by me in the hopes that it would serve the comforting lovey purpose: persuading a child to go to sleep, alone but not alone and happy. No, they all embraced other, odder, more awkwardly shaped things, and getting our lovey collection to a vacation spot requires a full duffle bag.

headline: Put Demand Behind the Wheel
text: Have economists in Europe learned nothing about the importance of stimulating demand? It was infrastructure building and government investment in labor that built up the consumer demand to revive the U.S. economy in the 1930s. Large taxes on the rich helped fund this stimulus. It was Henry Ford who said he must pay workers enough to buy the cars they built. Demand is crucial.

headline: Hunter Gatherer | Magnus Nilsson
text: At Faviken, a tiny restaurant in remote northern Sweden, the 28-year-old chef Magnus Nilsson contrasts the sweet simplicity of foraged and farm-fresh ingredients with a kind of Viking bloodlust. He’ll serve a thrush with its decapitated head, or fire-roast a black grouse in hay, or slaughter a geriatric dairy cow and then dry-age it for nine months until, he writes, “the pure flavor of meat becomes secondary to the aromas of controlled decay . . . rather like a cheese.” “Faviken” (Phaidon, $50) is Nilsson’s first cookbook, and it’s the work of an obsessive: he spends an entire page explaining the proper way to peel a carrot. With ingredients like pickled marigolds and “turnip leaves that have never seen the light of day,” many of Nilsson’s recipes are hard to reproduce. Better to think of them as evocations of his Scandinavian Arcadia, where he picks wild flowers and shuttles around on skis, a rifle on his back “in case a tasty bird crosses my path.”

headline: Four More Climb Aboard the Coca-Cola-Will.i.am Ekocycle
text: Four additional brands are joining the Coca-Cola Company and the musician Will.i.am in an environmental initiative called Ekocycle, which seeks to develop creative ways of recycling plastic beverage bottles.

headline: Judging if Wiretaps Are Necessary
text: “Necessity” is a simple word that means “an imperative requirement or need for something.” In Raj Rajaratnam’s appeal of his convictions for conspiracy and insider trading that will be heard on Thursday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, the critical issue will be whether the government established that it needed to use wiretaps because other avenues of investigation were not fruitful.

headline: A New Star Each Night, at Times More
text: SAN FRANCISCO —  When four former Giants were introduced to the crowd before Game 1 of the World Series, the public-address announcer noted that no franchise has more players in the Hall of Fame.
