headline: Claims on a Fortune
text: Paul Sullivan’s Wealth Matters column this week looks at the issue of whether Lance Armstrong should be concerned about keeping his wealth in the wake of the report from the United States Anti-Doping Agency detailing his use of performance-enhancing drugs to win cycling races. And the independent advisers and lawyers Paul spoke to answered that Mr. Armstrong will probably remain a rich man. Yes, he’ll probably have to forfeit his Tour de France prize money and his sponsors have dropped him, but much of his wealth is probably protected, these experts said.

headline: Frescoes and Festivals in an Umbrian Town
text: MY family and I made the three-hour drive from Rome to Gubbio, winding around spiraling curves as we approached the medieval Umbrian town on Mount Ingino, only to find that to reach the heart of the historic center we needed to walk up a seemingly perpendicular cobblestone street. Between pushing our 2-year-old daughter in her heavily laden stroller and feeling the sun beam down with fiery concentration, we felt as if we were walking up a wall on this last leg of the journey.

headline: Park the Pickup: Santa Fe by Bicycle
text: THE poet C. P. Cavafy said that a city changes when you fall in love with someone in it. It can also change for less exalted reasons: when, for example, instead of sealing yourself in the personal microclimate of an automobile, you use a bicycle to get around. I happened to grow up in Oxford, England, a city, and country, where biking is a normal means of transport, no more a sport than bipedalism is. But it rains a lot, and I didn’t come away with a proper appreciation of the benefits of the bicycle.

headline: The Art of Buying Art Worldwide

text: With the opening of Dabbous in January, London is suddenly smitten with the delicate, sincere, fragile, locavore “cuisine naïve” that’s enchanted Paris and many Scandinavian cities for five years or so. It is a big change from the major-production-values tables with lots of theater and taste-bomb dishes recently popular in London.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor: Regarding “$150 for a Room in Manhattan? 7 That Fit the Bill, More or Less” (Oct. 21), the key to the low price for the Sheraton Tribeca was probably the fact that it was a Sunday night, not the author’s use of Priceline or Hotwire. I learned this trick a few years ago. High-quality chain hotels in Manhattan can offer rock-bottom rates for Sunday nights because that’s the night they’re most likely to have lots of unsold rooms. Think about it: business travelers stay Monday to Friday and weekend tourists stay Friday to Sunday, which leaves available inventory for Sunday nights. Last January I stayed at the Radisson Martinique at Herald Square for $119 on a Sunday night; two months before, I stayed in an identical room there for $379 on a weeknight. In June, my family and I stayed at a brand new, immaculate DoubleTree Suites property on 29th Street near Seventh Avenue on a Sunday evening and paid $107 (the rate was $119 with a further $12 reduction with my AAA or AARP card). We were walking distance from Herald Square, Times Square and the High Line. That same room would cost $399 for a weeknight.GERRY MURPHYWest Hartford, Conn.

headline: Profile in Style | Pierre Yovanovitch
text: When Pierre Yovanovitch, the Paris-based designer bought his apartment in the Seventh Arrondissement, it was a 1970s period piece, complete with black lacquered walls, wall-to-wall carpeting and a kitchen that had never been touched, let alone cooked in. “It was pretty ugly,” he admits. “But the situation is amazing — 14-foot ceilings, with one of the best views in Paris.” Indeed, the front rooms practically float over the Seine. Yovanovitch, who is known for chic, modern interiors, spent one year renovating the space, approaching it as he does all his projects — architecturally. “I always think about volumes before décor,” he says. His signature mix of sleek lines and light proportions with strong, tactile materials like oak, stone and steel and sinuous furnishings produce an effect that is spare but glamorous. “I don’t like a white box, like a gallery,” Yovanovitch says. “Minimal spaces don’t have to be stark. They should be sexy.” More…

headline: Mourdock and Ryan, Abortion and Rape

I said I would want to know if a candidate’s faith guided his or her views on the issues, if religious doctrine would be a justification for excluding some categories of citizen (gays, for example) from the rights and protections the country promises, or if religious narrative overshadowed a candidate’s respect for serious science and verifiable history.

headline: When the Transition Out of the Service Is Less Than Smooth
text: As a colonel in the Army, I watched hundreds of soldiers and their families make the transition from citizen to soldier. In one unit in Germany during the 1990s, I would board the official Army “replacement bus,” a 40-passenger bus with soldiers fresh from their specialty training, to introduce myself, hoping that the personal touch would translate into them selecting my battery when the battalion personnel clerk asked which one they’d like to be assigned to.

He is 7 and a high-functioning autistic. Our strategy depends on the length of the flight:

headline: U.S. Presidential Stock Markets
text: In general, voters have tended to throw out the incumbent party after four-year periods when the Dow rose at a compound rate of less than 5 percent a year, and to keep the incumbents if the market gain exceeded that figure. If that pattern continues, Barack Obama will win re-election.

headline: Putting a Fresh Spin on the Familiar
text: IN August 1942, the folk painter Thomas Hart Benton watched the first wave of American servicemen board ships at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, headed for North Africa. He used the sketches he made that day as the basis for one of the oversize propaganda murals he created “to wake up the Middle West to the grimness of our national situation.” This painting, “Embarkation (Prelude to Death),” depicts grim soldiers bearing rifles and duffel bags as they head onto a hulking ship. Although the pharmaceutical company Abbott Laboratories financed this work and others as part of a national World War II propaganda campaign, officials at the government’s Office of War Information were not pleased with the results. As the Benton scholar Henry Adams explained, “Why would the army make posters of a painting reminding young soldiers that they are likely to die?”

headline: Eternal Charm Along the Hudson River
text: When the New-York Historical Society reopened its doors in 2011 after a three-year renovation, the museum’s director, Linda S. Ferber, was prepared for almost anything — except the ire of some visitors.

headline: Beauty and Beast Meet at the Movies
text: On a recent afternoon, Nicholas D. Lowry stood in a back room at Swann Auction Galleries in Manhattan, flipping through a stack of movie posters on a conference table and keeping up a running commentary.

headline: When Artifact ‘Became’ Art
text: A SEMINAL moment for America’s avant-garde came in 1913, when the Armory Show opened its doors to an unsuspecting public. An exposition of about 1,300 works, it introduced the New York art audience to movements like Cubism, Fauvism and Futurism, as well as the work of artists like Pablo Picasso, Henri Matisse and Marcel Duchamp, jolting them out of their romance with realism and toward newer, more experimental interests.

headline: Heart-Pounding Art, Seen Solo
text: How much museumgoers know about art makes little difference in how they engage with exhibits, according to a study by a German cultural scholar who used electronics to measure which items caught visitors’ attention and how they were emotionally affected. The scholar, Martin Tröndle, also found that solitary visitors typically spent more time looking at art and that they experienced more emotions.

headline: Exhibits That Only Researchers Usually See
text: George Amato climbs a step and lifts the lid on a shiny stainless steel vessel that is basically a tall, portly thermos bottle. Clouds swirl off liquid nitrogen inside, making the tank look like a high-tech witch’s caldron.

headline: Engaging Children With the Siren Call of the App
text: Each summer for several years, a two-week seminar at the American Museum of Natural History has allowed 25 youngsters to use technology to resurrect a prehistoric marine animal by designing realistic 3-D models and sea environments.

headline: Van Gogh’s Evolution, From Neophyte to Master
text: There are some artists on whom the sun never sets.

headline: An Artist’s Evolution
text: An exhibition at the Denver Art Museum traces Vincent van Gogh’s evolution as an artist through the 1880’s, from neophyte to master.

headline: At Shrine to Beats, Squares Are Welcome, Too
text: SAN FRANCISCO — JERRY CIMINO, founder of the Beat Museum, steps out onto the teeming streets of San Francisco’s North Beach section. Standing under a 12-foot-high, six-foot-wide painting of Jack Kerouac and Neal Cassady, he opens his arms wide.

headline: How ‘Hava Nagila’ Took Its Place on a Global Playlist
text: “Hava Nagila” was born in Eastern Europe, but became emblematic of Israel. It went global as a universal anthem of celebration and was recorded by performers ranging from Allan Sherman to Lena Horne. It evokes strong emotions — it has been denounced as “the kudzu of Jewish music” and hailed as “a profound haiku of Jewish history and identity.”

headline: On the Road
text: The Beat Museum in San Francisco houses a quirky, and lovingly curated, collection devoted to the Beat generation.

headline: Once on Fringe, Performance Art Is Embraced
text: WHEN visitors to the Museum of Modern Art enter the second-floor atrium later next month, they may feel as if they’ve made a wrong turn.

headline: Becoming Mainstream
text: Live, interactive performance art is increasingly a staple of mainstream museum programming.

headline: Will Labeling Genetically Modified Foods Make a Difference?
text: In the magazine’s Oct. 14 Food & Drink Issue, Michael Pollan argued that California’s Proposition 37 — which will ask state voters on Nov. 6 whether genetically modified (G.M.) foods must carry a label — might start a movement to put real pressure on politicians to change the food system.

headline: Deal Brings Mapplethorpe Shows
text: IN the museum world, the biggest institutions frequently work together while managing to protect their turf at the same time. Lending artworks? Gladly. Sharing information? Easy.

headline: Gallery as Museum, Art Dealer as Curator
text: THE British artist Antony Gormley explores aspects of the human body through sculptures intended to electrify their surroundings.

headline: New Partnerships
text: TV shows such as “Antiques Roadshow” and highbrow museums are offering integrated experiences for their audiences.

headline: The Dow as an Election Indicator
text: WALL STREET does not love Barack Obama, a fact demonstrated by large contributions by bankers to Mitt Romney.

headline: How ‘Pawn Stars’ Crosses Paths With Museums
text: OURS is an age of mysterious clutter, of attics, basements and closets brimming with objects that make us wonder: What on earth is that? The statue of a bear with a clock in its stomach, the chest of drawers handed down by Great-Aunt Frieda, the painting of the old bald guy no one knows but that’s been in the family forever — are they trash or buried treasure?

headline: The Tank Museum
text: The Military Vehicle Technical Foundation houses more than 240 tanks and other pieces of equipment.

headline: Care for Young Buildings
text: One shrine of the architect Louis Kahn is the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven. Completed in 1977, three years after Kahn’s death, it achieves its distinction “by modest and subtle means,” says Jules David Prown, the center’s first director: “perfect proportions, sensitively matched materials, honest expression of structure.”

headline: A Collector’s Legacy of War Machines in Repose
text: PORTOLA VALLEY, Calif. — A tank museum anywhere is a strange spectacle. It documents humanity’s ingenuity and ambition, and also its desire to demolish whatever is in its path with terrifying finality.

headline: From Bessie Smith to Lady Gaga, on Tour Together
text: Female rockers may now be in the vanguard of rebellion, frank expression and sexual freedom, but as a new traveling exhibit shows, they had a hard road to recognition and often struggled to make ends meet.

headline: A Sea of Solitary Islands, Coming Together
text: IN Bill Viola’s 2004 video projection “The Raft,” 19 people of varying age, race and sex gradually accumulate in tight physical proximity, as though waiting for a bus or cramming themselves into a subway car. Anonymous to one another, they look bored, lost in thought, sometimes annoyed — the flickers of their expressions accentuated by the extreme slow motion of the video. Without warning, a gushing onslaught of water from the wings knocks them into one another and down to the ground, obscuring individuals in one churning, flailing mass. Eventually, as the water subsides, the bewildered survivors look around and reach out to help each other, some embracing.

headline: The Zombies of ‘Walking Dead’ Take Over Sunday Night
text: For television fans who prefer hourlong dramas, no night of the week comes close to the bonanza that is Sunday, with its sheer volume of hits, prestige programs and guilty pleasures, all vying for precious time and DVR space.

headline: Gallery May Lead Arts Migration to Hudson Yards
text: It seems to be one of the most unpromising locations a high-end contemporary art gallery in Manhattan could possibly wish for: directly across the street from a Dunkin’ Donuts and a gas station, a block from the Nile Delta of traffic flowing into the Lincoln Tunnel, within sight of the 1980s mirror-ball exterior of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

headline: The Art Is Not on Loan. It’s an Exchange.
text: A trove of rarely seen masterpieces awaits visitors to “Dürer to de Kooning: 100 Master Drawings from Munich” at the Morgan Library and Museum. Part of a collection exchange with the Staatliche Graphische Sammlung in Munich, “Master Drawings” includes works by Michelangelo, Leonardo, van Gogh, Picasso and “one of the most remarkable Rubens ever,” William M. Griswold, director of the Morgan, said.

headline: The Art World, Blurred
text: TUCKED on the south side of Sotheby’s second floor is an all-white space that might as well be a gallery in the heart of Chelsea. Designed by Richard Gluckman, the New York architect who created Chelsea art galleries for dealers like Paula Cooper, Mary Boone and Larry Gagosian, this year-old space, called S2, is what officials at the auction house refer to as its “selling exhibition gallery.”

headline: N.H.L. Cancels November Schedule of 191 Games
text: The N.H.L. canceled its November schedule Friday, the 41st day of the lockout, eliminating 191 more games. In a season that was supposed to start Oct. 11, the league has lost 326 games — about 22 per team, or 26.5 percent of the regular season.

headline: A Mother’s Diary of Intimate Moments Becomes a Public Memorial
text: The busy young lives of Leo and Lucia Krim, as documented by their mother, Marina, on her dotingly detailed blog, seemed lifted from someone’s imagined idyllic New York childhood. Here was a photograph of Leo, 2, standing in his sneakers on a park bench on the High Line. Here was one of Lucia, 6, conked out on the couch, her eyes composedly closed and her small hands pressed against her lips.

headline: Salted Licorice Brigadeiros
text: This Halloween, how about a candy just for the grown-ups? Melissa Clark shows how to make salted licorice brigadeiros.

headline: Neighbors Won’t Give Candy Like This
text: IN today’s locavore, organic-minded, food-crazed culture, we get so wrapped up in the idea of seasonal fruits and vegetables that it can be easy to forget another important, deep vein of seasonal foodstuff opportunities.

headline: The Upstairs, Downstairs, Sideways Move
text: RATHER than surrendering their weekends to endless tours of the open-house circuit, or scrolling at all hours through infinite online listings, some shelter-seekers intent on altering or upgrading their living space are buying local, very local. They are sticking with the building they already live in.

headline: Man Claiming Facebook Ownership Arrested on Fraud Charges
text: In 2010, a New York entrepreneur made an explosive legal claim: an agreement that he had with Facebook’s founder, Mark Zuckerberg, entitled him to a major stake in the social-networking giant.

headline: Friends Listen
text: My friend keeps telling me that her 11-year-old son is not his regular happy-go-lucky self. It is clearly worrying her, and I have spent a fair amount of time listening. But of all the theories she has proposed to explain his quieter, more withdrawn mood, none seems as likely to me as that the boy is obviously gay. Would I be impolite to share my view or a bad friend if I don’t?

headline: How Do You Help Children Adjust to a Move?
text: T. and his family moved, exactly a year ago, to a new community. Their hope was to find a place with better schools than their old home had — a more affluent community, T. says, to be honest, and one where the children would thrive and the family could root itself and grow.

headline: The Past Is Always Present, Even Uninvited
text: WHEN film programmers at the Museum of Modern Art hit a speed bump putting together their coming series on Arab cinema, their Moroccan intern, Othmane Belafrej, did what many people do in times of stress: He called his mother.

headline: Carmona Ad Draws Rebuke from Arizona Senators
text: A new advertisement by the Democratic Senate candidate Richard Carmona elicited a sharp response on Friday from the two men who star in it: Arizona’s Republican senators, John McCain and Jon Kyl.

headline: Modern Romance | Rex Whistler
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 26
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: F.D.A. Details Contamination at Pharmacy
text: WASHINGTON — A federal inspection of a company whose tainted pain medicine has caused one of the worst public health drug disasters since the 1930s found greenish-yellow residue on sterilization equipment, surfaces coated with levels of mold and bacteria that exceeded the company’s own environmental limits, and an air-conditioner that was shut off nightly despite the importance of controlling temperature and humidity.

headline: Unemployment in Spain Exceeds 25%, Taking Economic Misery to New Levels
text: MADRID — Though hardly a surprise, Friday’s report that Spain’s unemployment rate had surpassed 25 percent was bad news for a government that recently trumpeted a streamlining of its labor market rules.

headline: New Play About Amy Winehouse to Open in Denmark
text: A play about Amy Winehouse’s turbulent life and tragic death, performed by the Danish Royal Theater, will open in Copenhagen next year, the BBC reported. Producers said the play would explore “the enormous pressure a sensationalist public put on a young superstar when her problems began.”

headline: Mile 18: Where First Avenue Offers an Old Bohemian Rhapsody
text: The marathon parade continues up First Avenue as marathoners pass the Mile 17 marker around 77th Street.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Fiona Staples Talks About ‘Saga’
text: A humanoid robot prince with a television for a head; a half-human, half-spider diva bounty hunter; and a planet-sized version of Amsterdam’s red-light district. These are just some of the characters and sights in the sci-fi universe of “Saga,” a new Image Comics series written by Brian K. Vaughan and drawn by Fiona Staples.

headline: ‘Great Journalism’ That Has Unwanted Business Impact in China
text: Here’s one memorable part of the coverage of the Chinese government’s censorship Friday of The New York Times’s Chinese-language Web site: the word “harmonized.”

headline: A Matter of Taste?
text: I used to think, back when all the foodie stuff was gathering steam (this would have been about 1994, when everyone was eating arugula and going on about, I don’t know, first-press organic broccoli rabe) that our newfound taste for food would lead, in time, to a taste for art.

headline: Dozens Are Killed in Myanmar as Sectarian Violence Flares Again
text: PHITSANULOK, Thailand — A resurgence of sectarian violence in western Myanmar has left more than 60 people dead, according to a local government official, and is renewing concerns that tensions could spread to other parts of the country during a fragile transition from authoritarian rule to democracy.

headline: Romney Tries to Take Up the Mantle of ‘Change’
text: AMES, Iowa – Mitt Romney intensified a new – and, aides said, final – line of attack against President Obama on Friday, arguing that the incumbent who once stood for historic change has run a re-election campaign built around small ideas and trivial attacks.

headline: Energy and a Suitcase
text: ALBERTA FERRETTI’S cute spinoff label, Philosophy, has a following, but it’s not a closely watched label, as few secondary lines are. So the news that Ms. Ferretti was stepping away from Philosophy and giving creative control to a newcomer, Natalie Ratabesi, caught my eye. Her appointment is noteworthy for several reasons.

headline: Boxer-Turned-Politician Shakes Up Ukrainian Elections
text: BORYSPIL, Ukraine — Vitali Klitschko, the world heavyweight boxing champion, stood on an outdoor stage — gloves off, sport coat on — pounding away, oratorically, in his bid to win a large number of seats for his party in Ukraine’s parliamentary elections on Sunday.

headline: Map Says Greenwich, Mood Says Port Chester
text: BYRAM, a tiny spit of land in Greenwich, Conn., has over the years seemed to change identity almost with the tides. For a time it was called Lyonville, for a prominent local family, according to historical accounts. Meadville, too, got a turn, for similar reasons. Residents of the densely settled neighborhood, which presses against the New York border 30 miles from Manhattan, also were briefly fond of the name New Lebanon, which survives on the sign at the elementary school.

headline: Black Is Her Go-To, Even if Luggage Gets Lost in Transit
text: Robbie Myers, 50, has been the editor in chief of Elle magazine for 12 years and lives on the Upper West Side after an itinerant youth that included stretches in Philadelphia; St. Louis; Estes Park, Colo.; and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

headline: Restoring Horror to a Grisly Luster
text: I mentioned Universal’s new “Classic Monsters” Blu-ray collection a couple of weeks ago in connection with that eight-disc set’s most prominent extra, the 3-D version of “Creature From the Black Lagoon.” But the collection is worth returning to for this Halloween week, not because these movies need any real introduction — with one exception, which I’ll get to below, these are among the most loved and frequently reissued films of classical Hollywood — but because Universal and its subcontractors have done an extraordinary job of bringing the material back to life, in editions remarkably superior to anything that has been available on home video before.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $17.9 Million
text: A sun-kissed duplex penthouse wrapped in terraces at the pinnacle of 965 Fifth Avenue, No. 18-19A, sold for its listing price of $17.9 million, making it the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Week in Review: Bank Suit Draws Fire Across Political Spectrum
text: There is an old defense trotted out by journalists that their reporting must be fair if both Republicans and Democrats are upset with them. If that is the case, then government officials can take some pleasure from the bipartisan complaints of their disjointed efforts to clean up the mortgage mess.

headline: Italians With Strong Allure, Dressed for Track and City
text: ITALY’S dominance as a spawning ground of great sports cars — not necessarily the fastest, but regularly the most desirable — is largely unchallenged.

headline: The Last King of Print
text: “I don’t actually go to newsstands anymore,” said Tina Brown, the editor in chief of Newsweek/The Daily Beast, a few days after she announced last week that Newsweek would become an all-digital publication and terminate its 79-year run in print by the end of 2012. But while Brown insists that she prefers reading on her Kindle when traveling and she sees “everybody reading screens,” there are still places in the world that thrive on stacks upon stacks of printed matter. One such is the corner of Eighth Avenue and 12th Street in Manhattan.

headline: A Diesel Rhino, Reborn for Suburbia
text: TESTED:  Volkswagen Touareg TDI Lux

headline: sry gotta bail mayb nxt tme
text: AT 10:52 p.m. on a recent Tuesday, Andy Cohen was preparing to host his weeknight talk show on Bravo, “Watch What Happens Live,” when a text message arrived.

headline: A Taste of the Next Corvette: G.M. Offers Peek at New V-8
text: PONTIAC, Mich.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Lebanon, Syria, Cyprus and Senegal.

headline: Q & A
text: Limiting Co-op Occupancy

headline: Putting the Tigers’ Situation Into Perspective
text: If athletes are laughably superstitious — and it’s a documented fact that they are — then sports fans are howl-out-loud superstitious. Take me. There was no way I was going back to Harlem to watch Game 2 of this World Series. Not after what I witnessed there on several big TV screens on opening night — the San Francisco Giants beating my beloved Detroit Tigers like a dirty rug.

headline: A Web of Answers and Questions
text: IT starts with a lowering of our shoulders. You and I have just befriended each other, and now we are well into our first cocktails on our first-ever get-together. We’ve bonded over a mutual appreciation of Roald Dahl, and now you’ve endeared yourself further with your comment that the name Real Simple sounds like a manual for people with learning disabilities.

headline: Homemade Candy Is Just a Click Away
text: In this week’s video and column, I make grown-up Halloween candy from scratch. But there are plenty of recipes on the Web for more classic Halloween candy that you can make at home. And if you’ve made candy, for Halloween or any other time of year, share ideas and recipes in the comments section.

headline: How to Shoot a Photo to Remember
text: Sometimes the realization comes almost too late — you sense that your parents or other loved ones may soon be gone, and it dawns on you that you don’t have any recent photos to remember them by.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: China’s cooling economy is squeezing American exporters, Apple introduced the iPad Mini, and Microsoft unveiled Windows 8 as well as its new tablet, the Surface.

headline: Another Day, Another Set of Insider Trading Cases
text: It has been yet another busy day for insider trading on the federal court docket.

headline: How an Autonomous Car Gets Around
text: Self-driving cars will rely on a number of sensors and other digital devices.

headline: Yes, Driverless Cars Know the Way to San Jose
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.

headline: Can’t Guys Just Learn to Fight for a Friendship?
text: SOMEWHERE I have a photograph of my friend Dan and me when we were 6 months old. Sitting up and facing each other with adult hands hovering inches behind our backs, we stare, dumbly, sweetly.

headline: Nippon-Ham Fighters Draft Teenager Who Wants to Play in U.S.
text: Shohei Otani, a 6-foot-4, 18-year-old right-hander who is one of Japan’s top high school prospects, was drafted by the Nippon-Ham Fighters on Thursday despite his announcing that he would rather start his professional baseball career in the United States.

headline: The Pleasures of Persimmons in Fall
text: PERSIMMONS are prized worldwide for their sweet, mellow flavor and their haunting beauty, whether they are observed in a fruit bowl or hanging from a branch.

headline: Exercise May Protect Against Brain Shrinkage
text: Remaining physically active as you age, a new study shows, may help protect parts of your brain from shrinking, a process that has been linked to declines in thinking and memory skills. Physical exercise not only protected against such age-related brain changes, but also had more of an effect than mentally and socially stimulating activities.

text: More Photographs

headline: I’ll Take It! | A Garage Sale at MoMA
text: For the first time, the Museum of Modern Art is holding a garage sale. Not that excess Picassos and Pollocks will be flying out the door — sorry! — but a hoard of other stuff will. From Nov. 17 to Nov. 30, the artist Martha Rosler will stock (and restock) the museum’s atrium with 12,000 donated objects, including neck chains, hankies and underwear, that she has gathered for her “Meta-Monumental Garage Sale,” possibly the largest ever — at least in an art space. (The image above is from a similar sale in London in 2005.) Rosler is widely known for her seminal Vietnam War-era collages, “House Beautiful: Bringing the War Home (1967-72),” which are on view elsewhere in the museum, and her sale doubles as a demonstration of the way society values received goods and ideas, and as a commentary on desire for ownership. That’s why she won’t reveal which six charities will receive the proceeds, only that she doesn’t plan to give MoMA — “the Kremlin of the value of art” — a single dime. “I don’t want people walking in there with a sense of virtue,” she says. Haggling, on the other hand, is welcome, and a hired wedding photographer will document the transactions, streamed live, Marina Abramovic style, on moma.org/garagesale under “Martha Rosler Made Me Buy.” “Maybe the garage sale is a metaphor for the mind,” Rosler says. “I find it very stressful.”

headline: Two-Wheel Renaissance
text: The Aprilia Tuono V4 and Ducati 1199 Panigale, pictured, are tradition-rattling departures from their respective makers’ heritage.

headline: Fuyu Persimmons, Ready to Eat
text: This week’s City Kitchen column is all about persimmons, mostly the ready-to-eat round Fuyu variety. Now is the moment to buy them — they’re popping up all over at greenmarkets and fruit stands. Though I do give a method for a rather delicious salad, here are a couple of dishes you can make with Fuyu persimmons that require no recipe and very little time.

headline: What Medicare Will Cover Even if You’re Not Likely to Get Better
text: Should the federal government cover the costs of many kinds of treatments for patients who aren’t going to get any better?

headline: Schoenberg on Yom Kippur and Sheriff on the Holocaust
text: In 1938 Arnold Schoenberg was asked by a Los Angeles rabbi to compose a take on “Kol Nidre,” the central prayer of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement. Schoenberg planned it as an attack on sappiness, explaining that he wanted to “vitriolize out the cello sentimentality of the Bruchs, etc.,” referring to Max Bruch’s elegiac version, among others.

headline: Reid Involved in Minor Car Accident
text: 6:11 p.m. | Updated

headline: Navigating the Medicare Claims Process
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I write about the settlement of a class-action lawsuit over the question of whether and when Medicare should cover treatments for people with chronic or degenerative conditions for which there are no cure.

headline: Paintings on the Walls, and Dancing on the Floor
text: When the Congolese choreographer and dancer Faustin Linyekula ventures onstage — a raised white platform smack in the middle of the atrium at the Museum of Modern Art — he begins with minute movements in which his fingers splay and wiggle indecisively. He then lowers his body to the floor with buckling limbs as his feet press down like putty.

headline: “Bypassing Security”:  Contest Wrap-Up and Winners’ Names
text: SPECIAL POST — Well, that turned out to be a lot harder than I expected, on account of an unintentional trap. Then, as usual, some solvers created traps of their own.

headline: Google Is Testing Same-Day Delivery for Shoppers
text: Google is now in the same-day delivery business. In San Francisco, some people affiliated with Google can buy a product, using their phones or computers, and have it delivered to their homes in a matter of hours.

headline: In an Entrenched Car Culture, Painting a Bolder Face on Mass Transit
text: LOS ANGELES — “Make metro cool.” That was Michael Lejeune’s task 10 years ago when he was hired as the first creative director of the Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

headline: The Old Is New Again, as the Muse Endures
text: In the 1980 Dance in America telecast “Beyond the Mainstream,” the choreographer and director David Gordon spoke about how he didn’t feel there was anything left to invent. “I think there are only new combinations of things and a new way of looking at something,” he said, calling what he does “a kind of reinvention.”

headline: Fresh Flights Outfitted With Classic Soundtracks
text: With higher energy, brighter music and more rewarding choreography, the second program of Ballet Next proved altogether better fare than the first of the company’s current New York season. Though problems certainly remain, both dance and dancers held the attention firmly. At Wednesday’s performance, all three works were world premieres. Each gave room for lively discussion.

headline: Fanning the Flames of Love and War
text: A woman in a pale dress, gloves, pearls and bare feet moved sensually around small tables cluttered with half-filled glasses and cigarettes as the vocalist Theo Bleckmann — portraying the protagonist of Phil Kline’s alluring new monodrama — lamented a lost love.

headline: Reviewing the Aprilia Tuono V4 and Ducati 1199 Panigale
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Norman Mayersohn reviews the Aprilia Tuono V4 and Ducati 1199 Panigale: two Italian sportbikes priced from roughly $15,000 to $25,000 that take different paths to making MotoGP-level riding dynamics accessible to mere mortals.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A four-bedroom Nantucket-style colonial in Huntington Bay, N.Y., and a four-bedroom house on an eight-acre horse farm in Tabernacle, N.J.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Ditmas Park Victorian, a TriBeCa co-op and a West Village co-op.

headline: Who Gets Credit for the Recovery?
text: Washington

headline: A Pro Hockey Team in the Early ’70s Was Golden in Name Only
text: It might seem unlikely that when the Islanders move to the Barclays Center arena in Brooklyn for the 2015 season their star players will be asked to pose naked to promote the team in magazines.

headline: Murder So Refined, It Deserves to Be Repeated, and Repeated
text: HARTFORD — Jefferson Mays dies not once, not twice, not thrice, but a staggering eight times in the delectable musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” having its premiere at the Hartford Stage here. And as each passing away passes by, this gifted actor discovers ingenious ways of making the final throes of his ill-starred characters inspire full-throttled laughter.

headline: U.S. Cuts Estimate of Sugar Intake
text: It was repeated so often it was accepted as true: the typical American consumed 95 to 100 pounds of sugar each year. Health experts said that consumption was surely contributing to a nationwide crisis of obesity.

headline: Tamara Mellon’s Next Step
text: LAST November, when Tamara Mellon suddenly left Jimmy Choo, the shoe company she helped build into a global juggernaut, taking with her a reported payout of roughly $135 million, she did so without much explanation. The only thing close to an official statement was a message, sent out to her roughly 12,000 followers on Twitter, thanking them for their support and signing off with, “I will keep you posted.”

headline: Islamic Cleric Held on Terror Charges Will Be Given New Prostheses
text: The Islamic preacher extradited from Britain on terrorism charges who is widely known for the hook he wore as a prosthetic device is expected to be fitted next week with new prostheses, a federal judge said on Friday.

headline: A Mile a Minute in One Long Nightmare
text: The distinction between actors and special effects shrinks ever further in the video game-turned-horror film “Silent Hill: Revelation 3D,” which reduces its human players to plastic action figures in tired genre settings.

headline: In Our Nanny We Trust
text: Parents and caretakers expressed sadness and shock after a nanny allegedly fatally stabbed two young children and then stabbed herself.

headline: Donning Familiar Halloween Costumes
text: Just as houses can be classified by the type of Halloween goodies they hand out, cable channels can be categorized by the type of new Halloween movie they offer. This weekend, television trick-or-treaters can fill their DVRs with a variety of treats: some zombie hard candy, a sugarcoated witchcraft confection and a gourmet ghost bar. If they cause cavities, it will be in your brain, not your teeth.

headline: Playing Hardball Runs in the Family
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

headline: Poll Watch: Track the Polls In the Race’s Final Days
text: Less than two weeks to Election Day, a number of national polls are showing a close race between President Obama and Mitt Romney among likely voters. Check back here daily to track the race as it heads into its final days.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Civil Wars
text: Sorry about blog silence: traveling, and also a bit under the weather.

headline: In an Autonomously Driven Future, Whither Automotive Reviews?
text: As Henry Fountain writes in this Sunday’s Automobiles section, the era of the autonomous vehicle may be nigh. A pursuit long derided by skeptics as an after-school science-club experiment has evolved into a potentially transformative force in the automotive industry. He writes:

headline: Changes to Charts by Billboard Draw Fire
text: Three weeks ago, the editors at Billboard, who for decades have defined what makes an American hit, shook up the song charts for various genres.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Yay, Not Boo

text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Tyson Chandler expects to play in the Knicks’ season opener against the Brooklyn Nets on Thursday. That’s what Chandler said with confidence Friday after practice. The team announced Thursday that he had a bruised left knee.

text: Talk, talk, talk — all Patrick Stickles does is talk. On “Ecce Homo,” the first song from the new album by his band Titus Andronicus, he’s talking about himself, and it’s not pretty.

headline: Spicy Morsels From the Subcontinent
text: Coromandel Cuisine of India in Southport is part of a small but growing network of like-named restaurants. All of them are operated under a four-person partnership, but unlike the other six outposts, Southport’s, which opened in 2010, is firmly grounded in modern-day India. What artwork there is in the main dining room — Hindu processions painted in vibrant colors, ceiling beams inscribed in Sanskrit, earth-tone portraits — is set against a finely chiseled stonework wall and similarly austere backdrops. White Eames-style molded chairs, a glass-brick divider shielding the bar area and contemporary Indian pop music suggest much less of the India of maharajahs than many other such restaurants choose to evoke.

headline: India’s Plague, Trash, Drowns Its Garden City During Strike
text: MANDUR, India — Outside Bangalore’s last official landfill, the garbage trucks regularly lined up here for hours, their burdens putrefying in the afternoon sun. A stinking mountain of trash, the landfill has been poisoning local waters and sickening nearby villagers. Another dump site was in even worse shape before it was closed recently after violent protests.

headline: Returning to the Top, but With a New View
text: ISTANBUL — Serena Williams has hit a ball across a net more times than anyone could ever count, in settings ranging from nighttime finals at the Australian Open to early morning childhood practice sessions in Florida.

headline: Winter’s Approach Adds to Crisis as Refugee Population Swells
text: The population of registered Syrian war refugees in neighboring countries, which has already surpassed United Nations projections three times, is expected to nearly double by year’s end, to more than 700,000 people, just as the greatest need for shelter from the Middle East’s achingly cold winters is at its most intense, aid workers, advocates and relief officials say.

headline: A Lighter Atmosphere for High-Toned Fare
text: ON a recent frosty night, I was in the mood for soup, a four-letter word that in no way does justice to the root-vegetable velouté that cascaded from a silver pitcher into my waiting soup plate in the Tap Room at Crabtree’s Kittle House in Chappaqua. The velvety purée, laced with pumpkin oil and chive labneh, and decorated with a tuft of greenery, was the sort of dish that can set the course of an evening: not only was the service swell, and the mood convivial, but the kitchen knew exactly what it was doing.

headline: Who Was Jimmy Savile?
text: “All my life I was governed by fun; every day’s Christmas Day, every night’s New Year’s Eve. It’s all fun, and there’s nothing wrong with a bit of fun.” Those were the last, autobiographical words of a documentary, “Sir Jimmy Savile — As It Happened,” spoken by the film’s subject, a British D.J. who hosted popular music and children’s programs for the BBC in the 1960s and ’70s.

headline: Panicky Ride in an S.U.V. Becomes a Kidnapping
text: Andrew Hawkins was 36 and, to strangers, probably looked fine. Articulate, living with his girlfriend in an Upper East Side apartment, he was a freelance investor and budding day trader.

headline: The Paramount Closes Its Curtains
text: PEEKSKILL, N.Y.

headline: 4 Powerful Messages That Stand Out in a Sea of Advertisements
text: Here are four ads from smaller political action groups that stand out amongst the thousands of ads cluttering the airwaves in the final weeks before the election.

headline: Culinary Battles of Mitterrand’s Chef Go From Kitchen to Screen
text: CHAVAGNAC, France IN the fall of 1988, a local farmer and self-trained cook named Danièle Delpeuch was approached by a series of mysterious government officials with an unusual proposition: Would she move immediately to Paris to become the “personal chef” of President François Mitterrand?

headline: A Venus Ascends Into the Night
text: There was always a troubling question about “Venus in Fur.” When New York critics fell all over themselves praising the play’s 2010 Off Broadway production and became equally excited when it moved to Broadway last season, the lion’s share (and by that, we do mean all) of the talk seemed to be about its star, Nina Arianda. Ms. Arianda, an unknown before this role, ended up winning a Tony Award for it, beating out even Tracie Bennett’s praised-to-the-rafters portrayal of a late-career Judy Garland in “End of the Rainbow.” So a nagging concern sat there. Was it the actress, and not the play, that impressed us so much? Hartford TheaterWorks’ frisky new production clears things up. “Venus in Fur” is an entertaining, worthwhile play on its own. Without Ms. Arianda — who in her 20s is being compared to Meryl Streep — it is not quite as intoxicating or as magical. But with the deceptively button-cute Liv Rooth, who was Ms. Arianda’s Broadway understudy in both this play and “Born Yesterday,” it is perhaps a bit sharper and clearer. And this intimate Hartford theater is an ideal setting for a show about two people in a rehearsal studio on a dark and stormy night.

headline: A Journey Through Nepal’s Mustang Region
text: Beijing correspondent Edward Wong takes readers on a trek through Nepal’s Himalayan Mustang region:

headline: A Celebration of Jazz, With a Hint of New Orleans
text: MICHAEL KLINE, organizer of next month’s inaugural Exit 0 International Jazz Festival in Cape May, said he had “great respect” for the local group that put on the semiannual Cape May Jazz Festival, which ended a 17-year run in 2011.

headline: Fears of Storm Disrupting Final Days of Campaign
text: AMES, Iowa — Mitt Romney intensified a new — and, aides said, final — line of attack against President Obama on Friday, arguing that the incumbent who once stood for historic change has run a re-election campaign built around small ideas and trivial attacks.

headline: In a Fog of Guilt, Daring to Breathe

headline: China Blocks and Criticizes Investigation Into Premier
text: HONG KONG — A spokesman for China’s Foreign Ministry on Friday criticized a decision by The New York Times to publish a lengthy investigation into assets accumulated by the family of Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, saying that the article “smears China and has ulterior motives.”

headline: Romo’s Many Critics Focus on What He Has Not Done
text: IRVING, Tex. — His tone suggested no hint of excuses or apologies when it comes to the quarterback legacy of the Dallas Cowboys. Yet when Jerry Jones spoke this week of signal callers past and present, he was unable to resist an analogy that fuels the expectations placed on Tony Romo.

headline: Current TV Considers Putting Itself Up for Sale
text: Current TV, a low-rated cable channel that recently reinvented itself with a lineup of political talk shows, is considering selling itself, the channel’s chief executive, Joel Hyatt, said on Friday.

headline: In Virginia, Romney Scours Coal Country for Edge Over Obama
text: When Jay Swiney emerges from the night shift in the coal mines to assume his duties as mayor of Appalachia, Va., it is hard for him to miss the partisan forces rocking the heavily unionized Democratic hamlets in the mountains along the Tennessee border.

headline: Roosevelt’s Elephant
text: Q. The F.Y.I. column last Sunday mentioned several small animal specimens at the American Museum of Natural History that were collected by Theodore Roosevelt. Does the museum display any big game that Roosevelt shot?

text: To the Editor:

headline: With Team’s Move, Pondering Tailgating on Train
text: For their most zealous fans, evenings with the New York Islanders have been as unchanging as the seat number on a season ticket: Hop in the car. Enter a fading arena. And in recent years, watch a once-proud hockey team lose more often than it won.

headline: For New York State Senate
text: The corrupting culture of New York’s Legislature makes it tempting to want to throw out the incumbents. But there are lawmakers who deserve to return to Albany, especially those who have voted courageously on controversial issues in the face of pressure from political leaders or lobbyists. Here are our endorsements in five important State Senate races. In three cases, we are recommending candidates who took heroic stands to approve same-sex marriage and were then savaged by ultraconservatives.

headline: Pancakes for Dinner (Syrup Optional)
text: Having pancakes for dinner has always been a fun way to shake up a routine meal. Now Martha Rose Shulman has made pancakes healthful, savory and delicious enough that they can regularly be eaten any time of day. She writes:

headline: For Asians, School Tests Are Vital Steppingstones
text: Ting Shi said his first two years in the United States were wretched. He slept in a bunk bed in the same room with his grandparents and a cousin in Chinatown, while his parents lived on East 89th Street, near a laundromat where they endured 12-hour shifts. He saw them only on Sundays.

headline: Preparing for Hurricane Sandy Along the East Coast
text: With the nation’s top weather officials saying there is now a 90 percent chance that Hurricane Sandy will slam into the East Coast early next week, emergency management officials from Virginia to Massachusetts outlined plans for what is being described as a monster of a storm.

headline: A Disparity in Top Public High Schools
text: Fewer than 1 in 7 public school students in New York City are Asians, but they earn a majority of seats at four elite high schools.

headline: Eyeing ’13 Mayoral Bid, de Blasio Focuses on Small-Business Issues
text: Bill de Blasio was pacing the conference room, listening to small-business owners in Long Island City, Queens, bemoaning municipal red tape, when he relayed the tale of a frustrated laundromat owner whose water bill was inflated, erroneously, by an extra zero.

headline: Brother Against Microbe
text: On Oct. 27, 1862, the Confederate cavalry commander Jo Shelby filed a report on his brigade’s recent operations in Missouri. The colonel concluded with a sobering assessment of his troopers’ physical condition. “Our men, from being so poorly clad, and owing to the excessive duties that they have been compelled to perform, are rapidly becoming unfit for service,” he wrote. “Our brigade reports now some 500 sick. We have a great many men without a blanket, overcoat, shoes, or socks.” When the brigade was first organized, he went on, it numbered 2,319 men, and “the greater portion were reported for duty until within the last few days. Since this cold spell of weather set in, our reports show but 1,068 men for duty. The increase in sickness in Jeans’ and Gordon’s regiments is 100 per day.”

headline: The Company Romney Keeps
text: The saying goes: A man is known by the company he keeps.

headline: 4 Powerful Messages That Stand Out in a Sea of Advertisements
text: The number of presidential campaign ads that ran across the country in the last week was a staggering 80,000.

headline: For Romney, Ties That Bind
text: In 1999, when Mitt Romney was put in charge of organizing the 2002 Winter Olympic Games in Salt Lake City, there was an unusual company among those angling to be Olympic sponsors. Along with the Coca-Colas and the McDonalds, there was a company called Nu Skin, based in Provo, Utah, that sold anti-aging products and nutritional supplements. Its distribution network is what is called, in the industry, multilevel marketing. Critics have another name for that kind of business: a pyramid scheme.

headline: California Redistricting Fuels Competitive Races That Lure Outside Funds
text: ELK GROVE, Calif. — President Obama enjoys a gigantic lead in the polls in California, but perhaps nowhere is the fight over the House of Representatives fiercer and closer than in the nation’s most populous state.

headline: Slow but Steady Improvement
text: The slow pace of the nation’s economic recovery has picked up a bit lately. In the third quarter, the economy grew at an annual rate of 2 percent, beating expectations and the dismal 1.3 percent growth in the second quarter. Over the past year, the growth rate has been 2.3 percent. At that pace, there’s enough momentum to keep unemployment, currently 7.8 percent, from getting much worse, but not enough to spur big job gains.

headline: Mutual Fund Leaders Aim to End Jam Over Rules
text: Worried about a regulatory crackdown, mutual fund executives are pushing for limited restrictions on a controversial type of fund in an effort to end a bitter dispute between the government and the financial industry.

headline: Obtaining Financial Records in China
text: China’s political system is not very transparent, but corporate and financial information is often readily available to the public.

headline: 5,800 Miles From New York, Ranger Finds Hockey and More
text: If a Rangers defenseman was in Astana, Kazakhstan, 5,800 miles and 10 time zones from New York, what would he expect to find? Probably not a mall with a beach inside.

headline: Making Revolution Work
text: In Tripoli this week, there was no water for at least five days, huge heaps of garbage lined the highways and thousands of young men, most of them heavily armed, lacked meaningful work. As Libya reached the one-year anniversary of the death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his regime, the country’s new leaders are not delivering on the revolution’s promise and many Libyans are souring on democracy.

headline: England: Belarussian Is Granted Asylum
text: Britain has granted political asylum to a prominent Belarussian dissident and former presidential candidate, Andrei Sannikov, his wife said Friday. Mr. Sannikov, who was imprisoned for 15 months after challenging Belarus’s autocratic president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, in presidential elections in 2010, told the Charter 97 news service that he had fled the country in order to avoid arrest. Mr. Sannikov’s wife, Iryna Khalip, has been barred from traveling outside Belarus.

headline: China: Two Tibetan Self-Immolations
text: Free Tibet, a London-based activist group, said that Lhamo Tseten, 24, burned himself to death on Friday. It was the fourth self-immolation this week in an area that Tibetans call Sangchu County, and that the Chinese identify as Xiahe in Gansu Province. On Saturday, another activist group reported a fifth self-immolation. China has offered a reward of $7,700 for information about anyone orchestrating the immolations.

headline: Races for House Offer Little Suspense but Lots of Odd Back Stories
text: WASHINGTON — In Michigan, a House candidate confessed that he had difficulty telling whether or not he is, in fact, Santa Claus. In Tennessee, a freshman Republican who is a doctor stands accused of impregnating a patient, then pressuring her to have an abortion.

headline: Rise in Household Debt Might Be Sign of a Strengthening Recovery
text: WASHINGTON — For the first time since the Great Recession hit, American households are taking on more debt than they are shedding, an epochal shift that might augur a more resilient recovery.

headline: Means to Enlightenment
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — It seems almost perverse to say that I had fun doing a Saturday crossword puzzle, but I did. Aren’t we supposed to labor intensely over the Saturday grid, sweating our way through the cryptically worded clues, setting off in numerous wrong directions, erasing and overwriting, only to land, exhausted but triumphant, on the hard-won completed puzzle?

headline: Corrections: October 27, 2012
text: NEW YORK

headline: A Deeper Look at the Elections, or Not
text: Along with records for spending by candidates, every presidential election seems to set records for use of technology, and this one is no exception.

headline: Reports on Energy Drinks Show Gaps in Safety Policy
text: The disclosure this week that the deaths of five people since 2009 may be linked to a popular energy drink has revealed major gaps in the way federal regulators and companies monitor product safety.

headline: Life Was in Chaos for Nanny Accused of Killing 2 Children
text: She was unraveling. Yoselyn Ortega’s home was an overcrowded tenement that she yearned to leave. She shared the apartment with her teenage son, a sister and a niece, and roamed the halls selling cheap cosmetics and jewelry for extra money. She had been forced to relinquish a new apartment for her and her son and move back. A woman had chiseled her on a debt. Neighbors found her sulky and remote. She seemed to be losing weight.

headline: Piecework and the Horror of the Jets
text: Halloween holds no fear for the children’s book author R. L. Stine, 69, who has said that nothing scares him. He has been writing fright into his books for 20 years with his “Goosebumps” series, which has sold more than 300 million copies. In addition to his other series, which include “Fear Street,” “Rotten School” and “The Nightmare Room,” the prolific Mr. Stine has written a new horror novel for adults, “Red Rain,” which is out this month. On Sundays, he sticks close to home on the Upper West Side with his wife, Jane, and their 6-year-old Cavalier King Charles spaniel, Minnie.

headline: Tracking the Future of Satellites
text: Polar satellites, which orbit the earth from pole to pole, are a useful tool for forecasting major storms. But existing polar satellites are nearing or beyond their life expectancies.

headline: Nanny Searches, Already Intense, May Become More So
text: The battery of questions that can rain on nannies from prospective employers or agencies often resembles a psychological appraisal, far more probing than mere background and reference checks.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Parking Rules
text: Because of Id al-Adha, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Fister Is Fine, Tigers Say, a Day After Batted Ball Strikes His Head
text: DETROIT — After seeing the frightening play live and then again on television replays, the Detroit Tigers’ head athletic trainer, Kevin Rand, says he still cannot believe that pitcher Doug Fister did not sustain a concussion or worse Thursday night after a line drive off the bat of Gregor Blanco struck him in the head during Game 2 of the World Series.

headline: Cuomo Hits Campaign Trail for New York Democrats in Tight House Races
text: ROCHESTER — Representative Kathy Hochul, New York’s most endangered Democrat in Congress, sat in silence in a plumbers’ union hall on Friday morning, her voice crippled by a sudden case of bronchitis.

headline: Exoneration for a Man in Prison for 2 Years
text: The assault conviction of a Brooklyn man was reversed on Friday after a special investigation by the Brooklyn district attorney’s office revealed he was the victim of mistaken eyewitness testimony and innocent of the crime for which he had already served two years in prison.

headline: A Blended Clientele
text: Grata, a less-than-year-old restaurant on First Avenue near the Queensboro Bridge, has an elegant cuisine that blends the flavors of Italy and France, and one of those improbable New York clienteles that blends the personalities of its two owners: Mirso Lekic, a restaurateur who has been working in the neighborhood for 20 years; and John Cenatiempo, a stuntman and actor who can be seen these days in the Miami gangster drama “Magic City” on the Starz network. On any given night, the darkly sophisticated dining room might host stylish Sutton Place couples, professional mixed-martial artists, visiting Hollywood types, dancers from the strip club Scores down the street or — as on a recent evening — a multigenerational dinner party of Wall Streeters.

headline: Art That Irked Energy Executives Is Gone, but Wyoming Dispute Whirls On
text: LARAMIE, Wyo. — The idea behind the sculpture that appeared on the University of Wyoming campus about 16 months ago was simple but provocative: a swirl of dead wood and lumps of coal, intended to show the link between global warming and the pine beetle infestation that has ravaged forests across the Rockies.

headline: 2 Arrested in Shooting of an Off-Duty Officer
text: Two men wanted in the shooting of an off-duty officer who tried to foil their robbery attempt in the Bronx have been arrested and charged with attempted murder, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Boyfriend Is Questioned in Killing of Woman and Death of a Baby
text: Though she was a petite woman, Luisa Rodriguez usually carried her newborn daughter by herself, in a large stroller, up four flights of stairs to their apartment in the Kingsbridge neighborhood in the Bronx, neighbors said.

headline: Student’s Account Has Rape in Spotlight
text: AMHERST, Mass. — This year has brought news of student athletes charged with sex crimes at Boston University and at Temple, along with countless other less publicized cases. There have been claims that Wesleyan University tolerated a fraternity house where the abuse of women was common. A gang rape at the University of Massachusetts was reported just this week.

headline: A Duck’s Odd Path to Prestige
text: EUGENE, Ore. — After practice Tuesday, Kenjon Barner climbed inside his Camaro, an audacious combination of burnt orange and black stripes with No. 24 decals on the taillights. The engine purred. The bass thumped. Barner, a muscular running back with a Mohawk, pointed the car toward campus.

headline: Qatar Is Becoming a Player in French Sports
text: PARIS — Long an underwhelming also-ran of European soccer, underloved by most everyone but the French, France’s top league has entered what seems a new era, one of eye-popping salaries and international attention. Behind the shift is a tiny desert peninsula in the Persian Gulf, Qatar, a nation with little inherent interest in French soccer but with outsize ambitions and the oil money to pursue them.

headline: Where the Bones of Ships Are Laid to Rest
text: Stretching more than 21 acres along the Arthur Kill tidal strait, a salvage yard is the final resting place for several dozen ships.

headline: A Death in Custody Puts Focus on Police
text: MILWAUKEE — Before he died, Derek Williams pleaded with police officers for help. For about 10 minutes, Mr. Williams, shirtless and handcuffed on suspicion of robbery, claimed he could not breathe, and then collapsed in the back seat of a police cruiser. Finally, the officers began to give CPR. By then it was too late.

headline: Scandal Hints at Decline of U.S. Denominations
text: When World magazine, an evangelical Christian publication, reported last week that Dinesh D’Souza, the outspoken conservative and president of the King’s College, a small Christian liberal arts institution in Manhattan, had checked into a South Carolina motel with a woman who was not his wife, the first obvious question was how a smart man could do something so ill-considered.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Oct. 27
text: Consumers are feeling wealthier, so they are still out there spending.

headline: Depleted Knicks Take Closer Look at Wallace
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — With the Knicks’ frontcourt becoming more and more depleted, Coach Mike Woodson could need significant playing time in the team’s season opener Thursday from the most unlikely source on the roster: Rasheed Wallace.

headline: South Carolina: State Computer System Is Hacked
text: A hacker broke into the state’s computer system, exposing 3.6 million Social Security numbers and 387,000 credit and debit card numbers, state officials said Friday. Gov. Nikki R. Haley said a hacker in another country had staged several cyberattacks on the State Department of Revenue since August. The authorities are urging anyone who has filed a South Carolina tax return since 1998 to contact state law enforcement officials to try to prevent identity theft. Ms. Haley said the authorities were working to find the hacker. “My instructions to them were to slam him to the wall,” she said at a news conference. All but 16,000 of the credit card numbers are protected by encryption, but hackers may be able to decrypt them, the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division said.

headline: Te’o and Toma Brought a Friendship to Notre Dame
text: “All right,” Manti Te’o said to Robby Toma, before announcing to the world that he would play linebacker at Notre Dame, “this is where we go our separate ways.”

headline: Pennsylvania: Judge Rules Against State Utility Panel
text: An appeals court judge on Friday ordered the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission to cease its review of zoning ordinances in four townships, a process that has held up payments from a statewide levy on gas drilling to the municipalities, which are challenging a law restricting local control over the natural gas industry. Judge Keith B. Quigley of Commonwealth Court, who previously ruled that the law was unconstitutional, said the earlier ruling barred the commission from its review. Jennifer Kocher, a spokeswoman for the regulator, said it was reviewing the court’s ruling.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,125 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Princeton Tops the Ivy League After 2 Dismal Seasons
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — It was midterm week on Princeton’s leaf-littered campus, heaping another layer of distraction onto a team suddenly burdened with expectations. Homecoming weekend had passed. A long bus ride to a road game loomed. And a newfound obstacle emerged for Coach Bob Surace and his staff: handling success.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Poets Gather in Exile, in Queens
text: ON a miserable rainy night on the outskirts of Jackson Heights, Queens, a couple of dozen people were gathered for an informal cultural experiment: How do you create a literary community in a place that does not even have a decent English-language bookstore?

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: John Johansen, 96, Last of ‘Harvard Five’ Architects, Is Dead
text: John M. Johansen, a celebrated Modernist architect and the last surviving member of the Harvard Five, a group that made New Canaan, Conn., a hotbed of architectural experimentation in the 1950s and ’60s, died on Friday in Brewster, Mass. He was 96.

headline: Many Fleas, Growing Market
text: Two Brooklyn entrepreneurs, expanding a market whose vendors sold knickknacks and food, have built up a large business by providing platforms for small ones.

headline: Eloy Gutiérrez-Menoyo, Cuban Dissident, Dies at 77
text: Eloy Gutiérrez-Menoyo, who went from fighting beside Fidel Castro as a rebel commander to spending 22 years in prison for trying to topple him, died on Friday in Havana, where he had lived his last years as a tolerated dissident. He was 77.

headline: Saturday’s College Football Matchups
text: Eleven unbeaten teams are left in the Football Bowl Subdivision. One is Ohio State, but because the Buckeyes are ineligible for a Bowl Championship Series game, let’s consider them pigskina non grata. Not so for the teams involved in this week’s biggest matchups.

headline: Kings of a Small-Batch Empire in Brooklyn
text: IN between bites of broccoli pecorino and sweet corn jalapeño fritters, Jonathan Butler and Eric Demby considered the candidate standing over the sizzling griddle in a conference room in Dumbo this month. They mulled her sauces and her sources.

headline: Respecting A-Rod’s Feelings
text: Joe Girardi was so sensitive to Alex Rodriguez’s feelings about being replaced by a pinch-hitter that Girardi made a call to the press box to tell the public-address announcer not to mention Rodriguez’s name during that switch.

headline: The 80-Year-Old Marathon Man
text: EVERY morning, Otto Mond, 80, gets out of bed and runs a mini-marathon at home.

headline: The Long Run
text: Otto Mond, 80, plans to run in his 19th New York City Marathon this year.

headline: When Crimes Feed Our Worst Fears
text: In the spring of last year, over the course of five days, several burglaries occurred in Brooklyn Heights, a neighborhood so untouched by disruptive incident that about the same time, I found a lost billfold in front of a brownstone; it had managed to spend the entire night on the stoop unmolested. As I learned when I opened it, the wallet, containing a credit card and about $60, belonged to the teenage son of my real estate broker.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: MIND GAMES Robert Osborne and Drew Barrymore explain why “Diabolique” (1955), Henri-Georges Clouzot’s thriller about the cruel headmaster of a boarding school (Paul Meurisse) whose wife (Véra Clouzot, above left with Simone Signoret) and mistress (Signoret) plot to kill him, is required viewing. The women drug him, then drown him in a bathtub and dump the body in a pool. But when the pool is drained, the body is gone. It is easy to see why the film’s distributors “are earnestly asking audiences not to reveal how it ends,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times. “And it isn’t only in the last reel that the surprises and the excitement are in evidence. The morbid fascination starts building before the picture is 10 minutes gone. By the time it is rolling toward a climax it is spreading the most delicious chills. It is a pip of a murder thriller, ghost story and character play rolled into one.” The evening continues with “Games” (1967), at 10, starring Signoret as an aging cosmetics saleswoman and amateur medium who joins two Manhattan socialites (James Caan and Katharine Ross) in a series of novel pastimes, this one involving the seduction of an adolescent delivery boy (Don Stroud). And in “What’s the Matter With Helen?” (1971), at midnight, two mothers (Debbie Reynolds and Shelley Winters) move to Hollywood to start a talent school after their sons are convicted of murder.

headline: How to Buy Art When Traveling Abroad
text: The Travel section’s Emily Brennan sat down with Barbara Gladstone, owner of two art galleries in New York and one in Brussels that represent artists in London, Germany and Italy.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Saturday, Oct. 27
text: NEWS  Sectarian violence in Myanmar’s western state of Rakhine has surged again in recent days, with 64 people reported killed in clashes between Buddhist and minority Muslim communities. More Muslims fled to overcrowded refugee camps, and the U.N. secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said Myanmar’s transition to democracy could be jeopardized if “vigilante attacks, targeted threats and extremist rhetoric” are not stopped. Thomas Fuller reports.

headline: Bangalore’s Female Trash Pickers
text: New rules that require Bangalore’s residents to sort their garbage aim to reduce inefficiencies in a system that has the city teeming with open dumps. The dumps attract cows, stray dogs and rats, and are a surprising sight in a city that prides itself as the Silicon Valley of India.

headline: The Weekend Word: Tactics
text: Today’s Times

headline: One On One: Andy Greenberg, Author, “This Machine Kills Secrets”
text: Andy Greenberg is the author of “This Machine Kills Secrets: How WikiLeakers, Cypherpunks, and Hacktivists Aim to Free the World’s Information,” published by Dutton Publishing. Mr. Greenberg, a Forbes writer, interviewed WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange three weeks before he leaked 250,000 State Department files, the largest release of classified materials in history. In that interview, Mr. Assange alluded to another leak — this time involving a major bank — that he likened to the Enron e-mails. Speculation that Assange was referring to Bank of America shaved $3.5 billion off the bank’s market capitalization. But that release never happened. Mr. Greenberg said he wrote the book, in part, to find out why. He traveled to cypherpunk hangouts all over the country and then the world — Iceland, Sweden, Bulgaria, Berlin — to meet Julian Assange’s predecessors and those who seek to build the next WikiLeaks. The following is an edited interview about information and the subculture whose members fight — often among themselves — to free it.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Beekeeping is picking up in the state after years of decline, The Indian Express reported. Honey output has jumped from 300 tons to 597 tons since 2010, according to the article. Apiculture is creating job opportunities, state officials said.

headline: The End of the Berlusconi Era, Maybe

Carolina Performing Arts’ Rite of Spring at 100, a season-long celebration of Igor Stravinsky and Sergei Diaghilev’s epochal ballet, which had its premiere in Paris in May 1913, reached an early climax.

headline: Florida’s Voter Registration Statistics
text: As Florida’s highly coveted voters began going to the polls on Saturday for the first day of in-person early voting at sites across the state, the state released new voter registration statistics that provided reasons for optimism and pessimism for both the Romney and Obama campaigns.

headline: Urgent Warnings as Hurricane Sandy Heads to Northeast
text: More than 50 million people from the mid-Atlantic to New England braced Saturday for a potentially massive storm, as Hurricane Sandy churned northward on a collision course with another storm system that is sweeping in from the west.

headline: Denial of Economics
text: Brad DeLong points us to Howard Davies, who accuses economists of being in denial, and of having had nothing useful to say in the crisis. The first part is definitely true for much of the profession; the second charge is just false. The truth is that basic macroeconomics, the stuff that is still taught in textbooks, has been very, very useful in this crisis. The problem is that half the profession and most policy makers turned their back on this kind of economics.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: College Football Saturday

text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For many N.F.L. players, preparing for a division opponent is like studying for a driver’s license test in a new state. Yes, a few tweaks or changes have been made since the last time they took the exam (no texting behind the wheel, please), but driving will always be driving and, for the Giants at least, the Dallas Cowboys will always be the Dallas Cowboys.

headline: Variety: Ring Toss

headline: Fiorenzo Magni, Italian Cyclist, Dies at 91
text: Fiorenzo Magni, a bicycle racing champion whose fearlessness on descents and fortitude in difficult conditions earned him victories in Europe’s most prominent road races in the postwar years, often described as Italian cycling’s golden age, died on Oct. 19 in Monza, Italy, north of Milan. He was 91.

headline: In Syria, Cease-Fire for Holiday Falls Apart

headline: Hitting the Reset Button on the Campaign
text: It’s been a little more than a month since Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign conspicuously declared a “reset,” when he was lagging in the polls and his prospects seemed grim. It’s been a little more than three weeks since the first debate at the University of Denver, where Mr. Romney brimmed with confidence against a somnolent commander in chief and seemingly turned his election narrative around. In the second debate, Mr. Romney seemed to struggle to hold his own against a more forceful President Obama, who may have benefited from an assist from the moderator, Candy Crowley. The third debate, in which the topics were ostensibly restricted to foreign policy, took place last Monday at Lynn University in Boca Raton, Fla.

text: PENSACOLA, Fla. — At a rally for Mitt Romney on Saturday, Representative Jeff Miller, a Republican from Florida, suggested that President Obama had abandoned the American ambassador to Libya and the employees killed in an attack on a consulate there last month.

He has a real chance. It’s a remarkable turn of events, given how many errors he’s made and how ill suited he is to this particular juncture in the American story. And to size up the situation honestly is to consider one conclusion as seriously as any other:

In a state of post-graduation anxiety early this year, I had paused from my résumé tweaking and cover-letter editing to acknowledge that I was at a loss. That’s when my gut persuaded me to e-mail an author I had never met, and to ask her for advice.

headline: Drumming for the Stars
text: I GREW up in Chevy Chase, Md., in a musical household. My mother sang and danced at Arena Stage in Washington, my brother played the trumpet, and my sister played the flute. When I was 10, a kid in the next cabin at summer camp had a pair of drumsticks and a practice pad that I thought were cool. I asked my parents to buy them for me, but I had studied and dropped both trumpet and piano, so my father made me earn half the money first.

headline: My Monster, My Self
text: In the spring, Edvard Munch’s 1895 work “The Scream,” one of the artist’s now-iconic depictions of terror, sold for $119.9 million at Sotheby’s, setting a record for any work of art sold at auction. This was no “Water Lilies.” We obviously put a high price on our sense of dread.

headline: Geoengineering: Testing the Waters
text: FOR almost 20 years, I’ve been spending time on a craggy stretch of British Columbia’s shoreline called the Sunshine Coast. This summer, I had an experience that reminded me why I love this place, and why I chose to have a child in this sparsely populated part of the world.

headline: Beating Odds in a Season of Improbable Comebacks
text: Brian Billick once received as a gift a book by Knute Rockne. Rockne, who developed a passing offense that helped ignite football’s early appeal, wrote that if coaches had to choose between a good offense and a good defense, they should always choose offense, said Billick, a former Baltimore Ravens coach and current NFL Network and Fox analyst. Rockne’s reasoning resonates even 80 years after his death: with a good offense, a team is never out of a game.

headline: How Prisoners Make Us Look Good
text: A FEW years ago, the sociologists Becky Pettit and Bryan Sykes tried to quantify a worrisome phenomenon: the growing proportion of black men imprisoned by age 20. Focusing on those born between 1975 and 1979 who later dropped out of high school, they noticed an anomaly. “Our initial efforts,” Dr. Pettit recalls, “implied that more young, black, low-skill men had been to prison than were alive.”

headline: For Obama, a Balancing Act of Campaigning and Preparing for a Big Storm
text: NASHUA, N.H. — With 10 days to go until Election Day, President Obama stuck to his plans Saturday and exhorted supporters at a rally here to help him win this state’s tiny but potentially significant four Electoral College votes.

headline: Teaching Lessons
text: How do we help students achieve academically and socially? As a teacher, I have lofty answers. But challenges — and questions — arise when I try to translate my ideas (and ideals) into concrete lessons, delivered in 90-minute increments to a very particular set of sixth graders, each as individual and evanescent as a snowflake.

headline: Will Snakes Inherit the Earth?
text: NAMED P-52, as if she were a fighter plane or a precious fragment of papyrus, the Burmese python recently found in the Everglades weighed 165 pounds and stretched 17 feet in length — a local record. (Not a world record — that was set by a 403-pound, 27-foot-long python living in an Illinois zoo.) A tan beauty, with black splotches, dry satiny skin, and a body like a firm eraser, P-52 had a pyramidal head, a brain surging with raw instinct and tiny black Sen-Sen eyes. In her heyday, she could squeeze the life out of an alligator or a panther. And she was pregnant.

headline: Russian Billionaire Says He Will Concentrate on Politics
text: MOSCOW — Amid heightening pressure on leaders of Moscow street protests, the billionaire Mikhail D. Prokhorov announced on Saturday that he was setting aside his business interests altogether to devote his attention to politics.
