headline: Europe Isn’t Working
text: It seems like every day brings new evidence of what Keynesians have long known: Austerity is counterproductive in times of recession. Just last week, a Times editorial reviewed data from the European Union showing that “countries that have most ruthlessly cut their budgets–Greece, especially–have seen their overall debt loads increase as a share of the economy.”

headline: New Jersey Reels From Storm’s Thrashing
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — New Jersey was reeling on Wednesday from the impact of Hurricane Sandy, which has caused catastrophic flooding here in Hoboken and in other New York City suburbs, destroyed entire neighborhoods across the state and wiped out iconic boardwalks in shore towns that had enchanted generations of vacationgoers.

headline: Fuel for a Data Center, Carried Up 17 Floors

text: President Obama has completed his helicopter tour of storm damage in New Jersey with Gov. Chris Christie. The two lavished praise on each other before boarding Marine Force One for their hourlong survey of the devastation. Some political commentators have found the situation ironically humorous, given Governor Christie’s acerbic attacks on the president in the past.Thursday, 7:49 a.m. | Updated  Mark Landler and Michael Barbaro’s article is here.

headline: Icahn Takes Stake and Netflix Shares Surge
text: We have seen this movie before, though the ending this time is unclear.

headline: Hurricane Sandy and the Need for More Paperwork for Mortgages
text: A colleague whose home is located in an area affected by Hurricane Sandy thought he had signed the final papers last week for a refinance of his mortgage. But on Wednesday, his lender said that because his home was in a declared disaster area, he’d have to provide additional documents.

headline: Otherworldly People With Earthy Tastes
text: “Let me say right off, I’m a witch,” Sowa (the charming Tony Award-nominated actress and singer Lonette McKee) tells the audience at the Castillo Theater, getting the New Federal Theater’s production of “Sowa’s Red Gravy” off to an engaging start.

headline: Best Basketball Programs? Coaches Make the Call
text: Every five years, Basketball Times publishes an analytical ranking of the top men’s college basketball programs in the United States (full disclosure: I compile it).  The qualifying criterion is teams that have won at least two-thirds of their games over the past 10 seasons, and in the latest version from the November 2012 issue, 33 programs made the cut.  The teams were then ranked using six equally weighted criteria: winning percentage; number of former players currently in the N.B.A.; federal graduation rate; academic reputation, as determined by U.S. News & World Report; and coaching and perceived program “cleanliness” as ranked by a panel.

headline: What Is Your Hurricane Comfort Food?
text: While waiting out Hurricane Sandy, my daughter and I resorted to mindless snacking. Maybe it was the worry of not knowing what was to come, or the chill in the air as the first rains smacked at our windows, but we sought comfort in food, munching on chips and guacamole, cheese and crackers, grapes and cookies, as we waited for the storm to hit.

headline: Bill Simmons Has a New TV Gig, and Some N.B.A. Predictions
text: Bill Simmons of ESPN, the Sports Guy and founder of Grantland, a sports Web site, has a new addition to his résumé. ESPN has added Simmons and Jalen Rose to “NBA Countdown,” the network’s N.B.A. pregame show, and the two will join the 2011-12 holdovers Michael Wilbon and Magic Johnson. In an interview, Simmons spoke about his role on “Countdown” and his predictions for the 2012-13 season. The Q.&A. was condensed and edited.

headline: Glimmers of Light Downtown
text: A FONDUE pot and a pack of Sterno helped Nicole Miller, the fashion designer, weather Hurricane Sandy and the stubbornly persistent blackout that followed it in the apartment she shares with her family on the 10th floor of a building in TriBeCa.

headline: Germany: Leverkusen Makes History
text: History was made last weekend in Germany when Sami Hyypia’s Bayer Leverkusen overcame 22-time Bundesliga champion Bayern Munich in the heart of Bavaria for the first time in more than 23 years.

headline: A Life Captured With Luster Left Intact
text: “Art is confession; art is the secret told,” Thornton Wilder wrote shortly after fame and the first of his three Pulitzer Prizes had come to him in his early 30s. “But art is not only the desire to tell one’s secret; it is the desire to tell it and hide it at the same time.” That suggestive formulation is as evocative today as it was when Wilder penned it in 1928. But now we are more likely to associate specific literary genres with the heart’s hidden truths: the ever-billowing genre of memoir is confession, we might say, and biography is the secret told.

headline: Sounding the Warning on Preparedness for Hurricane Sandy
text: The Times had a strong story on the front page Wednesday under a headline that says a great deal: “For Years, Warnings That It Could Happen Here.”

headline: New Piece Added to Puzzle of Truman Capote’s ‘Answered Prayers’
text: A small piece of Truman Capote’s famously unfinished novel “Answered Prayers” has come to light. The six-page story, “Yachts and Things,” found among Capote’s papers in the Manuscripts and Archives Division of the New York Public Library, is published in the December issue of Vanity Fair, out now in New York and nationally next week. The story will be available online in mid-November.

headline: Seeking a Solution, One Tiny Tube at a Time
text: LAST year, Liz Corry, a product manager for an e-commerce site who lives in Pittsburgh, realized she needed to do something about her sprawling stockpile of beauty samples. She emptied two drawers in her bedroom dresser and transplanted roughly 600 Lilliputian tubes of moisturizers, eye serums, lip glosses and other miniature promises of reinvention.

headline: Wheelies: The Hurricane Sandy Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Disaster Preparedness
text: You wonder how you would react if you didn’t know any better. If there were no warnings, no wind-flapped newscasters standing in rivers-come-lately, no tin shelves cleared of water and bread. What then? Would you just go about your day thinking, I guess it’s really autumn now, huh?

headline: In Shape, but Out of Focus
text: LIFE may offer worse comedowns. But not many. You train for your big race. You put in the hours and crank out the miles. All your friends say you look terrific. Marathon morning, you pin on your number, run, sweat and finish. A triumph for you and your fabulous body.

headline: Potash Confirms Deal Talks with Israel Chemicals
text: OTTAWA –The Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan confirmed on Wednesday that it has approached the government of Israel about increasing its stake in Israel Chemicals, another fertilizer maker.

headline: House Hunting in ... New Zealand

headline: In New Zealand, a Home With a Harbor View
text: This glass-encased house near Auckland was designed to create the impression of living without walls.

headline: App Snapshots: Storm Diversions
text: Returning to normal life, for many, has been a struggle after the storm, and there might not be as much time as usual for politics. So ease back in slowly with some lighter news you might have missed, plus some unusual insights into the race in the key states of Florida and Ohio. We collect the best of it all, essential and diversionary on the Election 2012 app.

headline: The Worst Thing About an Apocalypse? Surviving It
text: This month, The Times of London published the final issue of a monthly science magazine called Eureka, yet another casualty of the poor economy and the growing pressure on print publications. The magazine’s editors had an inspired idea of how to say goodbye — an issue devoted to The End of Life as We Know It.

headline: Timely | Seeing the Light
text: The Shy light collection, a modular system of L.E.D. tubes and elegant brass and aluminum hardware by Bec Brittain, is multifaceted in every sense of the word. Brittain has designed more than 20 versions of this crystalline pendant (that’s Shy 088 hanging over her head), each one of which can be hung from any point in its frame. What is more, “there are still many things in my brain I want to exploit with it,” says Brittain, who set up her studio last year. Brittain herself is something of a shape shifter. She briefly studied product design but went on to get degrees in philosophy and architecture. For three years she worked as the design director for the lighting designer Lindsey Adelman, all the while making braided leather jewelry, hilariously monstrous bug sculptures and crystal-dusted rope “waterfalls” in her spare time. This fall, Brittain will introduce two new faceted fixtures, and a pyrite-inspired pendant that she designed for the rapid-prototyping company .MGX will make its debut next spring at the Milan design fair. Still, she is not quite ready to settle into the title of lighting designer. “I’d like to explore the possibility of bringing the materiality and femininity of my other projects into my design work,” she says, adding, as if to remind herself, “You can only do so many things at once.”

headline: French Socialists, Under Fire, Display a Lack of Fraternité
text: PARIS — The symbol of the victorious French Socialist Party is the rose, but the bloom is off five months after François Hollande won the presidency, and the petals are blowing around.

headline: Red Bulls, D.C. Switch Dates
text: In the wake of Hurricane Sandy, and its impact on Northern New Jersey, D.C. United has ceded its home-field advantage and flopped home playoff dates with the Red Bulls.

headline: Marathon Preparation Continues
text: Timekeepers for the New York Marathon continue their preparations despite complications from Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Nov. 1
text: Puffy outerwear gets some panache, and Anthem Wares offers hard-to-find accessories.

headline: Classes Take a Tumble, Happily
text: FOR Carmen Hernandez, something flipped last summer when Gabby Douglas did.

headline: Christie and Obama Tour Storm-Ravaged Coast and Exchange Compliments
text: 5:25 p.m. | Updated  WASHINGTON — President Obama stood shoulder to shoulder with Chris Christie, the Republican governor of New Jersey, Wednesday afternoon, offering reassurance in the wake of devastating storm damage — and a politically powerful picture of bipartisanship just days before the election.

headline: Recalling Your Kindergarten Teacher and the Nonchalance of Adolescence
text: Adults tend to talk down to children’s theater. If a show can make a kid sit still, not offend or insult anyone’s intelligence, then it’s good enough, right?

headline: Iran Supreme Leader Warns Subordinates to Stop Bickering
text: TEHRAN — In his clearest warning that political infighting by his subordinates must end, Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said Wednesday that their public disputes would be treated as treason.

headline: Spring Is Here, or at Least It Is in North Carolina
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — Finally it arrived on Tuesday night: Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring,” performed at Memorial Hall on the campus of the University of North Carolina here by the Mariinsky Orchestra, conducted by Valery Gergiev. It had been a long, hard road: longest for those who attended the academic conference “Reassessing ‘The Rite,’ ” from Thursday through Sunday, leading up to Mariinsky concerts on Monday and Tuesday; hardest for Mr. Gergiev and the orchestra members, who had to compress their itinerary to outpace Hurricane Sandy.

headline: ‘Not Universal and Not Equal’
text: Reuters reported today that the man who runs the Russian election commission, who is famous primarily for helping Vladimir Putin defraud the Russian public, is highly critical of an electoral system that he says does not work very well – the one in the United States. “The U.S. presidential election is not direct, not universal and not equal, and it does not safeguard the secrecy of voting,” the official, Vladimir Churov, wrote in an article for the government newspaper Rossiyskaya Gazeta. “The electoral system and electoral laws in the United States are far from perfect.”

headline: Sex and the Weight of National History
text: EARLY in “Mies Julie,” a South African adaptation of Strindberg’s play, a domestic servant takes a garden fork to the kitchen floor of her boss’s house in a feverish attempt to free her ancestors’ spirits, trapped beneath flagstones that were placed over a burial ground. In moments like this South African history merges with Strindberg’s drama in a production that speaks boldly about that nation today.

headline: New York Start-Ups Become Officemates in Hurricane Sandy Aftermath
text: As the city of New York struggles to get back online in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, many companies and start-ups are trying to regain their footing and restart operations.

headline: Found in Translation: A Star Is Born
text: Hurricane Sandy has spawned an unlikely star: Lydia Callis, the sign-language interpreter for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. During televised news conferences updating New Yorkers on the storm, her dancelike hand signing and emotive facial expressions won her legions of Twitter fans, even as their cellphone batteries were later drained by blackouts.

headline: Where Creations Faced Destruction
text: The first thing you noticed walking through the streets lined with art galleries between 10th and 11th Avenues in Chelsea, on Wednesday, was the constant, undulating roar of generators, and the hoses, in clumps of three or four, snaking out of just about every gallery, from which cold water that had come flooding in from the Hudson River now gushed into the street. But if you peeked into the darkened galleries — no one here had electricity — you got a sense of the toll Hurricane Sandy has taken on the district, an important part of the arts economy.

headline: Two Films in Which Classical Music Is Much More Than a Score
text: LOS ANGELES — If the movie is about music, age, the politics of performance and the peculiar magic of a piece composed for an ensemble of four, it might be “A Late Quartet,” which is to open in New York and other cities on Friday.

headline: Total Cost of Election Could Be $6 Billion
text: The total cost of the 2012 election could reach $6 billion, according to estimates from a leading research organization, which would obliterate the previous record by more than $700 million.

headline: Sotheby’s Delays Auction
text: Hurricane Sandy is affecting next week’s important art auctions in New York. Sotheby’s announced on Wednesday afternoon that its sale of Impressionist and modern art had been postponed to next Thursday. (It was to have taken place on Monday.) The reasons, Sotheby’s officials said, are travel delays and fears that collectors and dealers would not have time to view the paintings, drawings and sculptures before the sale.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  BlackBerry Women, and Ghost-Hunting Tech
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Lederer Memorial Trophy in London
text: The Lederer Memorial Trophy is a popular event with the experts who are invited to play. Held on Sept. 29 and 30 in London, the event drew players from eight countries, including the Colonies team of John Carruthers and Joey Silver from Canada and Milt Rosenberg and Howard Weinstein from the United States.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New Jersey and Elsewhere
text: Photos from New Jersey, New York, Argentina and Pakistan.

headline: Relief Valves for Flooded Social Networks
text: It doesn’t take a hurricane, a presidential debate or an Apple product announcement to find yourself overwhelmed by the ceaseless flood of updates pouring into your social networks.

headline: Shell Ends Alaska Offshore Drilling for the Year
text: Shell Oil had its problems this year drilling off the Arctic coast of Alaska, but on Wednesday it declared success on the final day of operations for the season. (Only a brief autumn exploration season is allowed by regulators because of ice flows.)

headline: Clip: 'A Late Quartet'
text: A scene from the drama "A Late Quartet," directed by Yaron Zilberman.

headline: Romney in Tampa, Fla.
text: Mitt Romney gave a speech at a campaign event on Wednesday in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Movie Showtimes and Reviews, Never Out of Arm’s Reach
text: With the autumn film season about to hit its stride now through the holidays, a time when Hollywood has the Oscars in mind, the smartphone might be a moviegoer’s best friend.

headline: An Increase in Scrutiny for Generics
text: The Food and Drug Administration said it was looking more closely at the way generic companies made extended-release drugs after it found one such medicine failed to work as well as its brand-name counterpart.

headline: Designing a Home for a Wallflower
text: If there was ever a show that makes the case that young adults should get their own place as soon as possible, it is “The Heiress,” the story of a shy young woman, Catherine Sloper, living with her belittling and domineering physician father in a town house on Washington Square. The play, adapted from a Henry James novel, is set in the mid-1800s, however, when moving out was not so easy. Also, as the latest Broadway revivalshows, the Sloper residence is a great place: the parlor has Corinthian pillars, elaborately painted cornice work and stately furnishings. The set designer of the show (scheduled to open Thursday at the Walter Kerr Theater) is the Tony winner Derek McLane, who will be creating the sets for this year’s Oscar awards and whose credits include “Follies” and “Anything Goes.” This reporter met him recently on the set to learn what’s involved in recreating a drawing room from the past.

headline: Sales at DwellStudio, Blu Dot and Others
text: The dates of these sales may be affected by the storm.

headline: Back When They Were Doing Chores
text: Though big money has seeped into presidential politics to an astonishing degree, you would never know it from flipping through “Houses of the Presidents,” by Hugh Howard (Little, Brown, $40).

headline: Update on Hurricane Sandy — 5:30 P.M.
text: TimesCast: The latest updates on the recovery efforts in New York City and beyond.

headline: Online, and Newly Witty
text: To spice up its upholstery options, the furniture company Sofa.com, which normally deals in solids and stripes, is partnering with outside designers. Its latest collection is a collaboration with Thornback & Peel, a British company that produces tastefully quirky screen-printed housewares.

headline: Finishing Touch for Hire
text: The punch list — the final details in a construction project — doesn’t always get done. A contractor walks off the job. An architect is fired. The home isn’t finished, and the client is not pleased.

headline: Rare Rags and Patches from Exotic Places
text: The commercial interior designer Mae Festa, an expert in antique textiles, bought plenty herself over 50 years, from a 19th-century ceremonial Japanese bag, far left, to an Uzbeki yurt hanging, left, to an intricately woven Tibetan monk’s robe that she purchased from a woman who flagged her down on West End Avenue.

headline: On Sandy and Humanity’s ‘Blah, Blah, Blah Bang’ Disaster Plans
text: Nov. 1, 11:53 a.m. | Updated Below |For millions of people in the New York metropolitan region and adjacent areas flooded, scorched, and pummeled by the extraordinary hybrid storm once known as Sandy, arguments about how much of the storm’s ferocity was human-created are secondary.

headline: Market Ready

text: Thomas Fernez, who attributes his fascination with animals to growing up in Manhattan, shops for a menagerie of interesting housewares.

headline: On Twitter, Sifting Through Falsehoods in Critical Times
text: During Hurricane Sandy’s peak, Twitter was abuzz with activity, as tens of thousands of people turned to the microblogging service for alerts, updates and real-time reports and photographs of the storm.

text: ALMOST every item in the Thomas Paul housewares collection features animals: horses, birds, whales, even octopuses, printed on throw pillows, bedding, decorative boxes, shower curtains.

text: Community gardens have transformed vacant parcels of land into green abodes of urban agriculture. Now, they just need caretakers.

headline: Uber Struggles to Get Cars Onto New York’s Streets
text: In New York post-Sandy, the lack of subways can be just as troubling as the lack of electricity. New Yorkers, who typically live in cramped apartments, rely on the subway system to jump between their homes and offices, and to connect with friends and family elsewhere.

headline: An Unlikely Political Pair, United by a Disaster
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama toured the storm-tossed boardwalks of New Jersey’s ravaged coastline on Wednesday, in a vivid display of big-government muscle and bipartisan harmony that confronted Mitt Romney with a vexing challenge just as he returned to the campaign trail in Florida.

headline: Hurricane Sandy: View From Above
text: Watching the hurricane from the 51st floor of the New York Times building.

headline: Giants Shift Focus From Storm to Steelers
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A photo of Eli Manning staring at the rising water in the lobby of his apartment building in nearby Hoboken made the Internet rounds on Tuesday. Manning, the Giants quarterback, held a flashlight in his left hand and was snapping a picture of the flood on his cellphone with his right.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg Speaks About Sandy
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg updates New York City on the recovery from Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Idealism Harder to Find From Young Volunteers
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — With his wire-rimmed glasses and Salvador Dali mustache, Caleb Cunningham does not exactly look like the stereotypical young conservative. He crochets his own stocking caps, and after graduating from Brigham Young University last spring he spent six weeks trekking through Cambodia, Malaysia and other parts of Southeast Asia before landing in Washington with a used BMW and a job waiting tables. He currently shares a two-bedroom apartment with three roommates (only two of whom pay rent).

headline: Turkey Given Reassurance by Germany on Talks
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany met with Turkey’s prime minister here on Wednesday and pledged that the European Union would continue to pursue talks “in good faith” over Turkey’s accession to the bloc, despite disagreements that have proved challenging for both sides.

headline: Grover Cleveland’s Hurricane
text: A DEVASTATING storm slams into New York City; within days, another hits the coasts of Georgia and South Carolina. The president refuses to allow the federal government to coordinate relief efforts. No, it’s not a glimpse into a future without the Federal Emergency Management Agency under a Romney administration. It’s what happened in August 1893, and the consequences of the government’s inaction offer valuable lessons today.

text: BEIJING

headline: Hoboken After Hurricane Sandy
text: Hoboken, N.J., struggles to recover after flooding caused by Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Yankees’ Soriano to Seek Deal Elsewhere
text: When Mariano Rivera was injured in May and was lost for the season with a knee injury, the Yankees’ initial plan was for Dave Robertson to replace him. That plan quickly changed because of Robertson’s early failures and subsequent rib-cage injury.

headline: Medical Journal to Require More Details on Drug Trials
text: The British Medical Journal has announced that, beginning in January, it will no longer publish the results of clinical trials unless drug companies and researchers agree to provide detailed study data on request.
